Was thinking I could attack the king from g2 or h2 if I can get a knight to support
I missed his guaranteed bishop capture
I can protect one...
I didn't think it through - he can easily escape check, and I can't press in

Black resigned - impending pawn promotion, I figured lost cause at this point. Final takeaway - first game in a while, but I wasn't thinking even a couple moves ahead, and White had the initiative pretty much the whole time, as well as most of center control from the start - which allowed him to take out my entire pawn structure. Add in a couple bad blunders on my part...not even pretty. Annotator: You are to be commended for submitiing a game in which you lost; It would have been easy to fall for the temptation in sending in a winning game, but we typically learn more from - dang it - losing, as much as it hurts. (++ I took the liberty of looking at recent games played by you FICS to get a more accurate sense of your strengths and areas for improvement; This is what I like seeing: 1) You are playing slow games, and not speed games; fast games are fun but can lead to superficial thinking and sloppy play; 2) I can tell that you are taking your time on your moves; 3) I liked how you handled some endgames, and the aggressive play during some skirmishes. For areas on which to work, I note: 1) Tactics are needing improvement; Both you, and sometimes your opponents, are missing one and two move combos; Sometimes pieces are left en prise. Ways to improve this? Depending on the time and money you wish to spend, for books I recommend: book - Manual of Chess Combinations 1a & 1b by Ivanshenko; software - Chess Tactics for Beginners put out by Convetka); I hope you are not put off by the "beginner's" label, but I think the books/software recommendations are accurate, and there are follow up texts/software for intermediate and advanced. 2) The opening needs some study. A book I like, despite its age and its being in descriptive notation is Chess Openings Theory and Practice by Horowitz. The analysis is indeed dated, but lines are explained and many illustrative games are provided. The book can probably be found on www.abe.com. I am sure there are alternatives that are newer, but I would avoid books with endless columns and little explanation. I hope my input provides either/or instruction or entertainment. Please leave a message on FICS to jaberwock if you have questions.++)

Nc6 is usually played, but I just wanted to avoid Bg5. razim: Bg5 is not so a tremendous shot, so 3...Nc6 or 3.. .c6, directly controlling the center, are better. Moreover, h6 weakens the g6 square. f4 looks like a good try for White now, looking forward to exploit the f-file
Bc5 b4 chases the bishop.
Another plan was Qe2, Rd1 and d4
better 9... a4
Trans posing into a Ruy Lopez with the particularity that white's d pawn stopped on d3 and black played h6.

White was ready for d4 now, gaining the initiative, for example: 14.d4 cxd 15.cxd Rfc8 Bd3 with some advantage for White. b3 allows Black to play Nc6, answering d4 with cxd cxd Nb4 Bb1 Rf8-c1 and then Nc2. A tricky move is Nh4, for instance: 14.Nh4 Nxe4 (typical tactical reaction) 15.Rxe4 and if ...d5, then 16.Rg4, and now 16...f5 is a big mistake due to the Rook sacrifice 17.Rxg7+ Kxg7 18.Bxh6+! with a devastating attack. 14. Nf5 is worth a try, too
now Black is at least equal
the Bc2 is buried alive behind the pawns for a few moves. Black's strategical idea was b5, so c4 is just helping Black to realize his plan
Nd4 with the idea f5 was interesting too. Another idea was trying to get the control of the a-file by a5-a4
At the right time. Black has resolved the opening nicely and even has a tiny advantage. razim: I agree, Black has some pressure on hisopponent's castle now
I think Bxf5 is better. Black knight is well placed on d4. It controls the important f3 square.
Now White has some counterplay due to the idea Bf3-d5. The Bishop is alive again
there's no point in exchanging the Bishop. White's answer just improves his position

Nf6 was better. It had to keep control over d5. I missed the simple next move... razim: Ng5 could not be the best move, but Nf6 was a big mistake because of Rxf5. I would suggest ...Be6 in order to prevent the next maneuvre. The position is balanced
gaining space
White has a good position now, but I believe Black is still far from beeing lost
the Bishop is misplaced now
White controls the f-file
I can't find other ideas for Black. White threatens Nf1-e3 and then maybe Nd5 or g4

Bf7 to protect d5 followed by g6 was another idea, and I suspect the only one. The drawback of Be8 is, as you will see, that the more or less forced move g6 gives White time to play Nd5 threatening Nf6+ gaining the Bishop. That's not possible with the Bishop on f7. I have to admit I'm not very skilled in endgames, but in my opinion White will not be able to break through. In fact, this ending itself is very interesting. Let's see: 35...Bf7 38. Ne3 g6 39.Nd5 Bxd5 40.exd and the game should be drawn. It is not easy for White to find a plan to win. Black has time to bring his King in the centre and maybe even to try to win the game himslef by playing a5-a4-a3 Ba4-Bxb3 if White plays innacurately.

It was not too late to play g6. razim: I think this move, theoretically speaking, can be the introduction to an interesting counterplay idea connected with 35...Be8: a4-a3 and Ba4, threatening Bxb3 and if the b-pawn takes the Bishop then b3. Always look for tactical possibilities in the position. Unfortunately this idea isn't playable now: 37.Nf5 (as in the game) a4 38.Nxd6 attacking the Bishop and then Nb5, and White will gradually improve his position, or even more simply bxa4 followed by Nb7-Nxc5. So g6 seems to be the only move, but there is a problem: 37.Nd5 threatens Nf6+ winning the Bishop, so Black can move either the King or the Bishop. Let's see some variants: 37.Nd5 Kg7 38.Nc7 Bd7 (attacking g4) 39.g5, and black hasn't enough time to find a counterplay, ex. ...Bg4 40. Ne8 and Nxd6, or 39...a5 40. Nb5 and the d6 pawn is lost (40...Bxb5 41.cxb and the pawn promotes). 37...Bc6 instead of Kg7 is simply met by Nc7 and Black will lose a pawn. So I think that in fact it was to late to play g6 and that the position is already lost.

this is a big mistake by White! Now it's Black who has a chance to win the game! Nf5 is imple and best, as you can see from the following variation: 37.. Bd7 (a4 38.Nxd6 Bc6 39. bxa Bxa4 40.Nb7 Bc2 41.Nxc5 Bb1 42.Ke3 winning) 38.Nxd6 Bxg4 39.Nf7! Kg6 (...Bd1 40.Nxe5 a4 41.bxa Bxa4 42. Ke3 g5 43.hxg hxg 44.d4 and White is winning) 40.Nxe5+ Kh5 41.Nxg4 Kxg4 42.d4! winning the pawn endgame.

Still ignores g6. Seeking for trouble. razim: the decisive mistake. 37...Bc6 was interesting: 38.Nf5 a4 39. Nxd6 (39.bxa4 Bxa4 and then Bc2-b1) a3! with the idea Ba4. The point of Bc6 instead of Bd7is that White cannot reach the c5 square (Nd6-b7-Nxc5, and Black is lost). But obviously the a4-a3 plan needs no prophylactic moves, so let's try 37...a4! immediately, and if 38. Nf5 (bxa4 Bxa4 and Black has enough counterplay) a3 39.Nxd6 then Ba4! is already winning for Black.
Forced not to lose a pawn... razim: Now it is too late to play a4-a3. The pawn endgame is lost

As a general advice, I would suggest you to check out for tactical details in the position. Sometimes a little difference in the move order might cause quite a big difference in the result of the game. You can find tactics almost everywhere in chess, so always play carefully, even in the endgame - of course this is an advice I should be giving to myself, too!

prevent to lose e-pawn, so pushed it. joeva: I will start my comments here. So far, you have probably gone wrong in 'theory' already, but you're still in the game. This move kicks the knight f6 out of it's preferred defensive position, leaving black's kingside potentially vulnerable.

castle for safe king, didn't see Nxc3 threat. joeva: Again, you should work on your tactics, to see these threats ahead of time. However, castling here really isn't that bad. Even though it loses a pawn, I know quite a few decent players who would play this as a sacrifice in order to finish development and then turn towards the black kingside, which is remarkably abandoned by the black pieces.

lost a pawn here. joeva: again, it's not that bad. Pawns do count in the endgame, but in open middlegames like this one, they're really just in your pieces' way. I know, a pawn is still a pawn and enough to win in the end, but don't be afraid to lose a few, if you can get an attack on your opponent's king in turn. It may not be enough, objectively, but the defender always has many more problems to solve and opponents at your level (or mine, for that matter) will almost never find the objectively best defence.
your opponent finishes development, but it would have been better to move the knight c7 over to the kingside, to have at least one defender there.
little threat on h7. joeva: this 'little threat' should be enough to give you at least an even game, see my variation below.

at least weakend pawn structure. joeva: yes, then why do you not try to exploit it? There are several things to do when your opponents castled position has a weakness such as this: put your pieces in the holes left on f6 and h6 (in the text, you exchange all the pieces that could go there such as the knight and the Bc1-very bad); cause further weaknesses, for example by provoking/forcing . ..h5 (after the immediate Qh3, this would be forced); look for a way to sac a piece to remove the pawncover so the rest of your pieces can get to the king(again possible in the variation below).

going to trade 2 pieces for rook and pawn. joeva: that's a bad trade, even if you were not down a pawn. The two pieces are almost always more active than R+P, even if theoretically the trade may be even. In this particular position it's even worse, because you are trading off two of your most important attackers (knight attacking h7, bishop pinning f7) and attack is the only hope you've got left.

pro bably bad move because blacks bishop bad positioned. joeva: not only is the black B out of play, but your blacksquared bishop should stay on the board to start an attack on the black king on the weakened black squares on the kingside.
now your position is quite bad: you're down materially with no compensation whatsoever to show for it.

another bad move lost e-pawn. joeva: well, I cannot find a good move for white here, as Rfd1, to protect the d4-pawn is met by Ne7, followed by either Bd5, c6, Nf5 or Nd5 when your central pawns are blockaded and black can slowly increase the pressure. I don't know, if you know this, but central pawns are strong, if they can stay next to each other or advance without being blockaded, but are weak if they are blockaded along a diagonal. yours would be the second kind, so the text move could actually be considered an attempt of creating complications at the cost of a pawn. However, if you didn't see that this move loses the pawn, then, again, working on your tactics and "board vision" should be your primary concern for future studies.

This was a very tough Email chess game I played recently. I've annotated it with my thoughts written down during the game.
as you well know this formation is called Maroczy Bind

Black's problem in this formation is the extreme difficulty of achieving the Sicilian break with d7-d5. White has such dominating control of the d5 square that Black must, more or less, abandon this crucial idea, at least during the opening. In recent years, methods have been found to limit the impact of the Maroczy Bind, nevertheless, if you want to play the Dragon in its pure form, you shouldn't want to be drawn into these dangerous waters.

List of imbalances: Minor pieces: White knights are equal to Black knights. Both black bishops are active and good. The white Bd3 is "bad", Be3 is good. Pawn structure: White's e4 and c4 pawns can become targets later. a2 can also potentially become weak, but that's not where the action is. Space: White has more space. Files or key squares: Black has half-open c file. Fantasy position for me would be to advance my d-pawn to d6, pawns on g4 and h4 my rooks on h8 and g8, bishops on b7 and c7. With all of this, I chose the next move.

Generally speaking there are a couple of rules: the first is "King safety and develop pieces": your a-rook is not developed. The second rule is "don't start a wing attack if the center isn't blocked". Of course there are some exceptions but it's not easy to play such a game. Maybe the move from Kortschnoj is a good idea. MH: Computers play for tactical shots and in a mostly open position like this they're going to see lots of potential targets. As a human, I'd look at Nf3-g5 and the h7 target and if that didn't look very good I'd consider Nf3-e5, leaving Bg4 with no way to trade off, exposed, undefended and un-utilized. Which file to control isn't so important, but Re3 isn't good coordination with Qd2. If Black can trade ... Bg4xf3 and ...Rf8xf3 and secure h7, then he can aim for an ending where Nc6 might be better than Bd3 at attacking weak White pawns on dark squares.

Simply a tactical shot? Or, guarding against Nf3-g5? Both are tactical elements, so I'd say it found the best move to play defense and offense with regard to those tactical elements. Positionally I'd be hoping for rook penetration to the 7th rank, so your response makes good sense.
What important purpose could this possibly serve? Much better is either ...Bxf3 or ...Bf5 to get rid of a good White piece. Bg4 has nothing better to do.

Computers consider bishops more valuable than knights in nearly all situations, so it simply won't trade. It would rather bury it's own bishop than trade for a knight when It can't see a tactical necessity for the trade.

Uninspired offensive play. Rf2 doesn't threaten anything, doesn't improve the piece significantly and gets in the way of Qe1-g3 (which might be of some use later). You clearly need to have more offensive ideas at your fingertips in order to play this kind of position well and with confidence.

Aside from knowing the knight needed to move, what was in your mind that you would be achieving with this position for the knight? What does it do? There is the Re3-f3 threat, but that's something for the rook to do. What does the knight do at d2? Using your pieces to their fullest will usually involve threatening or executing a tactic. I'd suggest you study and practice ways to fully utilize your pieces to both improve their general mobility and utility and to execute tactics. A related issue is deciding when and which pieces to trade or avoid trading. Getting rid of your opponent's best pieces is clearly related to which of them could do tactical damage to your position. Knowing which of your pieces needs to be kept on the board relates to which can do real tactical damage (from somewhere on the board) in the future. Playing computer programs will help you see weaknesses in your own position and the next step would be learning how to neutralize their attacks and then you'll want to know how to improve your own pieces to possibly generate tactical threats of your own. Tactically wiping out the opponent while keeping your side safe is the ultimate.

All through the game I was anxious to castle and to get my queen-side pieces out, but never did TiredOfTheWar: The thing with most unusual gambits is, that they aren't very sound. The real reason they are being played is because the white player hopes the black player is not familiar with this line of play and will make errors. The best way to tackle gambits you're not familiar with is to grap the first pawn, and after that follow the standard opening "rules". You could also decline the gambit (here for instance with 2. ... e7e5) to play on safe, but that will give white some advantage in the centre. Whatever you do, never try to defend the pawn advantage when you are playing an unfamiliar gambit. Know that you will at one point give white the pawn back and try to force white to take the pawn back when it suits you best.

I don't really like this move. The reason behind 2. b2b4 was to remove the c5 pawn so white could get a strong, classical centre (d4,e4) and then use that centre to obtain material advantage in the middle game. I think 3. d2d4 or 3. Ng1f3 were better.
Solid move. Actively challenging whites centre.
Threatening Qe5+

Maybe this wasnt as smart as I thought... TiredOfTheWar: After cxb4, exf3, Qxf3, Qxf3, gxf3 white wins a pawn but has a very weak pawn structure. White has the bishop pair and with such an open position they can become quite strong. This is still an undecided position. Instead of e4, I think simply moving your bishop to safety (d6,e7 or even f8) would have been better.
Not the best move. Better was the line described above.

Seemed so natural at the time that I didn't pay attention, and never saw the next move coming. TiredOfTheWar: Well, Bd7 isn't a bad move and Bc4 isn't a real threat. You'll see why below. In general, whenever you move a piece, that piece will give up control over certain squares. When you give up control over certain squares, check and doublecheck if the opponent can take advantage of that. The square you are giving up control here is b7. If you would have taken a little more time here trying to figure out how white can take advantage here of the weakened b7, you would have surely found Bc4 followed by Qb3. But as said above, Bd7 was not a bad move.
A nasty shock I never recovered from.

Not a good move. Better was Nc6, giving white the opportunity to win back his pawn, but giving black the lead in development. After Nc6, Bxf7+, Ke7; how is white better than black? His queen is pinned to the defence of his bishop at f7. You threaten to win a pawn with Bxd4, cxd4, Nxd4. His gambit didn't lead to a better development. No, I think if anything, black is slightly better after Nc6.

Is this better 13. ..Qc6 14.Qb3 O-O TiredOfTheWar: Well, Qc6 was much better than Bc6, but after Qb3, O-O would be a big mistake (Ba3 attacking your rook at f8 and threatening to play Bd5). After Qc6, Qb3, and some move by black to disarm the threat Bd5 (maybe something like Qc7 or Qd6) I would say white has the advantage but it is still a playable position.

The game was probably lost by now TiredOfTheWar: No, not lost. At recreational level, the amount of errors in a single game is very high. While white undoubtedly has the advantage here, you should never give up. Keep looking for the best possible move and you'll see that you will win a lot of games where you thought you were dead lost.

Better was Nd7, threatening to come to b6 to maintain the balance in the centre. Also, Nd7 brings you one move closer to connecting your rooks, which is vital as the battle for the open files is about to commence.
This pawn move was unnecessary. It was better to keep on developing with Nd7, rather than trying to fortify your centre with f5.
This was probably the biggest error in the game. After d6 you will lose your rook at a8 to the unavoidable Nc7. The better way to support the a pawn was to simply move it up the board with a5.

The bottom line of this game is twofold. In unknown gambits, maintain your cool and find the best possible way for you to give back the pawn you won. Don't try to hold on to the pawn as that will usually lead to heavy underdevelopment. Secondly, never give up. After Qc8+, there is still material balance. Quickly develop your pieces, maybe even at the cost of a pawn. To sum it all up; Material is not everything, if you have the material advantage but your pieces are all on the back rank, how is that advantage helping you? Focus some more on positional play. I hope this review will help you in your future games, TiredOfTheWar

abandons e4 for no compensation. At this point we were making some rather rapid opening moves, and I think that Bb2, leaving e4 hanging was just an oversight due to being caught in a rhythm. A rather strange move that brings out the Queen a little early perhaps. While it attacks the knight, it really just pushes the knight back onto a square where he is happy. Usually when I see this move (Qf3) , I anticipate white trying to sling in with the classic Bc4 and attack f7. There is no basis for this attack here. Especially since the e pawn is still at home, and e6 can be played at any point to stop that tactic. The play here is to just bring the knight back and continue with natural development.

white resigns. game could have followed like this. End thoughts: I thought I formulated a solid plan early on, and played actively toward it through the whole game. I missed several tactics that could have made the game easier, but on the whole, I felt I played a solid game. The pawn majority turned out to be very powerful, rolling over white in the end. All started by an innocuous mismove early on, hanging a critical central pawn
Past master games continued here 7. cxd5 or 7. dxc5. The pawn structure after these exchanges will dictate both the following middlegame play and endgame play.
Focus on d4 was better, e.g., 7... cxd4, 8... Nc6. Now the danger - and opportunity - for Black would be to end up with pawns on c5, d5, without supporting pawns on b- and e-files.
A rook lift with tempo. I think that I have an advantage here. DC: The pawn structure has turned out symmetrical.

If I can figure out a way to get black's bishop on e7 to move, I can play Rh4, threatening mate. DC: Stepping out of the pin on N/f3 by Q/h5. Prevents Black from completing development by the natural .Nc6. White needs to develop the bishop, then decide where to attack, and hence where to place the rooks. Black needs to find a home for the knight.
Black has good piece coordination and lots of time to handle the connected passed pawns after 17. Qxa7 Nc6 18. Qxb6 Nxd4.

A thoughtless move, seemingly with no plan behind it. First, the pawn was already defended indirectly by .. Nc6 with double attack on Q/a7+R/d4. Second, the b-pawn becomes backward. Third, each pawn move means one less tempo is available in the endgame.
Now was the moment to launch your attack with 18. Rg4, aiming R/g4+B/c3 at P/g7 to provoke weaknesses in the enemy camp.

White still has an advantage because of White's nice pawn structure with only 2 islands compared to Black's scattered pawns with 3 islands - they are more work to defend. 26. 29... Be7 drives the rook away from its protection of the knight, and so wins the exchange.

We are now in an endgame. Perhaps the weakest part of my game. DC: There's no use coming out of the middlegame ahead by a pawn, if you can't convert it into a queen with which to give checkmate. So, everyone has to study the endgame sooner or later. I recommend 'Practical Rook Endings' by Edmar Mednis. It's short, cheap, well-written, and he focusses on what is most important and on what is most likely to occur in tournament play. Back to the game. This is an interesting position which both players must evaluate, and then form their plans. Black's winning chances are with the two queenside pawns. Black can try to win P/a2 to gain 2 connected passed pawns; or rapidly push them and exchange one of them for P/a2 to create a passed pawn. White's winning chances are with the potential passed P/e3. White needs to win isolated and weak P/d5 to make P/e3 a supported passed pawn. Next we consider the rooks and kings. Both players must strive to keep these pieces active: rooks behind passed pawns, kings heading for the action and attacking pawns.

Falling into a passive defensive posture, but it can keep an eye on both queenside and centre pawns. White's king must move to the second rank to avoid being trapped on the back rank; and head for d4 to drive away the rook from its protection of d5.

The more I look at this, the more I think that the rook was well placed where it was. It's preventing the black king from advancing to the 6th rank, he can't advance the pawn without at least a trade happening. DC: Both rooks are ideally placed: White's keeps Black's king out and harasses P/b5 and P/d5 from behind; Black's harasses P/a3 and the kingside pawns from the side, while keeping White's king tied down to the defence of the pawns on the second rank. Notice that Black's king is also in its ideal spot: from f7, it can move to e6 to defend P/d5, or it can move to g8 to defend P/h7. But with both Black's rook and king ideally placed, now is a good time for White to use one of the extra tempos saved up, push a pawn, and make Black give up the ideal place of either the king or the rook.
DC: ? There was no need to give up the ideal placement of the rook attacking P/b5 from behind.
Now the rook is out of play. 39. Rb6 would keep the king out, and keep White's rook active.
I think that this was my critical mistake. The moment I gave up protecting the f-pawn, I gave the black rook access to my king. DC: ? 40. Ra6+ to activate the rook is the only way to have a chance.
Throwing away an easy win by 40... Kd6, heading for c5 and protection of P/b5.
The final mistake. Either 42. Kf3 earlier or now 43. Ra6+ followed by Kf3 would keep all your chances.
Everything is in Black's favour: 2 passed pawns vs. one potential passed pawn for White; active Black king and rook vs. passive White king and tied-down rook.
Bet ter to use the active rook, or try to create a passed pawn with 50. h3.

As you appear to have been aware of the wobbly centre, you should have played Ne2, instead of Nf3, thus offering ample chances for the opponent to undermine it by eventually pinning the knight on f3. Ne2! would have avoided this issue.

It appears that I forget about Be3, which defends the center as well. I thought this would suffice, pinning his knight, and if he castles, capture it to remove an attacker of the center and double up his pawns. wolfv: Actually you have just deployed your units wrongly and not very economically. Don't forget that you have already made a move with this bishop! Why move it again while in the opening stage, and with other possibilities at your disposal?

Ugh... uncomfortable, because now a defender of my center is unusable, and if he captures, I can recapture with the queen (drawing away another defender) or with the pawn, which means my king doesn't look very safe. I did not know how to defend against that predicament, and tried... wolfv: There it is! The price for not playing Ne2 has to be paid, sooner or later. Now you are pinned and the opponent has a firm control of the black g7-a1 diagonal and is exerting pressure on the d4 square (pawn).
It becomes quite obvious at this point why Nf3 was a bad move. The pressure on f3 leads to your being passive and defensive.

He is up a I didn't find a good way to win it back, but I saw that perhaps a kingside attack could work because his dark squares are weak and the defenders seem sparse. Based on this, I decide against trading queens. wolfv: Your decision was good. At this point you should definitely avoid the queen exchange and try to profit by exploiting the black squares.
You could have tried Re1, attacking the e7 pawn and activating your rook along the open e-file.
I thought Qe5 looked a bit too obvious and lets him get out with ... Qf6. If I trade queens I can no longer attack and he may win with his extra pawn.

Unfortunately, I was not prepared for this move, which stops my queen from operating along the diagonal. I decide to try a different plan (In retrospect, now that I'm looking at this game, I see Qh4, and it looks like that would let me regain the pawn...)
I believe that d5-d6! was much better because that way you would have activated all your pieces, possibly creating some counter-attacking chances.
Why not Rc7 now?

Well, now I'm down 2 pawns and if I don't figure out a way to get that attack through, his passed pawn will win the game for him. Unfortunately, now that his queen is here to defend, my chances don't look too good. Perhaps it would have been better if I had seen Qh4 while at the board.

Under time pressure, I drop a rook and resign. After the game, my opponent was kind enough to show me a few things about the Gruenfeld (though I still don't fully understand it), and to note that instead of Bxe7, Rxe7 was ok. I'm not so pleased at how he was able to destroy my center completely, and I can't help but feel that I let a good opportunity go away, what with the mating chances against his king.

Weird at this stage, but many transpositions are possible *death - This isn't a bad move here - it hints at attempting to exchange the dark-bound bishops, which in theory favors white in Stonewall structures, though in many specific positions in which black hasn't yet committed to ...d5, such an exchange may tend to weaken white on the dark squares. 6.c4 is much more popular, of course.

Play active *death - This is a fairly good choice. Since white isn't claiming space very aggressively, the opening will be a battle for control of central squares and lines. Both sides can construct fairly sound positions, and the interesting interactions in the center will determine the character of the struggle. Another useful idea in reaction to b3 for white is to push the black a-pawn, even as early as the sixth move. By aiming for ...a5-a4, black will develop the a-rook on its original file, and create some weaknesses on the white queenside.
death - This position has certainly been seen before.

I didn't see this move. MH: Who is better and why? Material is even and pawn d6 holds back two of White's pawns, so you might say Black is better in a pawn ending. But, with rooks and/or queens it's more complex. I think you consistently tried to generate king-side activity throughout the game, but that this is a very real turning point where your whole modus operandi came to an end and you didn't know how to handle this next phase.
This is a tough ending for Black. White's rook is already more active (if Rb7 moves off the rank, then Rf7+ wins a pawn) and White's pawns are scattered in such a way as to be hard to attack.

I played very badly in the endgame. This is the end... MH: You were being true to your game strategy (such as I could discern) of playing actively on the king-side. You played too quickly for ...Nf4 and it might've cost you dearly. Your king was weakened earlier and it cost you later. You tried to attack when there was none (...Qh4). You attacked when you could (...f3) and it worked fairly well. You might have missed one or two chances to attack, but you were trying. You need to build up to your offensive more patiently and soundly, so I'd recommend you review some games from a database or off the Internet to see some plans of how that might be done. Look for games where Black wins with king-side play to get some examples and to see how he creates play even when White doesn't cooperate much. This endgame required it's own analysis and plan, so I'd recommend you clarify in your own mind exactly where the middle-game ends and the endgame begins and at that moment begin to execute an endgame strategy to win and promote pawns to make more material. This will often lead to pawn grabbing and king activity, but there will be much less (almost non-existent) chance for an attack on the enemy king -- until you get more queens and renew the attack in earnest.
3.d4 is most often played. 3.Bc4 is also popular.)

This is a waste of time. Since he has played ...d6, it's obvious that the Bishop can only be developed on e7. So why not put it there now ...a developing move rather than a weakening pawn move? If 4 ...Be7 5. Ng5?! (5. d4!) 0-0 and f7 is protected. White should not give up the B and N for a Rook and the f7 pawn ... that is a bad exchange. Then, if Black wants to drive away the N with h6, he does not lose a tempo, because the N uses a tempo in retreating. With 4 ...h6, Black has wasted a move.)
5.0-0 is also good, of course, but this is the sharpest move.)

It's worth looking at this position. White is better. Why? He has a little more space thanks to his e4 pawn and Black has no pawn beyond his third rank. White has three minor pieces in play, Black has two. White can complete his development in 3 moves ...1 Q move, 1 Bc1 move, Castles. The Rooks are then connected. Some would say 5 moves, because development is not achieved until the Rooks move, say to d1 and e1. It will take Black 4 moves to connect the Rooks. That is why 4...h6 is doubtful. It did nothing to help development. Black is a move behind anyway, so he can't afford to waste a move like that. So, White is better because of a space advantage and a lead in development.

I believe that White should play a developing move here. 7. Bf4 or 7.Qd3 both look good and 7. 0-0 is worth considering as well. 7.Nf5 is less good, I think, because it allows Black to catch up in development. The N has just moved for the third time and when he goes off the board his tempi go too. The Bishop which goes off has moved only once. It's true that White has the 2 Bishops in an open position ... a definite advantage, but it's also true that he gets a potentially weak pawn on f5. Also, he has no pawns on the d or e files and cannot quickly challenge the black pawn which will arrive on d5.)

t looked like everything was running rather smoothly so far. I have forced the small advantage of having a bishop over a knight. In the next few moves I somehow manage to get into trouble, but I can't really pinpoint how, I just started to feel like he had lots of pressure. (Ptarmigan: I think it is because Black catches up on development and has a good control of the centre with pawns on c6 and d5. Also, he has no weaknesses.) Everything was centered around his pressure on my f2 pawn. (Ptarmigan: It will take both sides 2 moves to complete development, or at least to connect Rooks. In other words, Black has caught up, and this was because of the N move to f5. The game is equal now. )

Good move, because when he plays ...d5, gaining space, White will need to move the Bishop, so Black gains a tempo. Also, because he has a dark-squared Bishop, it will help Black to have his pawns on light squares.)

Now we see that the absence of the White e4 pawn has driven the B from its excellent c4 square to d3, where it is doing nothing very much and is blocked by the f5 pawn (which used to be the e4 pawn :). Black has a very comfortable game.)
11 ...Bd6 is good.)

I guess this is probably were trouble started for me. Good thing that after a while of pressure he gives up his advantage by blocking his own attack with one of his pawns. (Ptarmigan: I would prefer 13.Qf3 here so that a future Ne2 would not block the Q.)
He starts to build up against f2. (Ptarmigan: 13 ...Bc5 is at least as good.)

I considered Bh4 now. I didn't see that if he played g5 I could capture en-passant. I noticed it probably on the next move. (Ptarmigan: I agree with you. 16. Bh4 is good, but it is no better than your move. Black has an edge after either move. 16 ...g5? after 16. Bh4 is a horrible mistake. 16. Bh4 g5?? (16...Ne5) 17. fg6 fg6 18. Bg6 Re5 19.Bh5 Rh5 and White is winning.)
Is this a mistake or a good indirect defense of the f2 pawn? (Ptarmigan: Not a mistake)
This is were he passes over the ball to me. I think I made pretty good use of it too!
I don't understand this move. What does it do? 21 ...Rxe1+! 22.Rxe1 Qb4 or 21 . ..Qb4 are more to the point.)

Is this too soon? The problem is the lost tempo when the knight attacks the Queen. (Ptarmigan: It's not too soon. I like it. Notice that Black's 4...h6?! makes this better than it would have been with the pawn on h7. We should always have a very good reason for advancing pawns in front of the K's home. You are right to think about the lost tempo, but in this case it doesn't count because the Q can go to a better square than f4.)
Driving the Q to a better square and removing a key defender from the K side. Better to swap the pawns immediately.)
23.Qh4 is better. Black can't stop the exchange of the h6 and g5 pawns. Then White will have his N on g5 and Q on h4, with pressure on h7 and f7.)

I would definitely take with the N. Being a short-range piece, the N needs to be in an advanced position. h3 is a bad square for him, now that he is not needed to protect f2. Black would be crazy to drive him away with ...f6, creating strong squares for White at e6 and g6. g5 is a great square for the N, hitting f7 and h7.)

I somehow played inaccuratly and didn't get a clear attack. Mostly because my timing was of and he has now blocked the f pawn. I decide to get the knight up, maybe to h5. (Ptarmigan: I think that Black is clearly better here (not necessarily winning), because of his conrol of the 'e' file, especially his grip on e1. So, I don't see the justification for White thinking he should have an attack. He can and should look for counterplay, of course. A good start would be to decide on the best squares for the pieces. The B is excellently placed on c4. The R is guarding the back rank. Maybe it can go to d1 at some point. I would start by moving the Q, to h4 or f4, allowing the N (the worst-placed piece) to go to g5.)

But I see right now that on the previous move a sacrifice of the bishop could've been interesting. At first it was thought of as a skewer of the king to the rook by my queen, but now I see there are many complications. I decided to play it now since it seems to be what needs to be done, and maybe I can find out the best moves as I go on. (Ptarmigan: 28 ...Ne4?? is a blunder which loses immediately. Black had two moves which keep the advantage. 28 ...Qc7 and 28 ...Bc3)
The winning move is 29. Qh5!. There is no answer to the attack on f7.)
Much better than taking with the Q.)
A losing move. 33...Qc5=)
This wins. So does 35.Rf3+.)

This is were I lost the game. The problem is I have very little time left and I really cant figure out how to continue on such a short time limit. After this point my moves aren't subject to alot of thought. The rest of the game is a meaningless attempt to play fast so as to avoid losing on time, I probably have less then a minute left on my clock at this point. (Ptarmigan: This is Black's best, but it loses. This position is totally won for White. White plays the best move here.)
for a second I thought I could play Qf7.

yerbamate resigns Conclusions This was a good game, well played, though obviously not faultlessly, by both players. White got an advantage in the opening, but this largely disappeared after 7. Nf5. Black's easy development and control of the centre, and later his control of the 'e' file, gave him an edge. The game changed dramatically after 28 ... Ne4??, which gave White a straightforward win, which unfortunately he missed. White made some excellent moves after this but he lost in time trouble, which happens to everybody from time to time.

At last I felt confident enough to play the sicilian defense and he, of course, never having studied it, throws me out of book. So I kept calm and studied how his choice of move gave me an edge here. Your cousin's move is the start of a well known Sicilian variation, named "the closed sicilian". This is my favourite variation when I rarely play against the sicilian (I am a 1.d4 fan!). Play is not that violent as in open variations. White develops calmly, g3 and Bg2, sometimes the f pawn is pushed in f4 followed by Nf3, aiming for a delayed or totally absent push in d4. It worths a check in
Stoppping 3. e5 You could have done it by playing Nc6, did you see?

And here I was happy to see the move. I knew that this pawn push was late because I still have my king pawn to advance. Late but perfectly playable here. It is only a delay, but the position now is totally theoretical

At this moment I wished for him to trade knights since that would increase my central control and facilitate .. .d5 later on in the game. But my cousin also so that and chose to leave the center to me. I do not like the e5 push here because it leaves the d5 square in White's hands. What it means? The d6 pawn now is unprotected by pawns (and it won't be forever), is a clear target in an open file, a target for white rooks. Your cousin correctly didn't trade Knights because doing that would have significantly improved your pawn structure in the center. Nb3 is also playable here, and pherhaps slightly better because avoids the annoying pin ing4

Thus far I felt happy with my position. My opening choice did give me an edge over my opponent. Stil, I was already expecting one of the two white bishops to come out to the 5th. rank, just as it did. Pardon me, I do not agree with your optimistic evaluation. In this position White hasn't any weakness, Black does: the d6 pawn and the d5 square. White should have continued with Bg5, pinning the Knight, and after Be7 should have traded it with Bxf6, getting rid of the main d5 guardian. Now the c3 Knight has a wonderful outpost. No matter if Be6 threatens to trade it off: after any simplification of the position, the d6 weakness becomes more and moreimportant in the endgame.

I decided to trade off that bishop. The game would later open up with ...d5 and I wanted to have the two bishop advantage. I was thinking about 9. Bb3 Na5 and the bishop must fall. I didn't like the look of 10. Bd5 Nxd5 11. Nd5! But I still had my other knight to trade, say 11...Nc4 followed by 12...Nb6. Now that I review the game I think this plan is just wrong. That knight must never be allowed into the d5 outpost. The best try to keep the Knight away from d5 was to avoid the e5 push :-) Your d5 weaknes is what the classical books identify as a "permanent weakness". Sooner or later White will take advantage on it.

Bad move. That bishop is zeroing in to the weak f7 pawn. This is the result of my last two pawn moves, trying to capture it. This move just locks my bishop out of the defense of the weak f7 pawn. During the game I saw this move as a preparation for Na5, further controlling the d5 square. So after 10...Na5 11. Bd5 Nxd5 12. Nxd5! Nc4 followed by Nb6. I was just so absort in getting rid of this bishop, that I didn't see the obvious. there's no need of any comment. You said all what was necessary to say about this move. I just add my two cents: assuming that the normal move would have been Be7, meeting Ng5 with a kingside castle, an interesting plan would have been Be6, trying to challenge White about the d5 control. No matter if White trades Bishops: the e6 pawn becomes the d6's best friend :-) (prepares the d5 push). Have a look to the following sample variations:

A strong move. Still, I desdained it. I just saw a simple knight fork on f7. Nevermind the bishop, it's dead (so I thought). So I defended f7 (or so I thought). Hard to keep calm after such a blunder! I perfectly understand you. Whenever I blunder I hardly find a way to complicate tasks for my opponent! Easier to find the way when relaxed, with a cup of coffee and a snack, in front of PC/chessboard. However, Qd7 defends nothing, as you correctly pointed out. Have a look to my variation. The d5 push would have brought the game to a very complex fight. I'm not sure everything is correct in my variation, but it is only an idea about how to behave in desperate positions. Normally there are two ways: 1-passive play, hope of an opponent's blunder (=myracle) 2-further sacs, aiming for complication. In both cases there are some practical chances of success. Definitely in case 2 games are more brilliant (and short :-).

And here it dawned on me. I'm only a pawn down in material. But what a bad position this is, that bishop cut in like a samurai sword. And where is my light squared bishop!? Sitting comfortably in b7 doing nothing. I might as well have resigned here. there's no hurry to resign, never :-)
Another blow. Just look at what that knight in g5 enables white to do.
Black is just falling apart
That pawn there is like rock.

And here I even thought that I would get out of the mess. I saw 15...Nxe6 16. Nxe6 Qxc2 followed by 17... Qc4 going for that monstruous d5 pawn. But as usual, I was only seeing what I wanted to see, for white had an ultra powerful in-between move.
The knight deals its final blow

And my light squared bishop is still happily sitting on b7. this short game has two very important lessons: 1) do not weaken your position with moves like e5 2) do your best to complicate tasks when you're down. There's a third lesson (do your best when calculating variations) but I admit to myself that is difficult to keep objective after a blunder. Hope you like my notes, See you on FICS.

I enjoy pl aying f4 in these positions, although I don't really know if it's a smart move or not? Killerman: This move is fine and we have reached a fairly typical Vienna Opening position, an opening that is often described as a delayed King's Gambit. As with a lot of the old gambits they are played infrequently at GM level but they are still good weapons for club players.

This is tempting as it looks like a good idea to block in the Black bishop and start an attack. However you have committed yourself a little early in my opinion. I prefer lines following Nf3 which retain the tension in the centre a little longer and allow you more flexibility. You may end up playing f5 for your attack later which is fine, but by delaying it you allow yourself to see how Black intends to set up his position before thrusting forward. In addition completing your development first will always allow you to carry out a better attack.
Risky as it weakens key squares on the kingside. Better would have been an attempt to swop off your light squared bishop with Na5

This might be exaggerating just a little bit, I could have played Bg5 already at this point I guess. Killerman: Yes, this move is tempting but is played too soon. Development is important so Bg5 is probably a good idea, however what will happen after Black plays h6? The alternative is to capture on g6 which will leave Black with weakened kingside squares
Na5 may also be possible getting rid of the c4 bishop
Did Black mean this? If so it's a great attacking attempt. After the more obvious Bb4 White still seems to retain an edge but it's far from clear.
Black decides to sack the queen, apparently for two pieces...Killerman: Black has no option but to accept this situation here
Correct. Black has to find the best moves now and hope for a mistake
Eager to spare my rook after 12. h3 g2 13. Rh2 Nf1, allthough h3 would have covered the g4 square.

Now of course the black Bishop enters the attack, but I really don't see how to wiggle my way out of this position? Killerman: The game was probably lost after 12 . h4 but now it's all over. Of course you can't stop the bishop entering the game but there is no need to open lines to your king as well. fxg6 just helps Black. You need to keep Black out of d4 so c3 is the best but you do now have a position that verges on Zugzwang and as such you have to sit and wait for the attack
It's too late for this move. Nf3 is probably best but the game has gone.

White checkmated That really hurt :) Killerman: A very exciting game and a great attack from Black. The game shows how difficult defending can be against a group of minor pieces on good squares. Keep playing the opening though as you are always going to get interesting games in these sort of lines. Just don't overplay the pawn moves. In the end your lack of development was the key to Black's success. Thanks for allowing me to review your game.
this is very quiet, it is probably now time for black to seize the centre with ...c5 or ...e5
Is castling here right away good? RT: well, you don't seem to be doing anything active, so there's nothing wrong with castling.
finally!

I went rook to b1 because of tactical reasons of the bishop on g7. RT: if you are planning b3, this may be necessary, but personally I would really rather make something happen in this position: for example, 8. c4 would be logical.
10. c4 would still make sense, putting pressure on Black's centre and possibly freeing c4 and e4 for your knight, or blocking the g7-bishop's diagonal.

Black's planning to go to Bh3 to try and trade off my white's square bishop so he can gain control or/and occupy the weak white squares in my kingside. I'm not sure if moving my rook to e1 followed by bishop h1 would be ok, in order to keep the white square bishop. I think keeping the bishop would be good for me since f3, g2, and h3, have been potentially weaken. Since the bishop on g2 is the main defender of the kingside, maybe keeping the bishop would be a good idea? RT: Re1 would be one plan.After the plan you chose, however, your light-squared bishop is much less useful since it is blocked by your e4-pawn, so you don't need it as much.

I'm cramped so I decided to challenge my opponent's space advantage in the center. RT: I would have played this 10 moves earlier. You are White, so the space advantage is something you could have had but gifted to Black.
I went a3 because c2 could be a potential target for black's knight on c6. RT: You don't need to worry about c2 as long as it is defended - if Black plays ...Nb4 you will have a3 with tempo.

Black is doing a good thing of exchanging the main defender of my king side. because once the bishops are exchanged, black's pieces may suddenly have access to h3, g2, and f3. RT: don't worry about this too much either -- the only Black piece that can get to these light squares is the queen.
I went back to Bc1 because it was a bad bishop. Bishops must have open diagonals to be effective. RT: Good idea, supports your natural break in this position which is f4.

I think this move is essential in order to keep the knight out of e3. Knights like strong secure strong points. RT: You are concentrating too much on prophylactic play, instead of backing up your ideas with analysis. Here you should analyse what happens after you play f4 and Black tries to occupy e3:
I'm not sure why my opponent played that.
since the center is closed, I must attack on the wing.
This moved suprised me. I'm not really sure why he moved there. RT: I expect Black is trying to use the d5-square.

Now I have a protected passed pawn. If I can get in an end game, would I have the advantage because of the protected passed pawn? RT: That depends on the type of ending. Let's try a thought experiment: Suppose all the pieces except for kings and pawns are removed, and that the queenside becomes blocked with pawns on a4/a5, b3/b4, c2/c5, d3/d4. Then Black can play Kf7 and keep White out forever, meeting h4 with ...h5 if necessary. On the other hand, this is the simplest possible endgame -- if you keep other pieces on, or work something out on the Queenside you should expect the e5-pawn to be to your advantage.

I'm trying to undermine the center by trying to get him to take on b4, so I can get the central pawn on d4. I know this thinking is faulty because I can't make him try to take the pawn on b4. RT: Even thoiugh Black does not have to take on b4, you will retain the option of exchanging on c5 and playing Nf3-d2-c4(-d6 -- another advantage of the e5-pawn), or of ganging up on the weak c5-pawn. So this is not a bad move.
you don't need to do this immediately though.

I'm trying to make my bishop good by trying to make pawn exchanges. Yes, I'm aware that I made a pawn weakness on c3. but, I can easily get rid of it with my 2 knights and queen. RT: I don't think this is the right way to play, although I don't see how else to develop your bishop.
That move surprised me. he's putting pressure on the pawn on f4. RT: it shouldn't surprise you -- this is why Black played ..f5 6 moves ago.

I think this move is a bit bad. It's a defensive move. The queen is not a great defender because it's always vulnerable to being captured. I should try and use the queen for attack. The queen is better for offense than defense. Counter attacking is the best defense. Can I counter attack instead of going to queen to d2? RT: You may not like to play this, but I don't see that you have much choice since your B, P and e3-square are all attacked there is no good way to counter attack. Grit your teeth and play it.
This move is good. It gets rid of my pawn weakness. RT: True.
Threatening to win a knight. RT: both you and your opponent may have missed that 28...Kh7! works, e.g. 29. Rxb8? Nxf4+ 30. Nxf4 Nxf4+ 31. Kg3 Nh5+ 31. Kg2 Rxb8
Threatening to win a bishop.
I think this move is bad. It lets the black queen put pressure on f4. Because of that, the black queen is another piece in the attack RT: I agree. Now Black breaks in.
Now my king is exposed. There are few pawns and pieces to defend my king.
34...Nf4+! is a killer.
Threatening mate of queen to h8
I think this move is losing. By trading pieces in my attack, it will get rid of my attack. RT: I think you are lost whatever you do.
I did not see this move.
I need some counterplay.
I trying to get some perpectual checking or something. RT: a little analysis should convince you that this is useless, the game is over.

In my opinion you displayed in your notes excellent knowledge of the principles of positional play. However I felt you were unwilling or unable to analyse some of the tactical continuations, and in the end you fell victim to attacking tactics based on a positional invasion. Furthermore, you were not willing to seize the initiative in the opening, to play actively enough. I think you have probably read too many books for the time being, and you need to practice more, and to practice playing more aggressively, so you can use what you have learned. Feel free to talk to me about this game or anything else, particularly if you feel I made some mistakes. Good luck in your future games!
I always answer 1. ... e5 and search for a Ruy Lpez. I think this is good for a beginner.
Ruy Lpez. I ignore the variation's names

Ruy Lopez main line plays 3... Nf6 first. In some variants the white bishop on b3 causes some trouble due to his attack on f7, especially before black has castled. Therefore it might be better to play Nf6, Be7 (or Bc5) and O-O first. But b5 is of course not a mistake.
I've seen that these pawn moves were played in GM games. I don't know if they are the best.

My idea was to threaten e4 and try to control the center JK: The problem is that after 5. O-O you cannot keep the pawn you take on e4 because after 5. O-O Nxe4 6. Re1 your pawn e5 is lost, and the unprotected king is in the e file - and the white bishop aims on the king's wing as well. An extra pawn does not always make up an unprotected king in the centre. As a rule of thumb, a beginner should watch out for a quick castle.
White doesn't seem to be afraid of Cxe4. Theory says that this move is bad because of d4 and Rb1. JK: Alright, but because of d4 and Re1.

Protecting Cf6 and preparing to castle. Correct? JK: Preparing to castle - correct. Nf6 does not need to be protected. More important, Be7 closes the e file, Re1 does not directly threaten the king; thus, Nxe4 would be possible.
Protects e4 and places a Rook in the center
I always castle as soon as possible.
Prepares d4 and prevents a Knight-Bishop exchange.
Too late for an exchange. JK: Yes, but you force the bishop out of the black king's diagonal.
Connects the rooks and Queen.
Searching for a central placed knight but wrong. White will win a pawn. JK: I do not see how white can force to win a pawn here. I have no problem with Nc4.
Okay, now pawn b5 cannot be protected anymore.
From now on, the game is lost for black. JK: Not really - it's just a pawn. Your position is not nice, but in a beginner's game there still should be many chances.
Now imagine your position with your knight still on f6 and Qa8 and Bb7. Quite some nice pressure in the centre, right?
The queen is not placed well on b5; thus, there's no need to expel it from there. And your Ba8 is closed in by c6.
Threatens e5 and checkmate or another pawn lost for black. White central pawns advance and I don't see how to stop it.
Demoralized JK: Okay, this move doesn't make any sense. Why not g6, attacking the queen and closing the diagonal towards h7? After that, white cannot advance the pawns.
Black's position collapses JK: This also wouldn't have been possible after 19... g6.
Defending by piece exchange. But there are too many threats.
forced JK: You could have removed your queen as well, but f6 is of course a possibility.
Still g6 is a possibility. Now the black bishop gets into a diagonal towards your king.
Setting up a trap for a back rank mate. My only idea. JK: That's a little obvious. I probably would have played 23... Ne5, blocking the pawn e5. After 24. f4 Ng6 the pawn h7 is covered.
White makes no mistakes.

In time trouble and lost JK: Now Ne5 doesn't block anything, for white can capture on d5. You cannot prevent that white opens e file and the long diagonal; for that, d5 was a bad mistake. Maybe still 24... g6 is worth a try, but everything doesn't look good anymore.
Instead, 26... Rxe2 could have brought some relief. This allows your king to escape into the e file.
This checkmate is a textbook expample. Now all moves are forced.
What about Kf8? After this move all is lost, even 28. Rxe8+ Qxe8 29. Qxe8+ is possible.
Taking the queen is no temptation for white
Black checkmated JK: Your opponent did extraordinary well, so don't panic.
A more logical move would be 3. d4 to occupy the center.
Here 5. d4 would be stronger. Black could now gain space with 5 ... d4.
Losing a piece after 6. . .. d4. The pawn attacks two pieces and you can save only one.
This time you were lucky.
Have you seen the black threat? If Black would now play 7. ... d4, you can take the pawn, because your queen give the black king check.
You have to defend against d4 again. a3 (with counter attack) or d4 (preventing the doppel attack mechanically) are the best moves for white.
Interesting case of mutually chess blindness.
Finally you make the best move! Black is still better. He can now destroy the pawn chain in front of the white king withBxc3

You have to defend against Bxc3. The natural looking 10. Qd2 is bad, after Ne4. Maybe the best try is Na4. Well, of course the knight is usally bad placed at the rim, but here it is the only move which prevents Bxc3. As you maybe know in the sicilian english attack, the knight is often placed at a4 defending the queenside.

Was this a good move? it turned out to be a wrong move. Pitigrilli: I dont like this move for strategical reasons. In positions with castling on different sides, white will attack on the kingside and black on the queenside. A pawn storm will often be the start of the attack. The goal of both players is opening lines for the attack against the enemy king. So first, the attack against the pawn on b7 is senseless. You cant take this pawn, because it would open a line against your king. Even worse the Queen on b5 is the target of attacks from the black pawns, making progress while you have to move with your Queen.
Bxc3 is the logical move.
Yippieh, you are back in the game. Black blundered a piece.
Ok, you are a bishop up. Now try to exchange more pieces to reach the ending. First try to prevent the opening of lines on the Queenside. The treat is pawn to a5 opening the a-line. So play Qa5.
Second chance to play Qa5.
This breaks the connection of your rooks. Try to utilize the open g-file with Rhg1.
What should I have done in this situation? Pitigrilli: First dont loose a piece. Qb3 and bxa5 holding your material advantage (the positional advantage is at black side: attacking chance).
Time to resign.
I did a bad move, and I resigned. The position was hopeless anyway.

1. In the opening you should try to occupy the centre. When your opponent plays some of the semi clodes openings like 1. e4 Nc6 then push your second pawn to d4. 2. Always look for the posibility of double attacks (pawn fork, knight fork). There are a lot of books with tactical exercise, like win a piece in one move. 3. In positions with castleing on opposite sites, dont move your pieces in front of the enemy pawns. They will move forward pushing your pieces back and making progress for the attack at your king. (this rule is going back to Steinitz)

Not being really at home with the Q-indian defenses-I'm winging it. (Your comment here is quite valuable, because your honesty helps address an very important need - an answer to white's QP opening.) In retrospect d5 would be better as it puts me on more familiar ground (Unless you are purposely experimenting with a new opening/ defense/variation, yes, stick with what you know.)
from The book, as I recall

d4 is, in my opinion, the best point to put pressure on (I am not sure if you meant d4 or d5 here. Since white covers d4 with the N, c-pawn, and e-pawn, let's go with d5. More thought should be given to b6 followed by Bb7 for black. White wants to play an eventual e4, so black will be in position to contest those white squares.) - There'se also Ne5, though Bxe5 dxe5 is not an ideal variation. (I was not sure if you were referring to Ne5 by white or Ne4 for black. Black was not in a position for Bxe5.) Also, A solitary d5 is something I need to watch out for. (An isolated queen pawn - IQP - is neither bad nor good in itself. Many club players fear being on the receiving side of the IQP, but with practice and some theory behind it, one can see that both sides are playable.)

More pressure on d4. I think e7 might be better, though my intention at the time was to fianchetto the Bishop-which I'll do next (I think in many positions, the location of the queen is among the last to be decided - GM Nunn alludes to this in his older book on the Benoni. The d4 square cannot really be pressured, so Qc7, Bd6 seems more consistent to fight for e5 square. Also, the black queen may get in the way of a possible black queen side expansion.)
The fianchetto (This was the first serious positional error by black. The weakness on the black squares may become quite serious, especially with the eventual e3-e4 by white.)

I thought long and hard about c4 at the time, though As I write this, it seems better: Qe2 is a bad move for white (If black wants to play c4, he should be in a position to follow it up by b7-b5, a7-a5, and with precautions, b4. Hence, the Qb6 slows that down. White's play will then be in the center and on the K-side. White's Qe2 is not at all bad, and fits in well with his plans of e4.)
White often plays dc5 in this system prior to playing e4, so as to avoid IQP.)
yup, I was right, c4 would've been better (I feel Nb3, a one-move atatck on the black queen, is inferior to e4.)
I feel Qc7 is better, allowing the black rook to contest eventual e-file with Re8.)

Don't get this one: White seems bent on making it easy for me (This comment puzzles me. e4 for white is an essential step, and helps highlight the weak black squares. The only drawback is after 11...de4 12.Be4, Ne4 white misses the two bishops. This shows why I prefer having the white QN on d2 torecapture on e4.)
Black must reckon with 12.e5, Nfd7 13.Re1.)
I would no t give up the dark sqaure bishop so readily. This helps eliminate the weaknesses aound the dark squares on black's K-side.)

Forcing his Knight to flee. Bracco: Didn't you see 4.dxe5(!)? It looks better than closing the position, bacause of 4...dxe5 (or Nxe5, 5. Nxe5 dxe5 6. Qxd8) 5. Qxd8 Kxd8 and Black at least lost castling, not to mention that he can loose a pawn if takes back the Queen with the Knight

My usual move would be Be2. But in this case, I decided to have a queenside pawn storm. Bracco: Strategically correct decision. White must play on the Queenside because of his choice to advance the "d" pawn at move 4. Nimzowitsch teaches that one must play in the direction showed by his most advanced pawn in a chain

He/She, on the other hand, is going for kingside pawn storm. Bracco: Black plays also the very correct plan. In this position the "F" pawn advance looks stronger than White's "C" because is faster and because White cannot enforce his central "e4" pawn with f3. Black can complete development and increase his pressure in e4-d5 in several ways. For example: 6. Nc3 Nf6 7.Bd3 g6 followed by Bg7, O-O and c6!, challenging white in the center. This game looks like a King Indian with a big improvement for Black: the f5 push has been played before Nf6.

To protect my e4 pawn. Should I have taken the f5 pawn? But that would have left me with holes in my pawn structure. Bracco: I would have preferred Nc3, because in case of Black's change in e4, a Knight is stronger than a Bishop in the square "e4". I don't think that White's capture in f5 is a good idea, for the simple reason that Black develops his light-squared Bishop for free!
He's closing my Kingside Bracco: Black has just played a serious mistake. There's no reason to close immediately the center. To increase the central pressure with Nf6 was the correct choice

Stupid move to castle on the kingside since he/she has already made a kingside pawn storm. Bracco: You are right! Playing this move justifies the Black advance in f4! There was no hurry to castle any side. You should complete development before take such an important decision! In this position castling is a delicate matter on both sides: on the Quenside you are already storming and thus weakening your pawn structure, on the Kingside you are under the fire of a pawn storm. Nc3 was once more the correct move.

Hoping to create some counterplay on the queen side since my kingside is blocked. Bracco: The center is blocked, and both sides has to create some threats. As mentioned before, White must play on the Quuenside, but the development has still to be completed! Nc3 becomes urgent.

This is just in case if the c6 pawn advances to c5 Bracco: A waste of time. Why Black should play c5 wasting two moves? And in case Black was a little bit silly, why White must defend his b4 pawn? Had Black played c5, White had to capture with bxc5, creating a passed and defended pawn in d5! Needless to say, Nc3 was better.
Looks mysterious to me. It should be a waste of time.

This is so that I can advance my g pawn to break his pawn structure. Is this a dumb plan? Bracco: Sorry, it is. At least, is incoerent with your actions on the queenside. Opening in any way the King side makes easier the Black's task of attacking your King. Remember, any opened line towards the target is a gift for the attacker.
I had no choice but to try and advance my g and f pawns to ease the building pressure on my kingside.

Completely senseless! Why to throw away such a noisy Knight? One should sacrifices his pieces only if has chances to crush the enemy position, or at least create him some difficulties. This is not the case.
Black is ambitious, but he hasn't enough pieces after his pawns to use for the attack. g5 followed by Ng6, g4 and Qh4 seems more effective.

Trying to break the pawn chain. Bracco: The best policy when dealing with an upcoming attack is to keep the pawns on the second row as long as possible. If you push your Castling pawns, the only benefit is for Black, to put your pawns easier in touch with the black one's.
Only to create a big hole in the middle! Bracco: The only big hole you created is the "g" column opened for the Black Rook :-) Read my previous comment.

Desperate attempt to ease the building pressure on my kingside. If he/ she takes the Knight, I'll take the pawn with my Bishop Bracco: I would have preferred Bxf4, because the Bishop was still at home and because a Knight looks more powerful than a Bishop in f4 (controls g6 and e6)
The intermediate Bg4 was the correct move!
How about Qxh5 check? Black is forced to play Ng6, and now e5! is a Nightmare for him! (Kf7? e6 ch. +-)

Or would Qf1 be a better move since I would have control of the g1 square? Bracco:You are a pawn up and you are under fire, any piece trade is favorable for you Rg2! was OK, the threat now is Bxg4. trading off at least the noisy Bishop and walking toward an endgame with a pawn more! If one is defending himself from an attack, a good idea is trading off the enemy pieces. The rook in g2, once the Bishop has moved, force Black to take a decision about the "G" column: trade off the Rooks too, or release the column? In both cases White is happy!
To guard my Knight Bracco: The least you can do ! :-)
To connect the Rooks and give extra protection to the Knight

Pinning the Bishop and Knight but I never saw Qxf1# coming. Bracco: The final blunder in a winning position. After Rfc1 is hard to advice Black in any way! The threat is R1c7 checkmate. Black can avoid it only playing Ke7, But with Nb2 White is a Rook up. Kenneth, I hope these comments will be helpful for improving your play.
