Gallagher recommends Nf6, stating that if black exchanges on d4 there isn't much point to the d6 variation, because white achieves an opening plus. His example variation follows your game up to 5. Nc3, stating that white now protects his e4 pawn with the knight instead of less desirable schemes like f3 or Bd3.

Both sides are making moves to fight for the center while developing and increasing the power of their minor pieces. Black's dark bishop will take a couple of moves to get to a useful square, probably via fianchetto, but the pin on white's knight helps to partially counterbalance this.

Taking stock of all the imbalances: For minor pieces, all the pieces are exerting about the same influence (knights have control of 6 or 7, bishops have control of 4 or 5) with the exception of black's dark bishop, which only has both scope and control of 3. As a result, white is currently winning the minor piece imbalance. For pawn structure, up until now, neither side has had any potential weaknesses. Black's advance of e5 creates a potential backward pawn on d6. It's shielded (by the d4 pawn) but since the hole on d5 was black's big problem later in the game, this may not be the best move. For space (I use the Yasser Seirawan technique of "count the squares in enemy territory you control, rather than overall squares"), both sides control 1 kingside. White has one central square and 2 queenside squares (compared to black having no central squares and 1 queenside square), so white is equal or ahead in space on all sides of the board. Material is equal. For important squares/files/etc, white has more of the center, and neither side seems to be vying for control of much else (the c file is open but currently uncontested), so white is a bit ahead here. For development, black is more developed on the kingside with respect to pieces that have moved, but white's dark bishop is influencing this sector without having moved, so I would consider this imbalance fairly equalized. Black may be considered to have temporary dynamic initiative due to the threat against d4 that e5 created.

I play Black here. My provisional Standard rating going in was 1745, My opponent's was 1702. Time control was 45 5. OS : For most of the game, white was playing with most of the imbalances in his favor. Now, black has a point of extra material to play with. This comes at a structural cost in that the d6 pawn really IS backward now, since d4 is no longer a shielding pawn. Black's dark bishop is not yet solved, but he has a very nice knight on d4. The potential of this knight is dynamic rather than static, since white can exchange off for a knight or bishop quite easily. Ironically, the d4 knight is no longer actually controlling any queenside space, despite being farther advanced and being able to reach more squares in enemy territory. Both sides have about equal claim to the center at the moment, although black is making better use of it. White has a spatial edge on both kingside and queenside. Black may want to consider bringing a rook in to the fray with Rc8, partly because the d4 knight is helping to control this file, and black needs to do something to fight back against white's queenside edge while it's still small enough to contest.

White had the option of Bxf6 and then placing his knight on to d5 where it would have an essentially uncontestable outpost. However, this would also cede d4 to black's knight, so he decided to come back to e3 to exchange. White was ill advised to embark on the one plan and then change his mind in that this involved loss of tempo. Black's difficulty here is that his backward d6 pawn is now exposed on a half-open file, presenting a target to white.

My plans now involve grabbing the open c file and playing for ...d5 if I can make it practical. OS: White's knight is quite a powerful piece. If white exchanges off his dark bishop to knock black's f6 knight away (whether it's exchanged or simply moves, it loses control of d5), then he gets d5 as a post. If the f6 knight doesn't move, this post is permanent. If it does move, it will have to concede further pawn structural weaknesses later to get rid of the d5 knight, which results in more targets for white.
I prefer Bg5 immediately for white

Connects the Rooks with an attack on a2 while maintaining watch on d5. OS: I don't understand where the white knight thinks it's going. It did much more valuable duty threatening to use the d5 post after Bg5/Bxf6 or Bg5/Bxe7.

Earlier you said you wanted to fight to advance d5. This is a good plan. Your rook may be better placed on d8 rather than c8 to fight to achieve this. It's doubly important to be able to do d5 to finally give your dark bishop some scope.

He's planning to double on the d file, meaning I will have to maintain defense of the pawn where it stands in addition to any thought of playing ... d5 OS : This is also part of why he should have left his knight alone on c3, because it helps his d file control and targeting your d6. Redirecting to f5 (which is what I assume he's trying for) doesn't help this, and doesn't coordinate his pieces.

Here is where I spent a lot of time trying to get my head around the possibility of 17 ...d5. Certainly it would be attacked more times than it is defended, but I spend a long time looking for a way to take advantage of the fact that the d1 Rook must stay on the home rank or I can play ...Qe1#. In the end I decide that I can't make anything work. Used up a lot of clock doing this though and had to play the endgame like it was a blitz game, which may have contributed to my demise there. OS: Based on your d1-is-stuck observation, how about d5 followed by e4 when his pawn captures, thus sealing his queen out and allowing you to safely recapture? I looked to see if there's any way he can dangerously redirect his queen and I couldn't see any. It's possible that your e4 pawn may fall from being so far advanced, but it's an extra pawn and your dark bishop really needs to start doing something so I'd willingly give the extra material back as black, if I had to.
I'm wondering if this was wise, as it forces the Knight back to c3 where it again defends d5.

Based on your having already penetrated a rook down the c file, you may want to bring the other rook to c8. You may want to take a move to prepare this with h6, to rule out Bg5 stuff, and make it harder for him to effectively use d5. Don't forget that the pawn you're fighting to preserve is an extra pawn, and the one extra point of material it gives you isn't worth sacrificing all your other possibilities for. If he ever does grab on d6, the good part is that your dark bishop is no longer a concern.

I don't know what he saw here. OS : he sees that he can support b4, gaining space and attacking your queen, if his knight either goes to d5 or stops being attacked by your rook. His lack of interest in having iron-clad control over d5 is a bit confusing though.
Now ...d5 is looking possible again

He takes a very long route before deciding to go to d5 after all. Then he recaptures in a manner that shields your backward pawn once again, so that it's actually doing a valuable service protecting e5. Better for him would have been to not invest tempo strengthening you on the c file while losing him the file he had control of but which is now blocked by his own pawn.
I like the queen here. If she's harassed, she can easily reach g6, where she still has influence on c2 for a possible rook drop.

I'm trying to force the Queen into a passive position but intstead I chase her into my position where she becomes trouble for me. OS: yes.. this move drops your extra material and gives activity to white. g6 followed by f5 might have been interesting, making use of d6's service to e5. It locks the queen out and gains valuable space on the one side of the board that you don't currently control. If he hops in to d7 immediately, you just force him back with R3c7.

Again I spend too much clock time looking for something better than trading off all the Rooks. OS : Are you forced to initiate the trade? I can't find anything tactical for him if you refuse, and play something like Qb5, to try to exchange off his rather dangerously placed queen.
It's unfortunate that your queen can't come back to defend the king without dropping your only pawn that's stopping his potential passers.
is the a3 pawn not takeable here? You're playing to prevent the penetration by the bishop on b6, but if Qxa3 Bb6, then Qxb4 and he'll lose the d5 pawn to Qe4+ if he's not careful.

how about Qb4? if he captures, you'll both promote and you'll be a pawn ahead with a target on d5. If he doesn't capture, he'll have to hang around protecting his a4 pawn, leaving you with the more flexible queen. Qb4 also disallows the move white chooses next.

The idea is of course to attack the pinned Bishop, but I don't consider my exposed King. OS: I suggest returning back to b4 with the queen. If he gangs up on a5 with Bb6, you can just return to d2 with check, and it's hard to see how white will make progress.
How about Kg8? That way, he doesn't win the d6 pawn, and can't win your bishop without the help of another piece. Also, h7 is protected.
it's unfortunate that Qb4 doesn't seem good here, since double-promotion now leads to white simply walking the d pawn in for another queen.

His correct plan is simply to walk the pawn. He may have been worried that you'd block him with Qe6, but that actually leads to black getting mated via Qe4+ Kg5 h4+ then either Kh5 Qxh7# or Kh6 Bd3+ Kh5 Qxh7#. If the king tries to stop it instead of the queen, then Ke7 d7+ ke7 qc8 and the bishop at the very least will drop.

at white, I'd probably play Qxh7 here. If black takes the a4 pawn, reasoning that he'll get an easy promotion, then I go Qg8, and if his queen comes back to d7 or e8 to defend, then white's dark bishop gets involved with a lot of mating potential. If black takes d5 instead, then I just come right back to e4, comfortable that I still have a material edge (since I think the d5 pawn is falling regardless)
So I win the one passed pawn, but I don't see that he can now get another.
I think black is better off with Be3 to try to keep control of a7. The direct result of the game move is that the black king gets trapped in the corner warding off promotion.
At this point, white is essentially up a piece (his mobile king), so there's really nothing left that black can do
SC) I'm partial to a4 here as it takes the game into independent channels. 4.....Bxb5, 5.axb, while equal on the surface, injects imbalance into the position and gets far away from the book.

I'm not too clear with this opening. In retrospect, Qxd7 might've been better; I like the choice of squares for my knight a bit better. (SC) Either Nxd7 or Qxd7 is good, although I prefer Nxd7 for black. It gives me more problems when playing this opening.
SC) Why so soon? If white wants to play the English, he can start with 1. c4. Here, 0-0 is more flexible, keeping white's options open until he sees what black has in mind.

I 'm no longer sure why I moved my queen here. I think my plan was to further support a b5 push although now that's looking unlikely, and also to clear the c7 square for knights, because the f6 knight can move from f6-e8-c7-e6-d4, and d4 looks like a pretty good square for the knight (SC) Not so fast. There is nothing wrong with Qc6, only the plan behind it. If black wants to play aggresively, he must break with d5 as queenside expansion can only beaccomplish ed with sacrifice of material. Unless there is some tactical support for this (some compensation in time or weaknesses created), the indicated break has to come at d5. Typically, if black can get this in without creating significant weaknesses, he equalizes. The Q at c6 supports this.
SC) Loses a pawn. The correct plan would be 13....Rfe8, followed by e6 and d5 when timing (i.e. tactics) are correct.
I chose not to capture the bishop because then the queen recaptures and dark squares around my king look loose. In particular Ng5 makes my king look uncomfortable.
If I play Nxd5 here, I'm expecting he'll recapture with the e-pawn, opening up that file, which I didn't like.

SC) Allowing 17. Ne7 and if 17.....Qb6 18.a5 Qb4 19.Qf4 e5 20.Qc1 Rbe8 21.Qc2 Rxe7 22.Ra4 Qxe1+ 23.Nxe1 where white gains material but the game is far from over. Black may find salvation through the weak black squares in white's camp. Correct is 17... Rbe8 but black is totally passive here. Even so, its still a hard nut to crack for white.
SC) White's advantage has evaporated. The position is essentially equal.
I realize too late that this allows the knight fork which results in him winning the exchange, so I pray that I might be able to get away with it because then his rook gets trapped in my territory.
SC) Winning is 21.gxf! gxf 22. Ne6+ Rxe6 Rxe6 when the open g-file is fatal. Black is at least equal now, even down the exchange.
Right here Qd7 leaves his rook with nowhere to go, but then he could try Rxe5 cxd5 Qxd5 and I didn't like that because he picks up a pawn with check

It looks like a few moves later I forgot about him giving back the exchange though, because I played this move. I had reasoned that Rxd6 runs into Nxg4, and it looks like the attack against his king is good. (SC) White should try 25.Rxd6 and if 25....Nxg4 26.Qg3. Now if 26.....Qxf7+ 27.Qxf2 Rxf2 28.Rd7+ Rf7 29.Rxf7+ when a very interesting endgame arises.
I block with the queen, thinking if he takes Qxc5, I can do Qxb2 and attack his rook while keeping an eye on the f2 pawn in case he leaves it unguarded.

Now this move surprised me, because if I were white I would've tried to take more pawns off. Perhaps he was too afraid of the attack on the f-file? (SC) 27.Qxc5 Qxb2 28.Re1 leaves white a healthy pawn to the good.
He didn't take the e file? I'm very glad to take it! (SC) See my last note. Indicated here is 28.....h5!, working to trade off both pawns on the kingside.

Seeing this move, I'm thinking, "He can't possibly be trying Re1 ?" because at the board I had tentatively calculated that the endgame would be good for me based on my better king placement, even if he is up a pawn. I haven't run the endgame through computer analysis though, so I'm not sure if I'm right
SC) This loses. But White retains his winning chances with 20.Rh1! attacking the backwardpawn
SC) Black is winning, even if white takes. Superior king position and an outside passed pawn spell doom for white, even a pawn up. (SC)

I... don't get it. but I suppose free pawns are always appreciated... here I try a few variations and it looks like he has no choice but to lose here, so I suppose it doesn't matter that much (SC) Your following analysis is essentially correct. White is lost. The rest of the game is essentially an execution.

I think for the opening and midgame he fared better, but faltered in the endgame, where it looks like my skill surpassed his. (SC) Missed tactics. A lot of them. Primarily on the white side. But black took advantage of what was offered.

takes the c3 from my N but secures my center ** White has great flexibility to chose a pawn structure and development plan against the modern defense, because black isn't causing any immediate problems. Generally, white will take some kind of space advantage, then make sure his pieces coordinate well with each other and the structure. -- death **

a good diagonal,weak f7 and after the e6 maybe some pressure at g6 ** Although this diagonal looks aggressive, if there are no immediate tactics against f7, the bishop will be a target for a black pawn break on d5 or queenside expansion with ...b5. With the c3/d4/e4 structure chosen by white, I would tend to prefer to place this bishop on d3, play h3 to restrain black's bishop from developing usefully, then develop Nf3, Be3, Nbd2, then Qe2 (or possibly Qc2, if it helps pressure a weakened g6), probably choosing 0-0 (though 0-0-0 might be practical in some circumstances). The thematic way to profit from a space advantage is to keep the opponent cramped, and white has good chances to do this. Queenside expansion by b4 and a4 makes sense with this development, too. -- death **

I hadnt decide whether the f4 will overextend my center so i didnt want to play Nf3 to block the f2-f4 ** Neither side is taking the old adage, "knights before bishops," very seriously. More importantly, I don't think either side is basing their development plan on the actual position. Black seems to have a development in mind from move one, without much regard for what white might do. White is dithering, trying not to make any decisions. He fears overextending the center if he goes with f4, but equally would regret not being able to play f4 if he chooses Nf3. Be3 isn't a bad move, but it's the result of not making a decision. I want to know what is the plan. -- death **

I can't see any particular reason for this move. It weakens g6 and doesn't develop. Perhaps it's part of the general plan h6, a6, b5, g5, Ne7, Bb7, with symmetry. This may be aesthetically pleasing, but it isn't really chess. -- death **

white is almost fully developed while the black K needs at least 2 moves to castle so I have to open lines ** An interesting conclusion, but how is white to arrange open lines? It isn't really possible for white to force lines open here, because black's structure is so flexible. Advancing a center pawn allows black to close the center to his advantage. This highlights one of the positive points of playing f4, namely that the advance f5 really would create some weaknesses and open some lines for white. With the chosen structure, white has to develop his remaining forces, grab all the space that's freely available, then sit on black for awhile preparing a breakthrough. -- death **

to allow bring the Rs to the center files and eye g6 ** I would much prefer to develop Nbd2 first. The white queen might want to go to e2 instead, or even to b3. Usually develop the smaller pieces first, since the queen will have more options and it's hard to choose between them until the enemy force arrangements are more clear. -- death **
apparently I failed to create game while his K was still in the center

That rook might have had play on the queenside, so if I was going to move a rook here I probably would have chosen Rfe1. Having f1 available for the knight or bishop can be useful and the rook goes directly opposite the king. Even better than a rook move, though, is 11.a4. Black has made weaknesses on the queenside with his pawn advance, and a4 strikes at b5 while preparing to develop the a1-rook on its original square. Incidentally, this might have been even better if the queen was on e2. -- death **
a strange move since I have a quite secure position and weakens his Kside (his K cant stay in the center) so opening the f file must be good ** Black has achieved his symmetry. -- death **

A reasonable redeployment to allow white pawn breaks to open lines and expose some weaknesses in the black position. On this and previous moves, the pawn advances in the center are a bad idea. It's not just that they lose a pawn (or whatever) in each case, but that the white pawn center is currently potentially mobile, and once it advances, it isn't. White should keep his center pawns side by side for the present, ready to react to a black pawn lever as appropriate. In this position, with f4 coming, black really must do something quickly to avoid being crushed. -- death **

an nice place for both the N or the B but maybe surrenders the center ** Black didn't have any of the center, so getting a well-posted knight on e5 can hardly surrender it. White almost certainly shouldn't capture on e5 on move 13, since this allows black to relieve much of the cramp in his position and improve all of his minor pieces. Now he can get real play on the kingside dark squares, too. That g5 pawn is almost starting to look like a good idea.... -- death **

This seriously weakens the white e-pawn with the hope of getting at the black king along the f-file. It seems a bit too committal. Perhaps Nd3 or Ndf3 to undermine the well-posted black knight is better. -- death **
Hmm, the bishop was developed, attacking the weak isolated e-pawn, so.... it needed to be redeveloped? Why?? -- death **
This looks risky to me, creating another weakness near the white king. -- death **
a bad move,d6 is weak now ** Right, this is weak. -- death **
the N impoved his position
looses
Good execution. -- death **
I am strictly a 1.e4 man, so this will be a learning experience for me too! All of my comments will be inside these double brackets.))
This seems a bit odd. I'd expect 2...e5 or 2...d5))
In view of Black's last move, I'd play 3.d4 here to establish a pawn in the centre without blocking the Bishop's diagonal from h1-a8.))

Black has succeeded in establishing the classic centre - pawns on d5 and e5, protected by Knights on c6 and f6. He has good diagonals for both Bishops.This gives him a space advantage and he stands slightly better. I think that White should be looking for more from the opening. White must strike at the centre, sooner rather than later, or risk being choked.))

This does not prevent 5. ..e4 if Black wants to play it, so I'd favour 5.0-0 here. Then, if Black opens the game with 5...e4, the White King is safely castled and the Black King is in the centre, which can be very significant.))

5...Bc5 is probably better than this, when Black is ready to castle. If this was to enable ...e4, it wasn't needed. Black could play it now and probably should. In all lines Black establishes a clear, but not overwhelming, advantage.))
A sensible move. 6.c4 is the other good choice here.))

6...Bc5 i s more active; 6...Qd7 is worth a look, with the possible idea of 7 ...Bh3 to swap off the fianchettoed Bishop. A frequently used idea in these positions is to move the Rook so that the fianchettoed Bishop can avoid the swap. So here .. .6...Qd7 7.Re1 Bh3 8.Bh1))
A good, solid move, but I would prefer 7. c4 here. Black is about to castle and this is White's last chance to start attacking the Black centre before the King moves into safety.))

This move works because Black reacts badly to it. 8.c4 is certainly better. White may be thinking of bringing the other Knight to f3, but he must be careful if he does since the Knight on h4 will have no square to retreat to.))
This gives up the Bishop pair and mutilates the Black pawn structure. 8 ...Be6 is correct, when Black is slightly better.))
Of course!))

It's usually better to capture towards the centre, which suggests 9...hxg6. However, Black now has a Rook on the half-open f file. Against that, he has weakened the e6 square and this weakness is permanent.))

It is the right idea to attack the centre, but 10.c4 is better. White should do what he can to make the g2 Bishop a strong force. The c4 advance is more likely to open the long diagonal. Black can answer either 10. c4 or 10.e4 with 10...d4, in the one case the diagonal is open; in the other it is closed.))
Now the g2 Bishop will need to find a way into the game. It's vital that he should, because Black has no Bishop to oppose him and he could be very powerful.))

White is thinking along the right lines, but 11.Nf3 or possibly 11.Nc4 first would allow the Queen to protect the d3 pawn and would give the c1 Bishop some space. Piece activity is probably the single most important factor in chess and the Bishop is a bad piece at the moment. It's important to realise that the d3 pawn is now weak. Pawns and squares can be weak, pawn d3 for White, square e6 for Black.))

A mistake. Presumably he's thinking about doubling Rooks on the f file, but he's rushing it. 11...Kg8 removing the King from the open b2-g8 diagonal would be sensible. If Black plays 11...dxc3 it works out fine for White.))
Definitely best here, I think.))

This leads to problems. 13. Bh3, the, old idea of activating the Bishop, is good, with the threat of 14.Be6, winning the exchange. Black would have to play 13 ...Kh8 (13...Nf8 14. Ng5), but White will certainly improve the Bishop's game. 13.cxd4 is also good. ))
White should settle for 14.Qc4.))
I think that 14...dxc3 is more accurate.))
White is winning now.))
I know I have this knight, but I'm not patient enough. ((This is a losing move. 18...Raf8 looks like the best attempt, though White should keep a big advantage.))
Nxe5 ((OccamRazor is right. 19.Nxe5 wins.))
White has a choice of two winning moves here. The simplest, perhaps is 20. cxb7; but 20. Ne5! is even stronger.))
Good. Better than 21.Rxf3))

An interesting point is the Knight on e2. This piece is doomed and so Black should use him as a so-called 'desperado' .. . that is a piece which must be lost and so sells his life as dearly as possible. So here, and before now, in fact, Black could play, 21...Nxg3+ 22. fxg3 and he has at least taken a pawn with him. It's better to take with the f pawn since it is threatened by two Black pieces and may be lost.))

Rxe2 ((This should be the losing move! I don't agree that Rxe2 is correct, though. White should play 22.cxb7! Raf8 23.Rd3 c6 <essential to stop 24.Bd5! pinning the Rook and winning the exchange. See again how the Black King's position on the open diagonal compromises his game. This all started with allowing White to take the Bishop.> Of course, after 23. Rd3 in this line Black cannot dream of playing 23...Rxf3 24.Rxf3 Rxf3?? and White Queens the pawn. After 23 ...c6 24.b4 Bb6 25. Kxe2 White is winning.))
Better to take with the Rook.))
24...b5! ends the career of the White pawn. 24...bxc6 is also good.))
25...Rb8 is slightly better.))
In general terms, the player with the extra piece should be happy to swap off pieces but not pawns; the other player (White in this case) should swap pawns but not pieces)) .

Exactly what Black wants. He now has a passed pawn, and with the extra piece it should be an easy win. He should push the pawn as far as he can as quickly as he can. The point is that if White has to block the pawn with a Rook, and the pawn is on, say, a3 the White Rook has only two squares on the a file. A Black Rook would have a8-a4. In short, superior mobility.))
Black now has mate in 5. 35...Rb2+ 36.Kc6 (36. Kac6 Ra8 mate) Rb6+ 37.Kd5 Bg3+ 38.Kc5 Bf2+ 39.Re3 Bxe3 mate.))
See previous note))
Better is 41...Rb8+ followed by Rb5.))
White has fought hard and done what he can, but this is now hopeless. The rest of the game will be very lightly annotated.))
The King was fine where he was. 53...h5! Is this monotonous?))
There's another mate here, starting with 60...Rd2.))
67...Qd1+ and 67...Qc8+ both lead to forced mates.))
This leads to mate in 4, but 70.Kd3 is mate in 1.))

Black forf eits on time ((There are two mates here. A)71...Rg2+ 72.Kh5 Qh3+ 73.Rh4 Qf5 mate B)71...Qg1+ 72.Kh5 Rh2+ 73.Rh4 Qg6 mate.)) My general comments are: (1) Black was better after the opening and you need something sharper. White should strive for the initiative with his first move advantage. I really think that opening with 1.e4 or 1.d4 is a good idea for a while. Flank openings can be tried later. (2) You got yourself back into the game well during the tactical phase of the game, say moves 13-25, and after 18...d3 you had good winning chances. However, you should have lost after 22.Re4. (3) If you are spending time studying chess, at least half of it (maybe more) should be on tactics. You can study tactical positions in books or there are computer programs like Ct-Art 3.0 from Convekta or Intensive Tactics from Chessbase (you don't need to have Chessbase to run this). After you've solved 50 positions on each of pins, forks and so on, you'll start to see them in your games! (4) Always look at every capture and check on every move, yours and your opponent's. Losing material almost always means defeat ...brilliant sacrifices are another matter! It's really hard to calculate several moves in advance and evaluate the positions, but there's no other way tp play and you will definitely improve with practice. (6) Always try to anlayse your games afterwards. Once you have done that, check it with a computer program (Fritz or Crafty or whatever) if you can to see what you've missed. But don't let the computer do it for you. You'll learn a lot by working out your own mistakes. (7) Always check analysis, including mine. I've tried to be careful but there may be mistakes here. No analysis is ever complete and can always be improved. Thanks for giving me the chance to look at your game. I really enjoyed it. Good luck with your chess.))

When I open with Bird, my plan is to open f1 - a6 diagonal for my light bishop, use my dark bishop to aid in king defense, work at opening either a or c files and directing my main attack on white's king from queenside. I try to avoid attacks on king side, because my own is sort of weak. In this game submitted to FICS ladder (thanks MAd!!!) my plan is foiled. It ends up being my own fault though.
I don't remember ever being countered by a Dutch before, Scid calls this Bird Symmetrical.

How is black going to keep his king safe I wonder? I've actually used that opening as black against e4 openings, results in being a huge battle of minor pieces in the center with whites pawns all on the second row and Black's king totally exposed. Its fun but nerve racking for black. I won both times I used it so I will be totally cautious of this guy, especially his nights.

From my experience, using his opening I want to get my pawns out there and try to direct the fighting queen side or center. Also I want to hamper his knight movements as much as possible, as it is with mobile knights that opening worked for me. Thespiritoftal:This move is an interesting novelty.I believe this is a nice move.
Here he comes with the knights!
hampering his c6 knight and setting up b4 Thespiritoftal:There is no need for such a move.The plan a3-b4 is too early you should first develop your pieces and then start your plans.
I'm trying to keep the f1-a6 diagonal opened so I may use bishop f1 to keep his attacks queen side.

I have my open diagonal. thespiritoftal:It is good you are playing sticked to a specific plan.But the plan is not the best I think.True the bishop has an open diagonal but it doesn't control any important points. Additionally the c5-move gives up the tension in the center in favor for Black. As now he can land his knight comfortably to e4 which he couldn't do if the pawn was on c4 because then d5-will lack protection.
A wrong move.
What I don't like here is in my effort to get the pawns out, my minor pieces are not developed, nor is my king safe! thespiritoftal:You are completely right.You had a better move then b4 here.
preventing him from stealing my diagonal! thespiritoftal:This is a wrong move.
Now White is worse.
He is sneaky, I'll say that much! Hopefully that will stop his A column snatch attempt. Why am I playing Mr defense as white????
It will take my entire army to drive his knight out of e4, guess I'll have to live with it being there, not unusual when I use Bird to result in a knight stuck here, I'm used to it.
It seems way late for castling....
He has certainly destroyed my pawn structure :(
This is turning ugly for me thespiritoftal:This position is clearly better for Black.
Might as well get a1-h8 before he does! I have the good diagonals now, so why do I feel like I am going to loose this game?
Ah yes, the g1-a7 is his, this game is looking like a nightmare! I'm used to having pawns at b5, c5, d4,e3 to stop this sort of nonesense, where the heck are they?

Oh goodie, where did that knight come from???? I forgot to pay his knights close attention, and I know better!!!! As soon as he got the g1-a7 I should have expected this. Thespiritoftal:It is very interesting but I think this move is dubious.

Things are beginning to look hopeless :( My rook pair is gone, no pawns. Black's pawns are in perfect condition and I still have a knight on the back row!!!! Thespiritoftal:All you said is true but your pieces are active and Black king is in the middle. Now you could have had a attack!
After this wrong move your position is worse.
A blunder by Black.You had luck! :)
Well he falls for stupid tricks at least, maybe there is yet hope, I'll try confusing him with night movements and hope he makes another mistake.
He is not focusing his attacks well, I am feeling slightly hopeful now. Thespiritoftal:This is another blunder in return.
Black had such a nice set up, and is letting it slip away...... The opening he used is terrible for king safety!!!

With his king exposed like that, if I make no mistakes I should beable to win this one, certainly a major change of events here! thespiritoftal:I am thinking not like you.This position is good for Black if he plays precise as you can't bring your pieces to attack the enemy king.True it is bare and weak but you don't have enough pieces to attack it.
I'm feeling pretty confident at this point, I don't think he can defend those pawns and keep his king safe now. Thespiritoftal:I think a bit more optimistic about Black here.

Terrible move by me, I am so lucky Black didn't catch it! I feel kind of bad about winning this one now :( He should have done Qxh5, pinning my knight. I would have been done for after he Nxf3! Thespiritoftal: you had luck again :)
Black really blew an opportunity here, cost him the game. Thespiritoftal:It is true he missed an opportunity but he is still better.
Going into full attack mode now
By threatening his pawns I am hoping he will forget to protect his king

Another very poor move by Black, he should be defending e6, I think he has given up in this game and is just going through the motions of playing now. Thespiritoftal:This is a blunder.Now White is winning.
The 7th row is mine, I nearly never loose once I put a rook safely on this row.....
Diminishing his hopes toward moving those pawns, Black is a goner now, no king defense at all.
White has mate soon...

bakker resigns thespiritoftal:With mate coming... French Defense
Advance Variation. Other possibilities: exd, Nc3, Nd2, ...
in the french defense, black generally attacks white center particularly the d4 square
White wants to play the Milner Barry Gambit. They sacrifice the center for a quick developpement

avoiding the well known trap 6.. .cxd 7. cxd Nxd 8. Nxd Qxd 9. Bb5+ winning the queen ferkelchen: In my opinion 6..Bd7 is a slight inaccuracy because it opens up more possibilities for white. It is more exact to play 6..cxd4 first followed by 7..Bd7.

lepionjapon ais: white can protect the d4 pawn by playing Bc2 ferkelchen: a) Yes, that is true, but after 7..cxd4 8.cxd4 Nb4 black is already slightly better, because black will exchange the strong white-squared bishop. (9. Bb3 is bad because of 9..Bb5 (prevents castling) and after 9.Ba4 Qa6 looks very strong.) b) By playing 7. 0-0 white does not try to take advantage of black's move order. 7. dxc5 is a well-known good move in this position. The idea is to gain space on the queenside and to win a tempo by playing b2-b4 (attacking the bishop) and sometimes even to play b4-b5 (attacking the knight). The mainline is: 7.dxc5 Bxc5 8.0-0 a5 ( to prevent 9.b4, not 8...Nge7?? 9.b4 wins a piece) and now 9. Nbd2, 9.a4 (to control b5, Na3-b5 is an idea) or 9.Qe2.

9.Ng5 is an interesting offbeat line, not sound, but good enough to surprise your opponent - especially in a rapid or blitz game. But even in a tournament game it seems to work sometimes... ferkelchen-NN, Cologne 1988: 9.Ng5 Nc6 10. Re1 Bc5 11.Qf3 Nh6 12.Nc3 Bd4 13.Bf4 Nxe5? (to greedy) 14. Bxe5 Bxe5 15.Rxe5 Qxb2 16.Rae1 Qxc3 17.Nxe6! Bxe6?! (Better was 17..Qxe1+ but the position is lost anyway) 18.Bb5+ Qc6 19. Rxe6+ fxe6 20.Rxe6+ Kd8 21.Bxc6+ bxc6 22.Qf41-0
white sacrifices a second pawn

black generally declines this second pawn and plays a6 preventing white from playing Nb5 ferkelchen: Yes, 10..a6 is the "safety first"- approach and probably it is the best move. (Another solid move is 10.. Qb6 which should be answered by 11.a4 ( to kick the queen by playing a5 or to play Bb5 / Nb5) or 11.Qg4 ( to hinder the kingside development).) 10..Qxe5 is perfectly playable, but much more risky (No risk, no fun ;))

may be a mistake ferkelchen: I dont like 11...Qc7. The main idea of Qxe5 is to play 11..Qb8. There are almost 200 games with 11...Qb8 in my database (overall score about 50 per cent which is fine for black). This line is covered in detail in Watson's "Play the french", 3rd edition. Pretty complicate line, i will give you just one line, the one i played in hundreds of blitz games against a friend of mine. 11...Qb8 12. Nxd5 Bd6 13.Qg4 (or 13.Qh5) Kf8 14.Bd2 (14.Nc3 is an alternative) h5 15.Qh3 Bc6.
the e-pawn is pinned by the e1 rook ferkelchen: Nxd5 is attacking the queen now compared to the line 11...Qb8!

is Qb8 better? Qb6? ferkelchen: Well, after 12..Qb8 black is a tempo down compared to 11...Qb8. I can't believe that this is working. 12.. Qb6?? blunders the queen, i bet you meant 12..Qd6. I would play 13.Bc4 (idea 14.Bf4 winning) 13..Rc8 14.Bf4 Qc5 15. Rc1 and i don't see any defense for black, white wins.

I do not know what should be played here ferkelchen: Well, 13.Bf4 is a very logical move, it can't be wrong. But let's have a look at the position from a more general view: White is a pawn down but has a tremendous lead in development and the black king is still stuck in the center. White has to prevent black from catching up with development and / or has to create weaknesses in the opponent's camp.
to avoid the Nc7+ threat ferkelchen: yes, only move

I still do not know what was the best move here. I did not like the idea of exchanging pieces by playing Nc7 ferkelchen: Of course not 14. Nc7+ Black takes the knight 14...Rxc7 15.Bxc7 Qxc7 and you are lost. Black has two pieces and pawn against one rook. 14.Rc1 is a much better move.

all threats from white seem to have disappeared ferkelchen: Well, this position is pretty sure a critical one. One bad move and black will be better. But of course the same is true for black, he still has to be very careful.

a strange move. White has now two attacked pieces. But the bishop cannot be taken. Elsewere Rxc8 followed by Nc7+ is crushing. Both bishop and e-pawn cannot take the knight because of the pin and if the queen take the knight, white simply takes back with the queen, as bishop and e-pawn are pinned ferkelchen: Yes, this is true, but i still don't like the move because by playing 15..Ne7 black protects everything, develops the knight and attacks your strong knight on d5. Let's have a look if there is a better move than 15.Bb5. And in my opinion 15.Qh5 (idea is 16.Rxe6+) it as least worth a try. Well, what to do? a) 15..Bxd5 16.Rxc8 Qxc8 17.Dxd5 Sure, white is still a pawn down but black is under heavy pressure: For example 17.. Be7? 18.Qd4!, 17...Nf6? 18. Bb5+ Nd7 19.Qh5! 17..Ne7 looks like the best move, but white can play 18.Bb5+ Nc6 19.Qe5! and black still has to solve a lot of problems, white has more than enough compensation for the pawn. b) 15...Be7. 16. Nxe7 Nxe7 and now 17. Rcd1 creates a lot of complications with chances for both sides after 17..Qd5 18. Qh3 c) 15..Ne7 16. Nxe7 Bxe7 18.Rxe6 Qxd3 19. Rce1 0-0 20. Rxe7 looks drawish
is it good? ferkelchen: Let's put it this way: There is nothing better

It was better to play 16..bxc6, it forces the queen exchange. For example: 17.Nxe7 Qxd1 18.Rexd1 Bxe7 Black is a pawn up in the ending, but in my opinion it would be very difficult to convert the pawn: The queenside pawns are weak and the rook on h8 still out of play. But a pawn is a pawn...

in order to force the kinght to move, but bishop may have taken this pawn, isn't it? ferkelchen: No, 17.. Bxb4 loses by force: 18.Nxb4 Nxb4 19. Rxc8 Qxc8 20.Dd4! Nc2 and now a computer would probably suggest 21.Qxg7 but simply 21.Rc1 leads to a winning ending after 21..Nxd4 22.Rxc8+ Kd7 23.Rxh8 Ne2+ 24.Kf1 Nxf4 25.Rxh7 But you missed 17. Qb3! attacking the pawn on b7. Black is not able to defend the pawn because 17. .b6? 18.Rcd1 is winning - there is no defense against Nc7+ winning the queen. 17..Bd6 18.Bxd6 Qxd6 19.Qxb7 looks like the best chance for black, but white is definitively better after 19...Qd7 20.Qb5
Much better than 17..Bxb4?
Weaker is 19..Nxe7. 20.Rxc8+ Nxc8 21.Rc1! and the rook invades the 7th rank.
I do not like this move, 20.b5 first was better (see comment on the next move)
Why not 20..Kf6? 20..Kf6! activates the king and finally the rooks are connected!

A very bad move - but it wins the game! :)) Black should have played 22..Rxc7 23.Bxc7 Nd5 - as you mentioned below - and is simply a pawn up! For example 24.Bd4 f6 25.Be3 a6 Much better than 22.Rc7 was 22.Bg3 (idea: 23.Rxc8 followed by 23.Rc1 and Rc7). I don't think that black is able to win this ending.
black was afraid of the line Rxc7 Bxc7 with the threat Rd8# but missed the simple Rxc7Bxc7Nd5line

Black resigns. ferkelchen: A dissapointing ending to an interesting game. lepionjaponais: I would like to understand why black managed to keep a pawn more without any real threats from white. How white sould have played to keep the initiative ? ferkelchen: Well, i showed you a lot of possibilities in the notes given above. By the way: There is at least one lecturebot lesson dealing with the Milner-Barry-attack online on FICS. Don't miss it! See you online, bye bye.
Be brave! MH: Not all bravery is good. Do you think the move is good?

The threat of Nc3-d5-c7 is real, but quite easily blocked. Much more common for White is Nf3, Bc4, O-O, Qe2, Rfd1 to bring more pieces into the offense. The development of Bc1 is usually determined late, depending upon how Black has developed.
If Bc1 hadn't been moved earlier it could now be used at g5. If White was further developed and had Qe2 and Rd1, then Bf4 would still make pretty good sense (targeting d6).
Qe2 was needed to avoid Nxe4!
Going off into tactical territory before completing development involves some risk. It has to be very useful to outweigh those risks.
Retreating would've justified Black's ...Nh5.

n ow Black could have played Nf4, but alas, he didn't. Instead of Bd3, perhaps Ng5 would have been better? MH: It's requires some analysis rather than principle. In either case Black has a knight left on the rim and a bad Bc8. White is clearly better.
This leaves Nh5 awkwardly placed, leaves White's good Bd3 on the board and weakens e6.

here it is anyway. I don't like the position of my Q+B MH: It's not ideal, but sometimes we just move along and don't worry about such things. Remember, it was the earlier utility of these pieces which caused Black so much trouble. Perhaps Bd3 isn't as good as before, so that a trade for the knight is just an equal trade. If you focus on keeping a certain piece against all odds, then you devalue your other pieces. Bd3 served well and now you have the great Rd6 and Nd4.
ops, complications. Is my rook trapped?
how about Nxe5? After Qg3 Bxe6 Nxe6 both the Queen and mate at g7 threaten, so Black needs to play Qe7, getting into the same line as the game continues
Qb3 was tempting until I saw the answer Qc4, forcing an equal endgame

now Black suddenly aims at getting away with the material playing Rf6 in his next move. I have this bad habit of always wanting to increase pressure instead of taking back material, so for my next move I considered Rc1 (Re1 f4 didn't look too tempting), but ended up taking back the knight and the advantage. Note also how my initial plan of 22. Nxf8 Rxf8 23. Re1 won't work because of

White's knights are either terrific or just targets. If you can prevent Black's rooks from becoming active, then the knights are very good. Secondarily, after tying up Black's pieces what do you aim to do?
Black can't touch any of the knights! MH: Excellent.
but tries to anyway, hoping for Qxc7 Qxe6, when the Queen can go to g8 covering the check on the 8thrank
Very satisfying
the covered check is lethal, Black can't avoid both mate and queen loss with 28. Ng6++ - Black resigns MH: Excellent tactics. I suspect this last phase was quite exciting and difficult.

I don't know very well this variation, I was expecting Be2 and o-o RT: I'm not very familiar with this opening either but I think all kinds of move orders are possible here. 6...b6 makes sense to prepare ...c5.
I think this is one typical pawn push in the opening, the other one being c5. RT: yes, these two pawn pushes are standard, but here this just loses a pawn.
White goes for the exchanges, which tend to lead to a drawish game (without the queens). RT: npt when he has an extra pawn!
I realized that I was unable to take back the pawn at e4, as the knight is protected by the f4 pawn
if Nc6, then the exchange would destroy black's queen side pawn structure RT: I agree, Nbd7 is better.

to open the line of the Bg7 and to attack the Be3 RT: good idea, you get some activity now although probably not enough for the pawn. Probably White should have played Nxd7 last move and aimed to simplify. Now his pieces are a bit wobbly.
I think White is trying too hard to hang on to his bishop pair here. He is underdeveloped and has an extra pawn, simplification is good.
to open the line for the Rd8 and stop white from o-o-o RT: a principled idea, but as you make the rook better, you make the knight worse. Again Bxc3+ is something to consider.

I feel here the game was with only small advantage to White because of the extra pawn. Black king is safer, and black could get counterplay. RT: I still prefer White here, you really have to prove you have counterplay, and none of your pieces look all that effective here. tajincito: On the other hand, the Bg7 is now blocked by the pawn. If ...Bh6, then g3 protects the pawn

here, I started a series of attacks and counter attacks, but without a clear objective or strategy. I attack c2, and liberate e6 for the knight. RT: This is something you will have to work on. You can't live one move at a time and hope that your oppponent will miss your crude threats, or eventually you will luck into a threat he can't answer. When you make a move like this, think about whether you are improving your pieces. Is the bishop really better placed on f5? It turns out it is vulnerable and you must be alert to the idea of White playing h3 and g4 with tempo. Maybe 13.. .Rd7 is best (improving your rooks), but White is still better.

So far so good, but I did not realize that the Bishop would have no fly square after the knight occupies e6. RT: a tactical blunder, which drops a piece. Better to admit your mistake and drop back with 15...Be6

After the exchanges, I have two pawns for the bishop. This increases my material disadvantage, with no real compensation. RT: Black is lost here. You only have one pawn for the bishop. Although you have some chances of getting the e5 pawn, your h6 knight is stuck and White has the bishop pair
Attacking the Bd5 twice, blocking the pawn and menacing to win one in e5

my f6 square is very weak now, and white pieces will start to attack the weakness. I could double the rooks on the d column, but there is no target in white camp, as all minor pieces protect the d column squares. I was also thinking of Rf8 to prepare f6, but I preferred to prepare it by improving Nh6 position. May be too slow? RT: you are desperate now, Kh8 and Ng8 is as good as anything. Yes too slow, but there is nothing better.
Probably Rdd8 was better, to keep control of the d file? I did not like to take Nxf6 as this would leave my king completely blocked in the 8th rank (with the white pawn in f6)
Logic move, white occupies the open d file
In order to move the a8 Rook, I wanted to protect the a7 pawn from the bishop. Perhaps a6 was better? RT: because of the trap you are planning, ...a6 is better, but it makes little difference.
I realized that my previous move ...b6 allowed this attack on the Rook.
White takes control of the other open line, e.
with the white rook in the 7th rank, the game is almost at the end. My Ng8 is blocked and it cant take the rook as the pawn goes to queen.

The game is over, the f6 pawn is ready to make a discovered check and take the knight afterwards...RT: the game was over as a contest a long time ago. Your opponent didn't do much wrong, so perhaps you were unlucky in that regard. But you made the game very easy for him by dropping first a pawn and then a bishop early in the game. There is little point in analysing how the game goes once you are already down a piece. My two recommendations to you would be 1) check your "automatic" moves and make sure they don't lose in a simple tactical way. Here ...e5 is a typical opening move, but not when White has e5 so well covered. And e6 looked like the perfect square for your knight until you realised you had run your bishop out of squares. 2) Don't play aimlessly. It is difficult sometimes to have a plan. But even if you can't come up with a plan, try to improve your position somehow. Don't worsen your position attacking pawns your opponent can simply defend at no cost to himself. Good luck in the rest of your games!
I am not an e4 player, but I hope I will be able to help you guys to find some of your mistakes and strengths! :)
Ruy Lopez Main Line

wrong move IMHO. Leads to .. Qg6 11. Bc2 dxc3 which loses a pawn. Better is Bd5 forcing the removal of the powerful bishop at b7 (one way or the other) which would remove the mate threat on g2. vassil: Well, not the best move because after Qb6, white's in trouble. Better would be to just exchange pawns.
As I said, Qb6 would've been better.
Wrong move. After eXf (en passant), the King is in check and black is practically lost.
White missed the winning move.
No need to panick! First of all, white is protecting the mate with you knight; second,you can take the hanging f pawn with no worries!

Very bad move! White can now play Nd6+ and win the queen. This game is a war of blunders as I can see! :) Uh-oh. Leads to Ne7+ Nxe7 Bxg6 which loses a Queen for a bishop and a Knight. Better IMHO is dxc3+ 15. Kh1 cxb2 16. Bxb2 which wins 2 pawns for 1 pawn
Great move.. alternative would be Nd6 as I said above, but this is also winning the queen.
Better would be to take the h pawn.
Losing a knight for no reason.

Yup, a big mistake. White shouldn't panick.. the two rooks may be dangerous, but not fatal. Since white has such a huge piece advantage, it should attack, not try to defend. "Attacking is sometimes the best defence." Oops. Bad move on my part. Leads to Rh1+ which loses a queen for a rook. Better is Ra2 leading to .. Rh1+ 28. Kg2 R8h2+ 29. Kg3 Rxa2 which leads to an exchange of 2 rooks. A Better player would have punished white for this mistake but the inexperience of black allowed white to recover for a close win.
The blunder war has continued.. black should play Bd8.
Leads to 38. Ke6 Rh8 39. RF8+ RxF8 40. exf8=Q+ which loses 2 rooks and a bishop for a rook and a queen. better IMHO is Rxc6 which wins a rook for a rook and a bishop.
Black has moved into a forced mate in 2. Leads to Rxc7+ Kb8 e8=Q#

Black checkmated vassil: This game is a War of Mistakes. Black did a good job trying to win after the lost game.. white could've won alot quicker. Both of you did a great job in the opening (up until move 10) Try not to learn much opening strategy, but Middle and Endgame.. Thank you, Vassil
This and 1.. f5 are my answers to the strategical 1. d4.
Inviting the Nimzo-Indian Defence.
After this I have to think of what to answer. Though I could play 3.. b6 I won't, because I had bad results against strong players.
Leads into play I normally won`t play. You see my dilemma here - trying to play open tactical games and not beeing prepared enough for the difficult Queen`s Indian after 3.. b6.
At the time of the game I didn`t know any line after this - so all the next moves had been played without opening knowledge! (After the game I took a look at the main lines.)
As I didn`t know the common 4.. Be7 I tried to to something active. That looked logical for me since white can`t play e3 after he played g3.
Keeping the tense in the center and developing pieces.
Whi te usually take on c5 only after Black have committed their bishop on e7. So, your remark on your 6th move is exact. Here White should have played either 6. cxd5 or 6.O-O.
I was happy to develop my bishop without a loss of tempo.
Avoids a lonely pawn after 7.. ed. I didn`t like 7.. Qd5:, because of the possible Queens exchange. 7...exd5 was possible too. Although you have a lonely pawn, your play is free.
I have seen that this had been played by Pregarac,V against Harcet,F in Portoroz open 1994 with an early win for white (30 moves).

My new move. The ideas are putting preasure on f2 and b4, preparing for Rd8 and trying to get a majority at the queenside with the large number of pieces. I hoped that white would get some development troubles and black could develop totally (Bd7) soon. I am not sure if this was a risk, because it leaves Blacks` kingside alone? What do you think would be the best play here? Yes, your kingside seems alone, but White's pieces are not well placed to launch an attack on your king. There seems to be a drawback to 9...Qb6: Black has problems to developp his Bc8, as the pawn b7 is blocked by the queen. An interesting idea was 9... Qe7 in order to prepare e6-e5 and free the Bc8.
10.e4 !? seems to be faster.
With a look at the white queen.
Black now is developed completely. Whith this move I already had Bb5 in mind.

Now is the critical moment! I saw that 13.. Nf6 or 13.. Nc7 looked really bad for Black. So I sit back and took some time for thinking about a (tactical!?) answer to the move. Yes, i'm according with you: it's an important turning point in this game. White are weak on the a6-f1 diagonal. So I think they should have played 13. Rd1.

Gives knight and bishop for a rook and two pawns. After the game I asked my opponent about this move and he said something like "It was good and any other move would have been a lot worse". I'm according with him.
All that moves seem to be forced.

Here I had to find the right plan for Black. Material is equal mathematically, but Black has less officiers. I tried to move the b- and the a-pawn forward to get another queen. My question is: Was this the right play here and if not - what was it? I think this is a good plan. What could you do else ? 19... Rac8 is the only one other possibility, with play for Black on the "c" and "d". But sooner or later, it's inevitable that black pushes his "a" and "b" pawns.
My plan seems to work: Pawns are half way up already.
I think we can put a full question mark to 23th white move.
Moves forward with tempo.
Black would be happy to change some pieces to make the position more clear.
Trying to activate the rooks - and giving up the plan. and losing a pawn...
Sorry for that move...
My opponent was nice enough not to see it...
White seems to stand a lot better now - where did I loose the advantage? 27...b3 was a real bad move, not only throwing away the advantage you had but giving it to your opponent...
a tactical blunder which gives the victory to black.
Black is right to fear nothing: the Qa1 protects the g7 square. Now Black wins easily.
From now on both players had very littel time left - especially White.

A nice game... I want to say: - You played well the opening, seizing the initiative as soon as possible. - You have a nice tactical play (13..Ncxb4!) - You should verify carefully your moves before playing it (for example 27...b3 and 30...Rb4) and verify the possible responses of your opponent - When you choose a plan (push the pawns), keep it. A bad plan is better than no one...

I had never met this particular defense so I just decided to develop a piece and see what black had planned. joeva: I havn't met this defense either, but I believe it's called the "Baltic Opening" and I have recently seen an article on it at www.chesscafe.com

Now I can gain a tempo by making black move his bishop again. joeva: This move is already a severe blunder and shows that black doesn't understand the ideas behind his chosen opening at all. One of black's goals here is control of the square e4. And now he gives up that control for free, allowing you to gain a tempo, build an ideal pawn-center and then regain the pawn with a good developing move.

The for black is that he has managed to not block in his light squared bishop as in a normal QGD. joeva: Yet the downside is that it took two tempos, thus leaving white with a lead in development and good central control added in for free. Also, the light squared bishop in a "normal" QGD, locked in as it may be, has the important job of protecting b7, which is now potentially weak.

Just a look at the position reveals the white advantage: white has the perfect center, developed three pieces, castled, and it's his turn. Black, on the other hand has developed only two pieces (and the Bg6 is out of play for now), and is still two moves away from castling (and he won't manage to in this game).
I was planning for black to either retreat his bishop and I'd win another pawn or capture the c3 knight.
Now I can pick up another two pawns and generate some nasty tactics.
black obviously missed this tactic and is now down materially in addition to positionally. Many players might have resigned here.
Black is facing quite a bit of trouble in my opinion.

This allows a nice combination, one of the nicest I've ever been able to play. However, I don't see how black can do much better. Is there? joeva: Not really. A computer might argue that being only a piece down after, say, 13...a5 14.Qa4 0-0, when white will win "only" the knight on d7, is better than being down two rooks, which certainly has some truth to it, but it wouldn't have made any difference in the result...
And the rest is easy.

With the king confined to the 8th rank, I intended to blast up the center and checkmate black. joeva: or win in any other way with the two extra rooks... Again, quite a nice game, but really not particularly good for learning from it, but rather to "show off". Of course, we all like to do that now and then :-). Just don't forget to also remember the games, where you lost and didn't really have a clue why. I am certain those happen as well. Good luck and good games in the future. Joachim Vaerst, 'joeva' on FICS,joachim(at) sboberberg.de. Feel free to mail me with any questions.

Now I spot that black will have a very good diagonal for his bishop My bishop at e2 is very passive,I move it to d3 with the aim to force an exchange and get my bishop to e4,at least d3 is a more active square
I would like to play d5 but e4 forks 2 pieces,So I'm forced to take the e pawn
my pieces are congested on the d file and so I play to exchange them, with the black kings N gone black will have to be a little more curcumspect
The black bishop is now on the good diagonal and I exchange Knights

I need to do something about that bishop,Qc2 would be nice but B*N would be next and my kingside pawns are blown apart,so I'm reduced to trying to lock up the centre at the expense of making my bishop even poorer.
I not especially worried about the knight going to d4 because I will exchange and f2-f3 shores up the centre,I would like to open the d file so I need to move the Q out of the way
I guess the target is the pin on the knight and then a nasty Nd4
I dont know what hes up to but I assumed he was starting to go for the kill,In effect he is probably preparing f5,with my concern about Nd4 I offer an Q exchange that controls the d4 square.
I need to get the Bishop away before I'm just defending it
Attacking the C pawn I can defend with b3

He has a passed pawn but I have a queenside majority,I decide to attack e5 with my mandatory Q move.
time was getting low and I effectivelly destroyed any quuenside advantage Bd3 better
