He defends e5 but its not a good place for his rook,its starting to look drawish,unfortunatly we were both very low on time,I offered a draw but it wasnt accepted,we played on very quickly and when the dust settled my opponent would have won my h pawn and given his d passed pawn.I didnt think it likelly I would be able to hold off both,so I resigned.

I felt that this was an unusual moveorder, maybe it isn't. MH: It's very unusual and indicates he wanted to throw you onto your own resources immediately. Strong players often use that "trick". There is a Geller Variation of the Pirc where Bd3 is key. But, it's not considered terribly dangerous. The more common moves: Nc3 or f3 are perhaps a bit stronger. Of interest is the question: "Why didn't he want to play Nc3?" I'd guess he wants a bigger center with c2-c4 and only then Nb1-c3. Still, that's not considered bad for Black. It's just probably different than what you're used to seeing.
He might be teasing you into ...Bg4 when he knows pawn d4 isn't weak (he still has c2-c3). He could optionally advance some pawns.

This move surprised me as I've never seen it before. I got the impression that it was a mistake, as it might aid my queenside play, but I couldn't find a good way to exploit it. MH: I don't know if it's part of the Geller Variation, but if he follows with Bg5, N1d2, then it's a transposition to a Torre Attack. The guy is full of transpositions to confuse you. Fortunately, in the Pirc, the idea is to develop as you have and only then to look at White's set-up to decide what's next. Kasparov played this a bit in his earlier years, but nobody else plays it. I'd guess ...Nc6 and ...e5 should be good. Black doesn't have to worry about a Nb1-c3-d5 (or -b5), so no queen-side pawn moves are really needed. Then aiming for ...Nh5 and ...f5 as in a King's Indian Defense should be one good way of fighting for the advantage.

Here I choose between this move and c5. I don't know if I did the right move. MH: The problem with c6 is that it's just not needed. There's no target for ...b7-b5-b4. You're still okay if you see quickly that play has to be further toward the h-file with ...e5 and ...f5.
Here I felt that he was aiming for e5.

He slows down and doesn't play Bg5 - interesting. He could be waiting for ...e5 to pounce with 9. dxe5 dxe5 10. Nd2-c4. Now ...b5 fits and leaves White with no targets. Of course, you could also go with ...e5 and then fight back.

This move looks like a mistake when I see it afterwards. I want to play Nbd7 to further the control of e5 and make d5 not so effective as it will give the knight good squares. But I felt it would hem in the light bishop, so I decided to first exchange it. I know it cost 3 tempi and help develop his queen. But it is a closed position, he has no threats that I can see and I'm a bit cramped so I figured it would be alright.
Going for e5, I think. Feels like a mistake though, turns out it was. MH: Maybe Bg5, Qd2, Bh6 with king-side play would be more correct.

I don't think his Bd3 is very dangerous, but I do see your desire to trade a minor piece and ease your cramp. It's a bit risky as your note shows, but now that you've committed with ...Be6 you might have to do it. You could have begun with ...Nb8-d7 in order to move ...Nb6 to support either ...Bc4 or a pawn on that square. I think your struggle to find a good plan against his odd opening play was exactly what he wanted. Now you have to struggle to get further without a complete breakdown.
He isn't risking any complications and just lets you get by with the trade. Still, he has e5 in play, so you're not done with getting through the opening.

Can't see the the point of that move. Can you? MH: Only that he might be intending c3-c4 and plans to respond to ...bxc4 with Rxc4 to attack pawn c6 and Qc7. His play is a little here and there and not very focused. I suppose he was waiting for you to make some big mistakes, so he wouldn't have to commit to any plan which would either rebound badly or would limit his options.
Couldn't find a good plan, so I decided to expand.
Finally it comes. MH: No big deal.
Be5 is better than Bg7 and White's rooks are a little better than Black's. It's close.
BIG mistake. He didn't see what was coming and honestly, neither did I. MH: It goes nowhere from here and doesn't coordinate well with Be5.
Just to get some play... MH: Neat.
To trade knight for bishop... MH: Now I see what you were talking about with regard to Ng3. It does get in the way. At minimum you get rid of Be5 and if he's not careful it goes for lost.
NOW I saw it was trapped, and he never did!
Here I can take in three ways. If I take with the rook, I'll loose my knight. If I take with the knight, he'll get a second pawn and a strong grip of the game and a weak king.
HAHA MH: Perfect!
keeping your king perfectly safe is first priority. Of course, the knight had no other retreat, so it was easy to 'find'.
Is this an error? MH: Looks fine to me. Pawn d4 isn't so secure he could play c3-c4.
How to protect f6? if Bg7 I'll become incredibly cramped. Maybe Ng5 were better.
I underestimated this pin, but I saw that I could save it. MH: The pin on Nd6 was just the kind of tactic he'd been waiting to pull on you. It's his meat and potatoes against weaker opponents.
This seems to work, but is dangerously complicated. Once again you're defending and unfortunately you're proving he's better by choosing the hardest way to defend.

Going to b7. I could have saved the game, but the next move was a dire mistake that I couldn't recover from. After the next move I can't save the knight, I'm down a pawn and I couldn't think anymore. I fought on but it was futile, so I'll just pretend that I resigned after the next move. I hoped for 27...Re8 28. Rxe8 Rxe8 29. Qd1 (29. gxf4 Re1+ leads to mate)

The correct move was 27...Rfe8 with the same threat, but after the text I could still have moved my bishop to f8. But now I can't and the knight is lost. MH: Your note is jumbled as your thinking appears to have been. The complexity of this section of the game just confused you.

It's too early to resign! Either ...Bg5 or ...Bh6 are enough, though still complicated. I think you're giving a bit too much credit to your opponent (in this game) and were expecting super-human tactics or something. But, on the other hand, you weren't giving him as much credit as you should for being sneaky and subtle. All in all you played well and deserved to win or at least draw. I think you could study the openings more or stop worrying about them and just play. Every opening which might even distantly be related to your repertoire might be helpful. In this game some knowledge of the Geller Variation and of the King's Indian Defense (in case of c2-c4) and of the Torre Attack would have been of some use. As far as planning goes you did pretty well, but it doesn't appear you considered a very broad range of possibilities and when you struck out with a plan you didn't stick to it for long. Perhaps worst of all was that he was playing you (not just your pieces) and you were playing superman and not just 'some guy'. This showed, I think, when you got enmeshed in the Nd6 pin problem and you didn't solve it very neatly. Maybe I'm over-stating this, perhaps it was just technical skill, but I could see what he was doing to not expose himself and to have options and then how he tried to take advantage. That he goofed up and lost his bishop showed clearly he was far from GM strength and was certainly human. I suggest: study openings some if you think it would help you, especially seeing how some openings develop in to certain kinds of middle-game plans. I suggest you study how to analyze variations better: anybody below master needs it. No wait, everybody below 2600 needs it. Mostly I suggest you study planning and coordination so you can develop better plans in your games despite a running clock and a strong opponent who glares at you for taking your time. This will develop more confidence and you'll more likely stick to your plans until your opponent really forces your hand. In a nutshell: study openings if you like, some variation analysis and MOSTLY planning in unusual positions. A lot of planning is imagining where you want all your pieces so they're safe, active, coordinated and so on. You don't always have to say, "I go here, he goes there, I go here, he goes there." You can say, "Given a few free moves I'll go here, there, and even over there." or maybe "I'm gonna swarm that area of the board and put a knight here, a rook here and my queen there." This one-sided thinking allows you more freedom to imagine new situations and yet stay within the bounds (pretty much) of the reality of how a piece can safely move in the midst of enemy forces. Getting caught up in only responding to the enemy is too limiting and destined for failure.
A quiet choice which at first indicates that Black wishes to avoid main lines after Nf6
Going towards the English Attack setup. Killerman: You could also consider c4 setting up a Maroczy bind or simply Nc3.
Delaying the castling a bit more. There is no way, anyway that I can castle kingside with these pawn pushes. Killerman: Iagree
Black anticipates the Knight run from f6 to play it back to e5

This is a position very well known to theory. Despite White's obvious kingside attack it is normal for Black to castle as it is just as likely his king could get caught where it stands. Black's plan usually revolves around the moves b5, Qa5 and Rc8 with the b-pawn moving on to b4 at some point.

Black attacks f3, he is trying to keep up pieces activity. He will do that almost till the end Killerman: As mentioned castling is normal. Although the knight does attack f3 it is not actually necessary for you to cover the f-pawn.

Forced but useful, it covers f3 and lets the rooks talk to each other. Killerman: I don't agree that this move is forced as there are good alternatives. You obviously missed that if Black removes the guard to the f-pawn by Nxd4 you recapture with the queen which pins the Black knight to the g-pawn
Not really in keeping with what is required. Either 11..Na5 intending Nc4, b5 intending Bb7orcastleswouldbebetter

More than 4 minutes for this; I want to continue my pawn storm gaining a tempo with the forced Knight run. Killerman: Correct, but you must be careful when attacking that you do not get carried away with it.

Another long thought (5 minutes). I was not sure that it was appropriate to give back e5 to the Black Knight, but what else could have been done to continue the attack? The other alternative that comes to my mind is to strengthen the king's position with Kb1 Killerman: With any pawn storm you need to make sure that you have targets and that you can back up the attack. The f5 square which you are aiming for is a good place to go, but where is the backup? Also, as you correctly state, you have simply handed back the e5 square to Black, is it not better to restrict his pieces until you are ready to thrust forward? Kb1 is a good alternative, your king is safest there and covers the a-pawn but this needs to be combined with Nf3 which actually threatens h4 and gives some cover to e5. This knight manouvre is not unusual in the Sicilian. The variations are complicated after Nf3 or Kb1 but White is fine.
fxe6 is superior as Black keeps a grip on the f5 square

Dubious if not wrong. Much ado about nothing! I don't really get any real fruit from my attack. The bishop pair is well countered by the Black's active Knights; The f-file is very difficult to exploit. 15.Nf5 was much more dangerous, attacking g7 and d6. Killerman: You are correct that your move was not the best and Nf5 is far superior to any other option. What you needed to evaluate was the resulting position after exchanges and the relative value of pieces, you can't simply look to get the bishop pair and think that you will eventually succeed. The other point is the pawn structures, black would conceed too much if he captures the knight on f5 and allow you to recapture with the g-pawn so he is stuck with your piece in his position.

The dynamics of the game have changed and White's position is not now an aggressive one. Your pawns look weak and Black has the extra centre pawn. Black now has the time to start his standard attacking idea
Black counterattacks
making my pawn structure stronger
My idea was to play Nb1 and then Nxa3... It's a pity that later I will choose to foolishly invert the moves. Killerman: b3 is not any better
I don't have any means to strenghten my King's position but I don't see the need. I play this move in advance, blocking Black short castling and preparing for a never happened new attack.
d5 is also a good alternative for Black

I give the victory to the black. My idea was "Nxa3 and then Queen exchange"... "Nxa3 and then Queen exchange"... "Nxa3 and then Queen exchange".. . and then what? I play this going under the intermediate check

Dubious. Activate the bishop but h6 had more poison, opening a second attacking arena (e.g. 27...h6 28. gxh gxh 29 Rh1 with the white rooks in a sad passive position). Killerman: Black could also exchange a pair of rooks off and then play h6 which may be stronger still. The other reason Black's move is unsound is that he exchanges a centre pawn and thus creates another unsupported pawn which he will need to cover at some point. The positive position of your king in this position is critical as it is another attacking piece.
Exchanging pawns improves my chances to draw
g6 is better fixing the White pawns and looking to place the bishop on the diagonal

Black has not very clear ideas. He protects a pawn that is not really attacked and does not care about his real asset: the b2 pawn. Killerman: I actually think that the b-pawn is going to be doomed anyway, but Black must give it up in return for an advantage somewhere else. Kc6 is fine, it is his next two moves that are wrong.
Black doesn't want the b2 pawn? I take it, thank you Killerman: I agree that Black gives up the pawn too easily
Now is black on the defense

I should have tried to win with some Knight moves butpsycologicall y I was already releived to have escaped from a defeat, so my desire is to simplify. Chess endings are a black hole for me,anyway. Killerman: I agree. Nf3 is better but having made such a blunder earlier it's better to settle for the easy draw now
Black's king gets closer to my pawn chain but my pieces are more active and I can defend succesfully, even if it was me that should have looked for a win.

Draw by mutual agreement Killerman: A good battle and a very interesting game to look at. Your main error was 15. Nxe6 which effectively finished your attack and exposed you to a counterattack which should have won for Black. Your defensive plan 21. Na3 was certainly the only way to hold on, but Black would have retained the initiative. I hope you enjoy the review.

Right from the start he has me befuddled! I don't think move 3.. e3 is going to work now. OS: This is the "From Gambit" variant of the Bird. Your opponent is hoping to take you out with an early-game attack based on the open line to your king that f4 created.

e4 pawn is my post for the knights, he ruined it. OS: The theory move is to take the pawn and force black to generate compensation for his material deficit. Your chosen move helps to control e4 and f4, provides a path of development for the dark bishop, and dampens black's attacking spirits so that he doesn't get the initiative he was hoping for.

Well I'm going to do the opening the best I can, and see what happens. OS: You could consider capturing the pawn here, and use attack against his temporarily centralized bishop, perhaps with Nf3, to help gain time to build a strong pawn center. If he defends against Nf3 with d6, Qe7, Nc6, etc, you get d4 in for free and he's forced to uncentralize the bishop.

Got my post back, thats something, I think. OS: I'm not sure what you mean here.. if you're planning to use e4 as a central post, black's possession of a pawn on e5 doesn't actually stop you and can potentially even help you out by essentially serving as a shield against attack along the file

He smells a weak kingside, oh joy :( OS: It's true what he's developed so far, the bishop, points toward your kingside, and that your king is exposed along the e file and somewhat along the e1-h4 diagonal. But you have have time to castle, and your entire army is available to defend if things become somehow troublesome, so I wouldn't call your kingside weak.

I have no experience with attacks from queen side onto my kingside, wonder if I can put up any fight at all? OS: At this point, your opponent arguably has a development edge kingside, as both the two bishops and the queen point there. But, your decision to stubbornly keep a pawn on f4 rather than exchanging earlier has left you in solid control of e5 and g5, so black will find a kingside pawn storm quite difficult to get away with.

Accept for the fact that e3 is missing and d3 shouldn't be there, this set up is familiar to me. OS: you could also consider playing d4 and and Bd3, as your bishop on e2 will have to move again to allow white to fight for the e file

Things are weird, yet seem ok at this point, I'm probably missing something in his plan. Seems like he wants to dominate the diagonals into my kingside, simple enough. OS: his light bishop does more than kingside diagonal domination -- it also exerts influence over the central squares d5 and e4. His dark bishop on e6 looks intimidating, but I don't really like its position. It's blocking his d pawn.

I am thinking that the dark Bishop is going to be a key defensive piece. I learned that from Crafty's analysis in other Bird games. Really awkward way to get it into position though!!! OS: If he brings his rook to e8, you'll be forced to retreat back as redirection to f2 loses your f pawn without compensation. I recommend repositioning your light bishop starting with Ng5. If he challenges with h6, play Bf3 instead of retreating, then either recapture on f3 if he captures, or redeploy the knight to the e4 post if he declines via Nc6. This gives your knight a great square and eliminates his bishop's scorchingly powerful diagonal.
Well that is where I wanted the dark Bishop anyways!!! OS: Black has started to exert his will on the central file.
you might want to consider Nc3 instead, exerting more control over the center

Hoping to mess up his knight movements, also have b4, c4 in mind. OS: yes.. he's overly addicted to keeping his large light diagonal open at any costs, so he moves his knight to a poor square. His plan is probably to redirect to e6 via c7, but I think he'd have better luck with a c5 and d5 pawn duo and the knight on c6

Why did I do this? The Nc4 is where a pawn is supposed to go! What am I attacking? the fork Re1 Bb7 won't work because of Bf4, also there is no post or any sort of back up for that knight. OS: It should be noted that playing c4 instead of Nc4 won't stop him from playing d5. You wouldn't be able to capture due to leaving the d pawn isolated, and if he gets the advance d4 in, the pawn on c4 instead of c2 can no longer challenge, and he'll be left with a potent spatial bind in addition to his material edge
c4 was a dumb place for the knight to be anyways.
That's more like it!

Now it occurs to me that c4 and d3 are totally wrong!!!! My white Bishop is now bad!!!!! I messed up because of the missing f4 pawn and started the V in the wrong place!!! They should be at e3, d4, c4, b4 more or less. My whole plan is shot now, so all I am going to do is react to him. OS: Reacting to him without a counterplan will result in him smashing you. b4, the move you play next, accurately places pressure on the pawn chain that is causing you so much grief. If you can undermine it sufficiently, you'll relieve your defensive task.

I've been practicing defending this king position with crafty, lets see how it works out.... OS: g3 isn't actually necessary here, as the knight defends h2, and if black captures the knight then the other knight will defend h2

Getting the dark bishop to f2 certainly paid off! Thanks Crafty for teaching me that! OS: the primary problem facing you in this position is that the e3 square will remain under black's control despite exchanges.. I recommend holding the bishop on f2 rather than exchanging, and instead play bxc5 to continue your efforts to undermine the a7-d4 pawn chain.

Should I have gotten the white Bishop at some manuvering room. d4 ??????? OS: Your white bishop is ok. Black made an error in recapturing with the pawn. He shut down the e file, and if he's planning to plant a knight on f2 instead, it will take time and give more counterplay to you
Can I grab B column? OS: yes, you can and should. He can recapture with queen, but then Nb3 then Nd4 lets you keep his knight out of f2
What a surprise, I got it!!!! Original plan may not be shot after all.
Just trying to camp things out in his queen side so he will leave my kingside alone.

He is just letting me in so easily? OS: He can't stop you from getting in with your knight.. but I'm not sure what he hopes to accomplish with Rad8. Other than locking your bishop to e2, it doesn't seem to accomplish a useful purpose. The fork that you achieve next move puts a definite question mark on Rad8. If he left the rook alone for a bit, he could redeploy his bishop to h3 via d7
With his light Bishop gone, defending my king will be much easier OS: agreed
To have a rook on the 7th row of an oppenent ranked 400 points higher just feels right some how. What is he thinking?
You might want to consider Ng5 hoping for redeployment to the central e4 square

I have a lot of experience with these attacks, I don't think he has the right pieces with his light bishop gone to succeed. OS: If you didn't have your light bishop, he'd fork your king and rook with his queen. Since you do, his Nh3+ move doesn't help. However, 25 .. Nxd3 appears to win more material for him because 26 Bxd3 Qxd3! and if the rook grabs the knight, the pawn promotion appears unstoppable.
due to black's ability to push the pawn through using the approach I mentioned, I recommend Qc3 or Qa5

he's worried about his knight and a pawn, but Qe6 seems better. When the knights exchange off the queen can nestle in to h3 with check and bring a rook in, white will likely have to sacrifice the exchange to ward off mate.
Qh3+ without support from the e3 pawn is not very menacing, as compared to the earlier line I mentioned
You might want to consider grabbing the knight
Am I missing something???????????? OS: From what I can see, the only purpose to this move is the cheap, and avoidable, trap of skewering the king to the queen..
simply Kd2 gives you a simple extra exchange with more material to come, as the a pawn and knight are not both defensible
I'm not sure who is ahead right now, but a lone queen against a bishop pair and his pawns no threat, seems even up to me, unbelievable!

He is going to try and fork a rook, I'm hopeful he can't do it. OS: he can't. Your mate threat gives you time to not only win the a pawn but also connect the rooks. When they're connected the best he can do is get them both for the queen, at which point your a pawn will win the day

I am no great check mater, but I know this bugs him, two rooks on the seventh rank! Even if I loose now I feel kind of good about this game. OS: even if he somehow manages to get both your h2 and g3 pawn, your connected rooks can get his f7 and h7 pawn, and potentially promote your a pawn..

He initiates the draw, how flattering!!! I'm no idiot, I'll take it! OS: If you want to play for the win instead, get your king over to h3 to get shielding from the checks, redeploying to h1 when you have a chance, then start eating more of his pawns and work your a pawn forward. Your position isn't particularly high risk, so you can play for the win without really worrying about losing due to a really subtle mistake here

Game drawn by repetition OS: In summary, I noticed that most of your analysis was in terms of normal bird-opening plans, even though the structure started to become only semi-birdish early on. You may want to focus on what the pieces and pawns are doing in the game itself as opposed to what they would do if the continuation followed theory. I liked your queenside counter attack, penetrating up along the b file and making him exchange off his powerful light squared bishop. Also, you may want to increase your focus on the center a bit, for example when you played Nh4 instead of Ng5 to seek the e4 post. Given the complexity of the final position, I think that a draw was likely anyway, so accepting it was fine
Hi, whoever you are! This is a great learning opportunity for me - I've never had a game analyzed before.) Killerman: The pleasure is all mine.

As I hardly know any openings, I always start with e4 aiming towards the Italian with c3. Because few games ever turn out Italian, this way I hope to learn other stuff as well as stay alive to the middle game) Killerman: You are in good company as I too prefer e4 to d4 openings. One point to remember is that in most e4 openings White does well to play d4 early in the game to get a grip of the centre.
More common is Nf6 but this sideline has been played before. It's drawback for me is that it is too early to commit the pawn to c5.

You have played well to this position as has Black. Your advantages are that you have slightly better control in the centre and a well placed piece on d5. Black's dark squared bishop is probably his worst placed piece and for this reason alone you should refuse to take the bishop on your next move. Having opted for the exchange your centre becomes weaker and you have freed Black's position making things easier for him.

Maybe I should have kept the knight, as he was sitting quite comfortably in d5? And play something like Bf4 instead?) Killerman:Bf4 would be a good choice but I like c4 holding the centre although lines could transpose.
The position is again about level

I didn't like this move at the time, I thought it rather meek, but couldn't come up with anything more aggressive). Killerman: Your centre is now weaker after the previous exchange. The only aggressive idea I can find is to aim to post your knight on the f5 square. However, as long as Black sets up to play d5 he has nothing to worry about. Bf4 is a good idea together with the idea of stopping d5 with c4 but Black can get a good position although left with a backward d-pawn. Your move Qe2 is a bit passive but, sometimes you do have to wait for something to happen.

An error in judgement by your opponent. Black should of course be looking to play d5 but it is also important to complete some development first. Rfe8 would put pressure on the e-file and still threaten d5. It is a failing of a lot of players that they want to attack in the centre before getting the rooks into play first. Remember this. Rad8 or Rae8 are also good moves.

Both sides have played the last few moves well and the exchanges have led to an interesting position. White has the advantage of the bishop but Black has no clear weaknesses. Usually the plan in endings is to bring your king towards the centre from where it can start to act as an attacking piece. In addition each side also needs to look at entry squares into each other's position. Here Black should try to restrict the movement of White's knight by f6, but, he should also be careful not to put his pawns on dark squares so that the bishop can attack them. He also needs to improve the position of the knight on a5. For White centralising the king is important and I wonder whether it should be looking to drift over to c3 from where it can help the queenside pawns. the alternative is pushing the kingside pawns, that plan will certainly need the support of the king. The danger here is that if either side pushes too quickly, without being prepared, the advantage will immediately go to the other side. This is exactly what happens.
This is too soon. Black's pieces are not in good enough positions to be playing this move. Nc6 is clearly better.
Although this pushes Black's knight to a better square you also improve your own bishop too as it has a better square on c3. Well played.

Too soon. If there is one thing you have done well in this ending it is to improve your pieces. Before playing aggresive moves like c5 it is important to optimise the position of your king so Kf3 is better. In addition to optimising pieces and centralising the king the other maxim to remember is that you usually need to create two weaknesses in an ending to drive home the advantage.
This may be an attempt at a waiting move, but I don't think I would be moving the king away from the centre.
Kf3 is more accurate, keeping the cover on e4 and e3 and allowing Rd7.
Again Kf3 then look to play Rd7

This was surely bad, I didn't realize that black could throw me back to the 3rd rank with g5+. Well, he didn't see it either. Maybe 36.h4 instead?) Killerman: Yes, this is not best. h4 is the correct way to play this after which it is difficult for Black to find a good plan.
Good move
Do you need to do this? Whilst this works I would have played Rd7. Black is in a big mess after that.

te still maintains a clear advantage. I would now look to fix Black's kingside pawns on dark squares before pushing the queenside pawns. The advantage of your centralised king is clearly evident from now on.
h5 would be my choice but this is fine.
I would still play h5 first.
Black had to play axb5 but that would still lose.
Missing a great opportunity to finish the game.
h5 fixing those kingside pawns again may be better
This creates the second weakness and now Black is lost.

After this I stopped concentrating and just waited for him to resign. I've lost many winning games with THAT attitude... But the point is, rest of the game is hardly worth analyzing.) Killerman: I agree the rest is easy.

Black chec kmated Killerman: A nice game and thanks for letting me loose on it. The main learning points which we should all remember are: 1. Before starting an attack get your rooks in play. Black would have done better if he had done this and not played d5 so early. 2. In the middlegame, don't exchange knights for bishops just because bishops are better in the long run. You had a better position before you exchanged on e7 then it became difficult for a while. 3. In endings make sure you position your pieces on their optimum squares. You did this well but did take sometime before finally... 4. Centralise your king in the ending. You did this in the end. Remember the king is an attacking piece in the ending. Well played and I hope you enjoyed the review.
These first two moves are quite good. When your opponent does something funny stick to opening principles.
I would play Be7 or possibly Bd6 here. While you keep your bishop in the center white has d4 here which would allow him to take back some control in the center

While this strengthens the d5 square the same thing could be accomplished with Ne7 or Nf6 developping the knight and preparing to castle kingside at the same time. In the opening it is very important to develop all your pieces as quickly as possible.

Black allows e4 allowing white to take a bite out of the center. While arguably it is a slight improvement for black he would do much better to develop his g8 knight. I also just spoted Qb6 looks decent too but d4 would put a stop to this idea.
Black should be completing development. It;s not that the moves are that bad, it's that they're more appropriate for a middlegame. Black needs his whole army to attack.

Black looks awkward. At some point during the opening it is often a good idea to plan out where you would like your pieces to be. Knights generally are more effective farther up the board making moves like Nf6 and Nc6 more popular. If one of the pawns were not moved and a knight put in its place black would look much more menacing.
I would say Qb6 here. Black could start the attack and mobilize his queen. Black could then castle and make a very strong battery with Rb8
Castling would have been much more effective earlier in the game. Here black castles into the line of white's rook.
This is not generally a move one wants to make. Pawns can only move forward unfortunately and this is one of the king's key defenders. Its value as a defensive piece is much higher.

I see this as a mistake for black. He has overextended his pawns already. Black should still be thinking about his pieces more than his pawns. moving the rook over to b8 would do much for his position.

Often time an in between move can make a big difference in an exchange. Here black should take white's bishop off the board before exchanging pawns, this prevents the subsequent loss of bishop for pawn

Black blocks his rook which is pointed at white's king and freezes his knight in a pin to the king. Moving the king out of the way would leave black in a very good position since he can push the c pawn and simultaneously attack white's queen and the pawn on f2
This move would have been much better if black had not blocked his rook. The king would have been quite safe on h8.
Black could still have taken advantage of the open bfile which is now more enticing due to white's queen being there too.
A good move on first sight. This gives away the queen for nothing since it hangs to the a3 bishop (black can't even get back the bishop since his knight is pinned.
Moving the other knight to allow an attack on f2 would be more effective. Perhaps Nh6? (this of course is ignoring the hanging queen). Or Rb8.

A great move. Even if white takes the f8 rook black will still have a very strong battery aimed at the white king. only the g2 knight prevent the royal fork Nxe3+. Black could still turn things around here
Black is down and he needs a spark. Qxf2+ Kxf2 Nd6+ Might allow black some counterplay. The text move is not that bad though.

Black's King all the time remains on the light squares. This causes him significant trouble since he has no light square bishop. Black could get a free queen with Nxe3+! since white's knight no longer protects the e3 square and the f2 pawn is pinned.

Well here I put this piece and after I realized what I done. Maybe I moved without thinking? I wouldn't say so. the move is a great idea so you clearly thought. You just didn't check to make sure you didn't hang any pieces. Nxe3+ would probably still be your best move.

Yet again, I moved without thinking, I believe this is the beginning of the end for me in this game. When checking to see if a move is good the first thing you should do is look down the diagonols and for rooks and the ranks and files for bishops. Checking what squares your opponents knight's attack will ensure that these things don't happen
The queen taking would be much stronger, it comes with check and takes white's queen off of the same file as black's

Again, It seems I played this game too eagerly. I moved without see'ing the consequences. I have realized every mistake I've made. I wonder, how do I make myself concentrate better? When I started playing I generally only played 10 minute games. This allowed me to think about my moves long enough so that I didn't shamelessly hand pieces. Try longer time controls, 10 minutes will allow you time to think.

I had gone to the bathroom before I started this game, perhaps I flushed my brain down the toilet as well. :-\ You had many good ideas, you just weren't able to see them through to the end. This will come with practice and reviewing your games.

I believe after this point I'm pretty much screwed. But ya know, he(my opponent) played a good game. He did and he didn't. He didn't hang any pieces but he made many mistakes. He left his queen in a deadly fork which I pointed out. The key points you need to work on (other than not hanging your pieces!) is pins and development. To try and prevent hanging pieces pause for 5 or 10 seconds before making any move. Read about one opening (I like the italian game myself) and understand it. You must develop your entire army. You did a slightly better job than your opponent but the pieces didn't seem coordinated and black lost many oppertunities to develop faster. White's play is actually more deplorable. His knight on b1 never moved and it was only in the last four moves that his a1 rook did anything. I don't know about other people but I tend to consider these important pieces and they did nothing at all for white. Try and set your rooks on open files. The b file was begging for a black rook On b8 the whole game. Try and only make 2 or 3 pawn moves before you have all your pieces developped and have castled. DO NOT move the pawns in front of your king unless you find it an important defensive move. It's kind of like abandoning your mother in a bad neighbourhood late at night :) Try and place your rooks and bishops in positions where they point at the king or queen, especially when there are pieces blocking them. Who knows when these pieces might come flying off the board or when your opponent might feel the need to move them. Make a plan. There's a saying in chess; if you don't plan you plan to fail (well not only chess I suppose but what else really matters?.
I sent him a tell to just end my pain and take my bishop, though I anticipate he was already going to do that.

thespiritoft al:This is Stonewall defense.It was played by Botvinnik with success and today Kramnik also uses it sometimes with success.Black gets control of the e4-square and aims for attack but in return his light-squared bishop is bad.
still not sure how to capture thespiritoftal:I believe this is a dubious move.there are lots of other ways to continue here
I believe this is the right way to capture as this somehow frees your light-squared bishop and also opens the e-file for Black.

i dont like the idea of a passed e pawn but neither of a knight there thespiritoftal:I believe this position is about equal the structure seems symettrical and both sides have strong points (e4 for black and e5 for white)also both sides have a bad bishop (c1-bishop and c8-bishop)
there was no need for this move.
opens the a7-g1 diagonal
a very interesting position White's king is weak but he has a queenside pawn majority.Also black has a passed d-pawn.
after all the variations i was thinking i played the Bc4 without really check it and i missed the obviousQxB
Now White is better as d4-pawn is isolated and White has a healthy pawn majority on queenside.

here i wish i knew how i should setup my pawns and where to have my rook thespiritoftal:If you wish I'll be happy to explain : ) your rook is very active on the second rank as it restricts White king.I believe this position can be defended by Black.
you did right changing the a-pawn in return for b-pawn now a draw is nearer.
This is a theoritical drawn position though it requires knowledge.
you mustn't let your opponent fix your pawns because then he can win.
thespiritoftal now you are lost :(
there are some more moves but i was in time trouble thespiritoftal (Ali Polatel) was happy to analyze your game!I hope it will be helpful to you! :) regards,
I played this sicilian variation only once or twice before.
Sveshnikov Sicilian. It was very popular in early '90. GM Leko play it regularly.
White puts Knight on the excellent d5-square. In return Black has the Bishop pair.

I realized after the match that usually is better to push f5 to get rid of the doubled pawns, so the Bishop should stay in c8 for a couple more moves. Furthermore, to try to chase the Nd5 away with ...Ne7?? would lead to Nxf6#!! MR: You're right. Bishop should stay on c8. Better is f5 or Bg7

I feel this move loses time, if my N goes to d4, then he could have replied with c3. Better for white to develop and prepare O-O with Bd3 MR: You completelly missed White's idea with c3. Knight is very passive on a3. Idea is to play Nc2-e3, which reinforces d5.

I thought he was going to take with the N, i feel is better to have a piece in d5 rather than a pawn. d6 is not a weakness anymore MR: exd5 is excellent move. Black has the bishop pair, and White's idea is to block center and to completely shut down your Bishops. He controls f5 with the Knight and Black can't free his game.
with a pawn in d5, this bishop is hopeless in b7. It also helps to protect f5 and prepare f5. MR: Correct assesment about Bishop on b7, but unfortunatelly it's very hard to prepare f5.
White plays for a blockade on f5.
White com plete blockade of center. Your Bishop doesn't have good diagonals. I would say that White has strategitaly won game.
instead of castling, i thought the king was better in the center MR: Correct assesment.

here i felt the position was even, besides the pawn difference in material. However, it was difficult to find a good continuation. MR: I don't agree that position is even, even if we forget that White is pawn up. White is better positionally. The Bh6 is out of play, the Rooks on g-file can't do anything.
As my Rooks could swing easily on the 8th rank, I decided to attack on the queen side. MR: You can't attack on king-side, so there is only 2 choice: to attack on queen-side or to wait and do nothing.
I don't like this move
It was better to simply take the d5 pawn, pinning the Rf3. I preferred to unpin the e5 pawn, and bring the king closer to the quennside pawns
white manages to have a passed pawn on the king side...
I propose the exchange of queens and to open up the b column.
There are 2 weak pawns in White's position.
the final mistake, the rook has no fly square
I was running out of time and I did not count on ...b3 to block the queen side. ..

Hi, this is RoundTower of FICS to annotate your game for the FTL. I have marked my comments with RT: and yours with B:. If you have any questions about this game you can contact me by email or on FICS.

I'm not sure if I should play Ne2 right away. because now black can easily go to bishop e6, Qd2, and trade off my white square bishop on h3. Maybe I can wait on this move to see what my opponent does first? It might be too dangerous to castle right away, for at least two reasons. If I castle right away, Black can do the wing pawn attack by pawn to h5, h4, and hit my king side. Plus he can do the white bishop trade at h3. 4 ... RT: Well, you will probably want to castle eventually. Wherever you castle, your opponent will have the chance to try to launch a direct attack on your king. Particularly after the ultra-passive system you have chosen, you have to expect to spend some of your time defending.
Which is better? Moving the bishop to g4 or e6? RT: g4 looks fine. If you're really worried about Qd7 and Bh3 you can play h3 now.

I think this is not the best move for black. I think moving the pawn to c5 would have been better because it gains space and better control of the center. Plus, the knight could go to c6, and the queen could go to Qe7, preparing the bishop trade on h3. RT: this is probably a matter of taste - Black already has excellent control of the centre, and the c6 pawn can be useful to blunt the g2-bishop which is your only good piece at the moment. c5 would also be fine,
Is this bishop move a bit passive? perhaps he can go to Bd6? RT: I think I would also play Bd6 but I don't know where the bishop would end up. Mostly Black wants to get it out of the way and castle.

I had the decesion of developing my bishop to Bb2 or castling first. I chose Bb2 so it can attack the pawn on e5. I wanted my opponent's knight to land on d7. so he can't develop his queen to d7 and trade off my white square bishop on h3. I waited for him to castle first so he can't do the h-pawn attack on me. now it is probably safe for me to castle on the king side. If I would have castle first on the kingside, it would probably be too dangerous, since he has the opportunity to castle on the queen side and then do the h-pawn attack on me. Was it smart to wait for my opponent to castle first? RT: particularly after playing ...c6, I don't believe your opponent intended to castle queenside. If he had, I expect you would have at least equal chances in a sharp game where you attacked on opposite sides. I find it hard to imagine that you would have tried to castle queenside if he had gone queenside.

This a new opening that is called the Beginner's game. I have gotten good results with this opening. 8 ... RT: This is a load of rubbish especially for a beginner. Only the most blind of players would try to defend it as "hypermodern genius": in fact you should be developing your pieces to reasonable squares and fighting for control of the centre with pieces or pawns. All that said, I remember some players have had success with this game, in particular look at Pein-McShane from Kilkenny some years ago, and I believe one or two early anti-computer experiments based on the idea that the computer would somehow self-destruct if faced with this formation. My advice is not to play it.

good! I wanted black to do that! but then I have another thought. Maybe black can move his knight to Knight to b6 and then movinig his queen to d7 and then trade do the bishop trade on h3. I'm not sure why black didn't do that in the actual game. RT: It's good that you are aware of the idea for Black to exchange bishops on h3/g2, but there are also other possibilities in this position. Don't worry about it overly. Also remember Black has a pawn on e5 which his knight is needed to defend.

I think this move is uncessary for black. It weakens the king side and is a waste of time. I understand that you shouldn't move up the castled king pawns in the opening unless you have a very good reason. RT: I agree, I don't understand the point of this move. However I also don't see how you have even the remotest chance of exploiting this "weakness" and checkmating Black's king from this position.

I think this is a waste of time because it does nothing for my plan. Maybe it does. Maybe it helps me gain space on the queen side. 10 ... RT: I don't know what your plan is, but this move is plausible to support something like b4 followed by nb3. I would prefer to play c4 soon, and with this in mind, a3 is likely to turn out to be weakening.

Which is better, playing c4 first, or moving the rook to c1? I played Rc1 because it will be better placed since I was planning pawn to c4. Plus, the rook is lined up on the same file of black's queen, which is potentially dangerous for black. RT: This shows understanding of Nimzowitsch's idea of potentially open files. Be aware that you may have trouble with a weak pawn on d3 after you play c4 and recapture with a piece. Rc1 is fine, c4 would also be ok.

Black probably didn't play knight to b6 first, like what I thought, because he wanted to gain space on the queenside, i'm assuming. RT: well, your rationale for ...Nb6 was that it alllowed ...Qd7. Black seems to be neglecting this planm and I don't see what else the knight can do on b6.
I am threatening to win a piece. Plus I'm attacking now in the center. RT: a principled move
I think black didn't go knight b6, because he wanted to gain space on the queen side. RT: He could have gone Nc5, however, with complications possibly favouring Black.

I was thinking of going to e4 to keep the center closed. I didn't go to e4 because then my white square bishop will have a closed diagonal and have no future. Is pawn to e4 better? RT: No, e4 leaves you with huge problems with your weak d3 and b3 pawns - the result of playing a3.

Perhaps going to Knight to e4 is better? I didn't want to go to Knight e4 because black would trade my knight for his knight on e4. After the knight trade, the passive knight on d7 would go to f6 and it will be more active there. but then again, I'm kind of cramp on queenside, so maybe Knight to e4 would be good.so I could have more space by the knight trade. RT: best is, as you did, to notice the unprotected pawn on d4 and wonder what could you do to win it. It is probably best not to take immediately, but you can start to attack it and probably force c5, weakening the long diagonal.

Isn't this a bad move for black? Doesn't this make his black bishop bad by putting his pawns on the same color of his bishop? doesn't this weaken the d5 square? Maybe not. It supports the d4 pawn. RT: This move is positionally bad mainly because your Bg2 may now turn into a monster, but it was necessary because you ahd so much pressure on d4. Note that your "good" bishop on b2 is much worse.

I went to a4 because he could go pawn to ruin my pawn structure, by pushing up his pawn to a4. then after the pawns exhange, I would have weak double pawns on the a file. Then he would double up with his rooks and attack those pawns. I wanted to prevent that from happening. Is this prophylactic play? RT: yes, this is prophylactic play, but I can't decide whether or not it is correct given that you give Black a great outpost on b4 from which he can attack d3. I think I'll reserve judgement on this, but it's not a move I would have played. If Black does double up on the a-file, he won't be able to use his rooks elsewhere.

black wanted to get off the diagonal of my white square bishop, because of tactical reasons. but I don't think this is the best square for black's rook. I don't think it does much on b8. I think the rook should have moved to the open file on e8, where it belongs. RT: I agree. Black is now not going to be able to force through b5 at any cost.
I played this move so I can get my rooks connected. My plan here is to get my black square bishop on b2 outside the pawn chain so it can be good on Bf4. RT: excellent plan.
What's black's plan ? RT: I don't know, but he may be trying to keeo you out of f4

I have two things in mind. I might be able to get a good grip on the weak square on d5 with my white square bishop or my knight. I also want to make my undevelop dark square bishop good by playing f4. Is this a good and active plan? RT: Yes, you have understood two of the important things about this position.

I was thinking of going to knight f4 too. since my bishop was undeveloped, I wanted to develop it. Which is better, Bishop to f4 or Knight to f4? RT: Nf4 is probably better for tactical reasons. 20...g5 is quite good for Black, but even better was 20...Bxe2.
This prevents my plan! I didn't see this move coming. Maybe I should have moved the knight first to f4.

I was expecting for black to capture with the rook, not the queen. I thought that so he can double up his rooks faster. Which is better? capturing it with the queen or rook? RT: Again tactical reasons override the positional niceties of whether you should have your queen or rook in front when you double up major pieces. You are now in serious trouble because of the pinned knight. Probably your best here is f3 with a worse position.

This move is losing. It is a blunder. I thought I might have still get a grip on the weak square on d5. I also thought that when the queen trades the two rooks, I can outperform them with my queen. I should have played f3, and I would probably be ok. I also played knight f4 because maybe someday it could prevent the bishop on h3 to prevent mate. I kind of saw this tactic but not completly. RT: yes, a total blunder. Several of the things you got wrong here: 1) you are trading not two rooks for a queen, but two rooks for queen and knight. 2) the rooks would be better than the queen here anyway, with such good control of the e-file 3) You would still be worse after f3 4) how did you think you were going to maintain the knight on f4 to "guard" h3? it is en prise. Nf4 is positionally reasonable only with the idea Nd5. 5) You can't "not completely" see a tactic. Possibly you saw that you would have a discovered attack on the queen and thus gain enough time to play your knight to the good square d5. If you had seen QxR winning material, you couldn't have justified Nf4. I don't mean to be harsh here; as you admitted this move is a blunder, and it throws away a not altogether hopeless position.
I think it's all over now. RT: Yes, in addition to winning all this material Black has some serious mate threats.

This is lost position. I was thinking of queen capturing the pawn on f4, and do some sort of perpectual check but I saw it wouldn't work. RT: correct that it wouldn't work, a good thing to notice though.

After the game, my opponent said that I played very well. thanks. RT: As I said I don't like to be too harsh in my appraisal of a game like this but I cannot bring myself to agree with your opponent. If you are still at the level where you regularly hang pieces, you are to be congratulated for spending 21 moves without a blunder of this sort. However if you have moved past this level, you played this game very poorly almost from the beginning, with occasional flashes of competence. You played passively in the opening, worried about non-existent threats from Black, opened the game too late and ultimately to your disadvantage. Although you were able to speak knowingly of moves as "too passive", "prophylactic play" and "open diagonals" you showed in your moves little understanding of these concepts or willing to put them into practice. Perhaps the best advice I can give you is to ignore all these "advanced" concepts you have learnt and focus on playing actively from move one, getting all your pieces to work and always striving for an active plan. Don't be too discouraged by this review, and I hope you continue to play chess and to review your own games -- this is one of the surest ways to improve. If you would like to speak to me about any aspect of this game or my commentary, or any other matter, you can email me or contact me on FICS.
I played 1.e4 even though my opening repertoire is weak with 1.e4, I just wanted to experiment in a sense. Killerman: I play e4 all the time so experiment with d4!

In bullet I play against this using the exchange variation, but seeing that this is not bullet I decided to try using book, which I am not familiar with. Killerman: The French is my preferred opening with Black, it's a very solid opening and can lead to very dynamic positions with chances forbothsides

Well this is standard, this or 2.d3, I think I should have played 2.d3 and form a KIA because I know more opening theory on that opening. Killerman: If you are familiar with the KIA then I would probably have employed the system, but of course d4 is the normal way to face this opening.
Standard book move, Any other move would be weak in my opinion. Killerman: I agree

I should have exchanged like I do at bullet, seeing here I get into a line I memorized and not actually learned. This later would lead to my loss because he went into a line I didn't know. Killerman: I agree that you should follow lines that you know, but what I would suggest is that you find a line other than the exchange variation. The problem with the exchange variation is that you solve Black's problem over the c8 bishop and he should find no trouble in equalising as he would in other French lines. Your choice of Nc3 is fine as would Nd2 have been, but I think that e5 is the best move to play as I hate facing it. There are plenty of good books and material out there so rather than feed you a lot of lines here have a look around for some material.
I was expecting this, I always receive it.

That's book from my memorization, I was wondering though if he exchanges Bxc3 and Bxc3 doesn't he win the e-pawn? Killerman:I have played against this line a couple of times OTB with good results. Of course, Black can win the pawn on e4, but White should receive enough compensation, due to the time it takes Black to capture it. This makes the line very dangerous for Black if he is not careful. Of course White must follow up in the right way, unfortunately you choose the wrong line.

Oh look what happened, I knew that there was supposed to be a good book line here but I didn't know it. I was looking at the push of d5 as a chance to win a pawn back at g7 with my bishop. I was expecting the line 6. d5 exd5 7. Bxg7. I guess I wasn't paying attention to Nf6. I should have played 6. Qg4, but I am not experienced with openings and I lost my first pawn. Killerman: Good you have identified the best move Qg4 hitting g7 and preparing to castle queenside. On my database a few players have tried and failed when playing d5 too. I give a few sample lines below

Well I looked at two lines dxe6 or Bb5+. With dxe6 he could queen exchange and be up a pawn so I didn't look any more into that line. So I looked at Bb5, and that looked good seeing it checks, forces response, I don't think I looked into it good enough. Killerman: Again you are right. The problem is that even in your line the queens come off. In a way the damage has already been done in this game by missing Qg4 last time.
Bd7 is also fine for Black

That's what I expected but I was thinking the material would be tied up, I guess miscalculation. Killerman: OK, now is a key point in the game and I believe your next move is wrong. You are of course a pawn down and as yet have no compensation other than you do have the two bishops. It is therefore essential that you complete your development as quickly as possible. Attempting to stop your opponent from castling is a very good idea to think of, but we must deal with the issues in our game and the issue is you need all of your pieces in the game. Black must complete his development too which will not be easy as he has some weaknesses of his own i. e. the pawn on e4, the long a1-h8 diagonal and the pin on c6. I suggest Ne2 is best here not just so that you can castle but you can also threaten Ng3 attacking the weak e4 pawn.
Prevents castling.
I captured I could prevent his castle, but I guess the castle factor is relatively useless seeing that there are no queens on the board now.
I thought no big deal, just play c4.

This move caught me by suprise, I was thinking so much about kingside castle that I forgot about queenside. Killerman: As you can see Black has a very nice position without having had to do too much. You have still to complete your development and are still a pawn down. I hope that by playing through the lines above that you can see why this game could have been better for you.
I don't think I had a better move. Killerman: I agree
To prevent Nc4

I didn't even see this coming, and this kind of stuff is happening in my games a lot now, before I rarely faced it. I just came back into chess so do you think that has an influence on it? Killerman: I play a lot of correspondence chess so when I am playing OTB I miss a great deal. I am now just about getting back to how I used to play, but am still a little off my best. As it happens this move is not the best for Black as it seems to waste time. Rxd1 exchanging the rooks seems a better idea. All Black seems to have done here is to encourage c4
See I didn't even notice this block move in the analysis lol. How do I improve I guess my board awareness? Killerman: Practice, practice and more yes you guessed it practice
Attack that stupid e4 pawn. Killerman: Better seems to be Nd4 as the pawn on e4 will always remainweak
Might as wel l go into a endgame, because seeing he is 2100+ I was expecting a draw and getting a good rating boost. Killerman: I agree you still have drawing chances
Moving the king to centre. Killerman: Always a good idea in the ending
Attacking e4. But I noticed that f4 would despise me so I was wondering what I could do about that.
Prevent Ng4, but it doesn't seem to be a big threat now. Killerman: I agree. You ought to improve the position of your bishop with Bc5.

Better now would be h4 and I think that would maybe give me a draw but I cannot tell from this position. I played f4 and lost to the en passant. So here are my questions. I found a few weak points in my game, the opening in which I lost a pawn where if I knew book I would have and probably might've won. I had quite a few miscalculations in my trees of variations which didn't hurt me so bad but they don't benefit me. Also when he pinned my knight with his bishop I was completely shocked and I personally believe I shouldn't be. I didn't even notice the counter move when I analysed it over. My endgame isn't so weak but am I supposed to be able to tell if this position is won/loss/ draw? How do I stop making weak moves like the f4 move here, and how do I increase my awarness of tactical shots by my opponents. When I played 7 months ago, I never faced this problem but now since I came back it won't leave me alone. How do you suppose for me to develop an opening repertoire, should that be a first priority to me? Or should tactics/positional play be. My endgame knowledge is sufficient, I believe but can you tell from this play that I need more work? Why do you think improving my " " should be a first priority? What should be my last priority? What do you think my level of play is for USCF/ FIDE if you can awnser that. How do you think I should go about improving my chess, should I play more, study more? Why do you think I should improve my chess in that way? How is my tactical play, did I avoid any tactical shots or did I miss some? Is my positional play good, or bad and why? What is my style of play, is it aggresive, passive, why? What openings do you recommend from this? Thank you for your time :-) and I hope I didn't hassle you with all of these questions.

There is the weakest move in the game, I was talking to someone and I haven't seen him in months so he caught my awarness, then I looked at the board and saw that I had to move so I did a quick 1 hehe. Killerman: I believe the position is probably lost before this mistake as Black has solved all of his main problems and the pawn on e4 is no longer weak. However, there is no concrete variation here leading to an obvious loss. Nc3 is probably the best move here as h4 would at some point allow f4 weakening the h4 pawn

TheMate resigns Killerman: I have tried to answer most of your questions as I have gone along, but to summarise. It is important to have favourite lines against all of Black's main responses to e4 or d4 and to learn them. In this game Bd2 is not a 'main' line, but that does not matter if the player is familiar with the plans, so a good opening repertoire is essential and a good reference book is too. There is never a good substitute to good practice so if you have been away from the game for a while you will miss things, but this will return. get yourself a good tactics book and studies book and work on some problems each day (and try not to cheat by looking at the answers before you have fully solved each one!!) this will help a lot. As far as this game goes neither of you missed a lot, in fact I would say that Black did not really try anything in this game, he just won the pawn you gave him and swapped off into a won ending. If you look at the lines I have presented then you should be able to see the possibilities you had in the game. As far as being able to tell whether the position was ultimately a drawn position or not is really down to a number of factors. In this game the opposite coloured bishops and the fact that your king was better placed in the ending was a clue to you having drawing chances, but once Black had mobilised his kingside pawns he strated to become better. After f4 of course the game was lost and he was not really tested to prove he was actually better. I hope you enjoy the review and keep on with the practice.

The Sicilian Najdorf Defence. It looks a bit strange, because black doesn`t develop pieces first and leaves white a lot of space. The idea is preventing the white`s pieces from intruding on b5 and preparing ..b5 for a later attack whith a pawn storm on white`s queenside. The Najdorf has been very popular for many decades now and has been played a lot by World Champions like Fischer and Kasparov and many others.
Fischer`s favourite. It seems not as agressive as the common 6. Bg5, but black has to whatch out for sacrifizes on f7.
White can`t sacrifize on f7 any more, but now on e6. 6.. e6 has the other function to make space for the Bishop on f8.
That gives the bishop a safe home. Other ideas are 0-0, Pa3, Bg5, Be3 or Qe2.
Builds up the thread ..b4 and makes space for the Bishop on c8. On the other hand the rook on a8 isn`t very safe now and c6 has become weak.

Fischer`s original plan was castlig short. The move surprised me a little, becaue white could have played that earlier. And black wanted to play Be7 anyway. Kokesh: White is mixing systems, never a good idea in a sharp opening like the Najdorf.

Now white`s plan is clear: Castling at the queenside and attack blacks`s King whith the officiers - not whith a pawn storm. It is a rather old plan but not a bad one. The main thread at the moment is 10.e5 and Nf6 and Ra8 are attacked. Kokesh: In other lines this move is more reasonable than it is here, and Black doesn't have to try the risky 9. ... Nbd7 10. e5 dxe5 11. Qxa8 exd4 (with great compensation) in order to prove it. Even 9. ... Bb7 makes a lot of sense.
It seemed to me more agressive than Qc7, because the knight on d4 is beeing attacked. On the other hand white wanted to castle anyway. Kokesh: Both moves are reasonable.
The race for the Kings has been started!

Since white doesn`t plan a pawn storm he wants to activate all of his pieces, I guess. Kokesh: Who knows what White is doing. He's playing planlessly, centralizing the rook because it might be good eventually. Here it's just a waste of time.
Now the queen is indirectly threatened.

Now the queen is safe again and maybe she will build up some threads on h7. Kokesh: For White to set up threats on h7, he will need a knight on g5, a bishop on the b1-h7 diagonal, or a second heavy piece on the h-file. None of these ideas seem very likely. My guess is that White is planning to sac on e6, but there isn't any danger to Black yet.

Black, too, is developed completely. Kokesh: Black is now exposed to one of the problems with having the queen on b6; it doesn't protect anything there. Better is 12. ... Qc7, protecting against the tactic that White misses.

The knight needed support - and now black`s queen is beeing threatened. Kokesh: White missed 13. Nxc6 when Black's recapture allows 14. Bxe6 fxe6 15. Qxe6+, picking up the Be7 two pawns to the good. True, Black can regain at least one pawn by capturing on f2 (if he has played 13. ... Bxc6), but White definitely has an advantage.
The direct Qc7 was possible here. But I felt better after the position was a bit more clear. White could always try a sacrifize on e6. Kokesh: Both moves are fine.
Seems like he chances his plan - or he doesn`t know how to continue his attack. I liked the move - for black.
The knight leaves, before 16.g5 will make him.

That is an interesting pawn sacrifize. Taking the pawn seems to be dangerous, because white can move his knight near the black King and attack the bishop on e4 at the same time. Kokesh: I don't think that Black has anything to fear after 16. ... Bxe4 17. Nf4 Bg6 (or even 17. ... e5).
Now black has build up a serious thread against the white King. I liked black`s position much better now. I felt a win was possible.
Since black can play Bc2: whith check now taking the pawn seems to be good for black.
Here I expected the knight to move back to c3.

Another mistake and the critical move in this game. It gives black the good chance 19..Nc5! which would have made white`s chances smaller. I have seen that move, too, but something happened around me and I lost concentration. I liked my position up to that moment, but after that I made one mistake after the other. The other thing is that I felt I had a very fine position against a strong player and just had to win. My opponent felt unhappy at this moment as I have heard later. He thought I would win. Kokesh: There is nothing wrong with 19. Nf4. Slower moves allow Black to win with 19. ... a4.
There is absolutely nothing wrong with this move either.
I can`t see why I played that move anymore. Kokesh: After 21. ... Bxd5, I think Black is doing just fine. White will only have a pawn for his piece. 22. Rxe7 Be6 looks particularly good for Black.
22. ... Bb4 is at least as good.
Missing the last chance.
The game is over now.
Knoecken ran out of time

I've never seen this move here before, and it doesn't look sound to me. After 4. exd5 Nxd5 5. Nxe5, White's extra central pawn is huge. Black can try to temporize by protecting e5, for instance, 4. ... Qd6, but then White simply plays 5. Bc4 and is better. In general, when Black wants to avoid the sterile symmetry of 3. ... Nc6, 3. ... Bb4 is considered the standard.
5. exd5 is still good.
Closing the center like this is usually a bad idea. See below.
This is a really terrible square for the knight. White should retreat the knight to b1 and bring it back into the action with Nbd2.

So we have a King's Indian-type pawn structure. However, Black's pawn on c7 should really be on c5, so that Black would have a pawn break on c4. On the other hand, White's Nd1 is misplaced, and the Qe7 is also not well-placed here. This position is probably roughly equal.
The Black king might belong here, but then again, it might not. Black might consider 9. ... h6 (stopping Bg5) and/or 10. ... Bh3 before commiting his King to the queenside.
I needed to create some space. Kokesh: This sacrifice is way too optimistic. With regard to the space comment, Black has more central space, so he is really not in any danger of being squashed.
This is an indication of how unrealistic Black's sacrifice was. If Black doesn't show something soon, White's piece will count much more in the coming middlegame than Black's pawns.
Opening central lines and creating a weakness on d3. There's no reason for this. White should simply castle and prepare for the f2-f4 pawn break.

This is a really clumsy defense of d3. Keeping Black from achieving three connected passed (but yet impotent) pawns on the queenside makes sense, but maybe White should have simply played 15. O-O Qxd3 16. Qxd3 Rxd3 17. Nxe5, simplifying.

I am unsure about this move. Should I have made more preparations before commencing my attack? Would 15...Nxf2 have been better to enable capture of d3? Kokesh: After 15. ... Nxf2 16. Nxf2 Bxf2 17. Nxe5!, White is completely winning. Not that 15. ... Bc4 causes White any problems either.
I did not know what to do and consequently ran out of time. Kokesh: There isn't much to do here. Black is and has been busted since move 10.
Black ran out of time

I searched for this very exact position in my ChessBase (over 2 million games). Do you know what the result was? "No games found!". Did you find a theoretical novelty? Did you go thru a weak variation? The second is the correct one, IMHO. What White can do in this position? The first and only move I see is 9.cxd5, forcing Black to suffer all the game with an isolated pawn in d5, no matter what Black can answer to cxd5 (9...,cxd4 10. Nxd4!). You will think. "Is that all? I was expecting a very deep positional opinion...". Well, the problem is that the isolani in this position is the "main course", is the element on which the game will develop itself. Other elements become less important. For my personal taste, the plan with 8....c6 followed by Nbd7, dxc4 and e5 would have been preferable. Note that the queen in e7 helps this Black's push.

This is not a mistake, but I think that the isolani creation with cxd5 and dxc5 would have given White a clear plus. To have a clear target helps to find a plan! Furthermore, Bd3 looks like a waste of time because gives Black the chance to avoid the isolani creation with dxc4! White of course must recapture on c4 with the bishop, that spend two tempo to go to c4!
This is uncoerent. Why not Nc6? The only good point of c5 is the nice post for your knight created in c6.

Here's where I saddled myself with the isolated pawn that eventually ruined me. I have the option of cxd4 ____ dxc4, instead of b6. Is that preferable? Bracco: Yes! I mean that b6 itself is not a bad move at all, but IMHO liquidating the center was better. However, there are plenty of games in which one side allow the other to create the two isolated pawns in c5 and d5 (or c4 and d4 for White). If you were aiming to this structure the move 10...b6 fits very well. It's a matter of taste, two proud pawns versus open lines. In such cases the balance of the games generally favours the better developed colour - in this game Black seems a little bit late (Bishop still in c8, etc.).

For me, the whole idea here was to prevent e4, to connect the rooks, and to get the bishop doing something... but now that I look at this move, it looks ugly.Bracco: It may look ugly, but what else Black could play? Bb7 has some plus: connecting rooks, control e4 not only to avoid the white push, even to place a Black Knight! Whe one has the isolani (or the two pawns) the structural disadvantage must be compensated with a better piece activity, and a Knight in e4 looks active!

Only possible reason I could see that he played Rac1 is to open the c-file fully, perhaps through dxc5 ____ b4. I wanted to make the c-file a little less tempting, and I _really_ didn't think he'd play his next move. Bracco: The rooks must occupy the open and semi-open lines! There are no immediate threats, but if Blacks plays inaccurately it might arise....

I thought Nb5 was just a waste of time, though perhaps he did it for the simple purpose of giving himself a target on a6 in the future? Anyway, I added more pressure on e4. At this point I think I had the initiative and didn't have to respond to a particular threat, so I had to come up with a plan... and protecting e4 was all I had. :::shrugs:: : Bracco: I agree with you regarding Nb5, looks like a waste of time. I disagree when you say you've the initiative. IMHO the position is even with chances for both sides. White has just wasted time, Black has the Knight in d7 poorly placed. Had it been in c6, a6 was unnecessary, and the Knight could have a future in a5, aiming for b3 or c4!

Eh, yes... back over the notes that I made during the game, I felt I had the options c4, b5, cxd4, and a6, which I discarded because the knight could move back in. I felt that I had to respond to Bxa6, but rather than doing it by defending, I tried to attack, and I did forsee that I would have to play Nc5, but nothing much further than that... I shouldn't have played that move, should I?

Again trying to respond to a threat without becoming fully defensive. I think, though, that my possible response, nxn, pxn, qxq, rxq, rxr, nxr is bad for my position, because it trades off pieces, a bad thing to do with an isolani on the board, right? Bracco: Definitely. Despite its appearance, Ne6 is a defensive move. Black is going to be cramped. Any piece trade favours White
Naively, 'maybe I can force a trade and it won't be isolated anymore.'

He's obviously going after the pawn so I'm going to try to protect it... by trading more pieces off. After this, I feel that I lost control of the game, though it probably happened earlier. Lost heart in the endgame, and I had around 2 mins. left at this point, so it's definitely lost.
The position was still very hard to win for white. There is only one weakness in black position, and in such cases a passive defense may lead to a draw. Never give up!

What can we say about this game? Black could avoid to created an isolani, but he missed this chance. White ignored this opportunity for a while, then he did, he wasted some tempo and due to inaccuracy of Black instead of own brilliant play had the upper hand. The bigger error I see in Black plan was to play for prevent White threats instead of seeking initiative. In position with isolani the initiative is fundamental. That's all!
