To counter d4xf3 by black
Did I develop my Queen too early? Breder: No, otherwise the move f4-f3 would have been much more stronger.
Would Nd2 have been better as f3 proves to be a problem? Breder: No, the Nc3 must protect the e2 sqare (see variation) .
I was not expecting the Queen exchange
I thought I had better activate my rook.
I thought at this stage that I was in a reasonable position.
I felt I had the better position so I opted for the rook exchange.
I did not see that coming.
I know I have lost my bishop so I started to advance my pawns.
White checkmated

White loses time in the opening. Bracco: The french defense has been invented to avoid any risk along the diagonal c4-f7. White probably was still new to this defence, and thus played the bishop in a "double King pawn" fashion
A logical and strong move. Black put a pawn in the center with tempo.

This is a bad placement for the bishop because it blocks the "d" pawn. Better would have been Bb3. The active move Bb5-check allow Black two interesting possibilities: 1) to strenghten the center with c6 and forcing the bishop to further retreat 2) to propose the trade of bishops with Bd7. Should White capture in d7, Black goes ahead in development with Nxd7!
Black has already a small advantage.

Wasn't sure whether to play Nc6. I would have a stronger center, but doubled pawns. Bracco: This is the best option, in my opinion. As noted before, White must play another move with the bishop, while black has developed a piece.
The recapture with the queen would have been preferable. The knight has a wonderful square in c6, not to mention the chance to castle queenside once freed up the squares "b8" and "d8"
Here the push in d4 looks more active.

Taking a gr eater part of the center. Bracco: This move looks somewhat premature here. Generally speaking, the center pawns configuration should not be changed unless a clear goal is achieved. In this position the move "d4" does not improve in any way Black's position. The pawns center was more solid before, with the two pawns in d5 and c5 (squares b4-c4-d4-e4 controlled). The only purpose that I can see for this move is to free up a wonderful square in c4 for the White Knight :-)

Removing the pin. Bracco: The knight was not pinned. I think it was more urgent to put a Rook in the "e" column in order to meet the pressure that White is going to increase in this line. Please note how the black position is somewhat crampy after having recaptured in d7 with the knight. The "e7" square need protection, and the Queen sooner or later must move to allow rooks connection. Had the knight be placed in c6 and the Queen in d7, black would have completed satisfactorily his development.
Planning for b5 Bracco: Looks like a waste of time. The "e" line was a priority. Black was still in time to repost his knights and to place a rook in e8

Was unsure of playing b5 because I was scared of 16.Nd6, looking back though it probably nothing. Bracco: Your move "put a question" to the Knight in c4 and clean up a bit the quite messed position of the black knights. Nf6 was also playable, see the variation.
To stop Ne5. Bracco: Rfe8 was more simple. The "e" file is the only one opened in this position, and black cannot allow white to dominate it.
Putting pressure on c2. Bracco: Still in time for Rfe8

Was scared of Knight moving to g5 but I think this move might have wasted time. Bracco: You're right, looks a waste of time. Better would have been Nd5!, controlling "e7" and aiming for a wonderful outpost in"c3"
White is slightly preferable here
Black was still in time for Nd5
Not sure w White had in mind here (maybe Rxf7 Rxf7, Qxa8) Bracco: You're probably right about white's thoughts. maybe he simply forgot the pawn in "c2". A good move would have been Ne5

Was very uncertain of what move to play here. Bracco: For an "human" point of view, black is a pawn up but has a position very unconfortable. Fritz keeps calm and proposes Qd6 (see variation): Your move loses the exchange, but black remains a pawn up and force the white rook to a passive position in order to protect the "d3" pawn
Very bad posistion for me.

Altho ught I would have played that way in a serious game, this move looks too much optimistic. White msut keep his pawn in d3. Shouldn't he play that way, black can create some serious threats with his advanced and passed pawns. White should have played Rd2, followed by Rd1, Kf1, Ke2 and Kd2: now the rook is free and White can try to exploit its strenght.
The decisive mistake. White must capture one of the two free pawns. They are too dangerous.
And by pure luck...I queen. Bracco: You grabbed the only chance that an optimistic white left you. Well done! Never give up too early! The rest of the game has nothing to say.
wearenothomeyet resigns
I haven't seen this in a long time. It's considered premature to force these pawn exchanges because White gets quicker development.
No, this sacrifice just cannot be sound! But it turned out to be quite poisonous; black did get some compensation for the pawn. At least with some help from white...
e3 looks good to me. I'd only consider Nb1-c3 as a major alternative.
I like Be2 as it leaves Qd1 in contact with pawn d4.

I would have liked to keep the pawn on d4 but did not find (and do not find now) an acceptable way to protect this pawn forever. So I tend to think that this exchange had to be done sooner or later. MH: Ideally you'd like a2-a3, b2-b4, Bc1-b2. But, ...c5-c4 would cramp White. The alternative b2-b3, Bc1-b2 isn't bad, but b3 would hinder Qd1 even more. So, your method of trading queens first seems preferable.

Possible but not necessary. The reason to exchange the queens was not merely the fact that I was a pawn up. I was planning to develop the black-squared bishop to b2 and I couldn't find any role for my Queen - it would fall under attack on a4, h4, or even on c2. So getting rid of this troublesome piece seemed logical. Now, however, I think that sequence a2-a3, b2-b4, Bc1-b2 and Qd1-b3 (or c2) was better than this exchange, as after the text I was faced with some trouble with weak d2. During the game, I could not decide whether the correct way to place the queenside pawns was a2, b3 or a3, b4 (assuming that the bishop was to be developed on b2) ; the latter would have prevented black playing b7-b5-b4 but enabled a6-a5, leaving white with weak b-pawn instead. MH: Qd1 has few squares, so trading it limits the damage Black's queen and rooks might do. A Black rook at d8 would be very dangerous to White's Qd1.
This might be going a little too far. Some time you'll need to develop Bc1 and Ra1. Now is probably the time.

Now this was a clear mistake; the proper square for this bishop was c2. MH: I don't see that at all. Bc2 is a square I'd choose for offensive purposes, but in this position Black has the better pieces and White is defending. Be2 is less exposed and defends Nf3.
This move had to be done sooner or later; otherwise, after the bishop left c1, black could have played Be6-g4xf3, bringing the dreaded black rook to d2.

This was one reason why the white-squared bishop should not have been where it was. However, in given situation, retreating the knight to b1 (with b2-b3 and Nb1-d2-c4 in mind) would probably have been better than placing it on the ramp.
Black has achieved nothing during White's late development. After one or two more good moves I'd say White's well on his way to victory.
Now that Black has no threats and White is developed it's time for such offensive placements.

Ouch! Now I finally understood why bringing the king to center might not have been very good idea. Before moving the knight from f3, white has to decide what to do with the pawn on g2. Move it, what else? MH: If you could reposition Na4 or trade off dark-square bishops, so Na4 could move to either b6 or c5, then you'd be more than half the way to victory. As it is you can play Bb2-a1, Na4-b2-c4 or you can aim to advance king-side pawns to push Black's pieces back a bit.

I spent just a few seconds deciding this move; right after I had made it, I thought something like this: "Hmm, my kingside pawn chain would be very good for a rook ending. Why isn't it so good in minor piece endings? Well, because there are lots of holes for knights. Or a bishop. BISHOP!!! Oh holy Caissa, did I blunder away my knight??" While the text, surprisingly enough, did not have to lose, it was a plain suicide attempt and thus deserves to be called a blunder.

Of course. Now how to unpin the poor knight before it gets lost? The only way to achieve this was defending it with the white-squared bishop and then getting the king out of e2. And it had to be done quickly, before black would manage to play Nd6-f7-e5.
I did not like offering a bishop for a knight in an open position but I could not see anything else to avoid immediate defeat.

Enables e3-e4 and Ke2-e3, freeing the knight. But it had been really close and I do not believe that white had much chance to win this position. MH: White was very close to winning. It just takes a bit more consistent good play to be able to convert one measly pawn.

There was no reason to give away the a-pawn. And I saw it. But I also saw some promising complications (which I could not calculate to the end) involving tha hard-to-catch passed c-pawn. And I had had the move Nf3-d4 in my mind for so long that I felt obliged to do it.. . And after having escaped an immediate loss, I was simply a bit nervous and adventureous.

Now white could get back the sacrificed piece but then he'd have to spend lot of time getting rid of the a- and b-pawns, while black could use this time to eat up white's entire kingside. Time to give up. MH: Your notes reflect perfectly the kind of talk I've heard from 1700 players. Your thinking is a bit scattered. Your position assessments are sometimes good, but often terribly wrong. You struggle to find your way through a maze of variations and surprise moves when a stronger player sees simplicity. I suggest you do your position assessments more carefully and try to get a very clear idea of what you want to do with the position. Only then check variations and tactical shots. Choose your move or the move-sequence carefully, but have faith in your idea. In this game your handling of the early position (after 1. d4 d5 2. c4 c5) is indicative of this confusion and lack of order in your approach. Recollect how you faced that position. Did you think Black's move was a mistake? A bluff? A good move? Did you try to refute it or just let it go unnoticed? This initial feeling about a position determines a lot of how you handle it. Recollect how you felt about the position after the queen trade. Did you feel confident it was only a matter of technique to win or did you have great doubt about whether White was better? How about after Bc1-b2? Could you not feel White was clearly better? How did those feelings inspire you to choose this or that plan? Position assessment has to be accurate to lead you to the right idea (to play next). Recollect what you thought about the position when you played g2-g3? How many different moves or ways of mobilizing the king-side did you consider? Having a good idea also requires you to carry it out (execute it) effectively. You were a little weak on piece activity: when you played h2-h3 and neglected Bc1 and Ra1. As you assess positions you should consider piece activity a bit more important. Feel free to e-mail to me if you have any more questions about the game or my notes.
I was told that d4 is better, but I prefer this one. PTFN: Neither 4.O-O nor 4.d4 is in itself better than the other, so the choice depends on the player's favourite. If 4.d4 see the variation

This is not a good idea for black after white's castling. Black's refutation against white's Bxc6 dxc6 Nxe5 winning a pawn is based on the double attack Qd4, which fails when white has already castled: Nf3 Qxe4?? Re1 wins the Queen. Normal is 4.Nxe4
Maybe d4 would be better? PTFN: Your actual choice was correct. 7.Nf3 preserves the extra pawn, whereas 7.d4 leads to a big exchange which allows black to equalize the position:
I think I that e5 would win a piece, but I didn't play it because n the game I thought it was wrong. This must be my big opportunity, but I missed it...
I felt silly when I saw that I had the chance to win a piece TWO times, but I missed it! Grrrr...
I thought that I would eat the B with my Q, but then I suddenly realised that I would lose my P at e4! PTFN: Qd3 wouldn't help c3, but at least it got rid of the pin on d1-h5 diagonal.
It seems black should play the following variation concerning white's prospect of attack on the kingside:
Bg5 is stronger:
It seems you would have reserved some chances by not exchanging the knights:
Again Bg5 is better as it saves a pawn for you without the black knight escaping.
What did you think when making this move? Have you considered other possibilities like the one following?
The game is in a dead draw now.
and after that I offered a draw,which she accepted

From the game it reflects you are at the beginning level. You prove to be aware of some basic tactics by figuring out the e5 fork, but you still need a lot of practice to get yourself more familiar with general play of chess. Doing some not-so-complicated exercises may help, too. And I would like to give you a piece of special advice related to this game: Avoid the habit of playing "straight lines," such as immediate recapture after capture, creating first-pulse threats, and so on. As the 19th move, I believe you could have figured "Bg5" out within a little more investigation if you had not played "exf6". And 25.Rb7? is just too easy-to-be-defeated to be a threat, moreover you could have got chances by not exchanging major pieces. That's all. Just play more and you ARE to improve. Good luck!

Why did he play that? Althought I'm not an expert of this opening at all, I know for sure that the move "a6" by Black has several purposes in the Sicilian: to keep away a White Knight from "b5"(intending to play e7-e5), or preparing an enlarged Fianchetto (b7-b5, eventually followed by Bc8-b7 and maybe b5-b4), or simply confuse the opponent with the move order, aiming at a particular variation reached later.
I think he had the ability to play Nxe4 and after Nxe4 d5 The well known fork-trick here doesn't work. See the following variation.

Was that a bit pathetic? I can't see anything wrong with this move. It's a normal developing move that can be followed by d7-d6, 0-0, b7-b5 etc., reaching positions that have been reported thousand of times in books
I think I have a better development than he has The Black position is not so bad, White as a little space advantage and nothingmore

If he wanted to move the B to b4 he could have done it earlier.He missed a tempo I totally agree. In addition, this move allows White to fix a weakness of the Black structure: the hole "d6". That's why in my opinion the move "d7-d6" at this stage would have been much better. Look at the variation.
Not an mistake, but "e4-e5" was stronger. See the variation below
Both useles and piece-losing Correct. An escape-square for the "h5" Knight should have been created, for instance with "g7-g6"
Hey man,where does that little piece goes?
I now have a great attack!
another big mistake in a sad position. Black could have resigned at this point In view of Qxf5!! Your move is also good
When I made that move, I felt great! He can resign now...
After the game, my opponent told me that he thought that I couldn't take the Rc7. But it isacheck! Sadly for him, i't's a check. The game has nothing else tosay
Things are easy now...
Threatening Qe8 and after Bf8 Ne6
As I saw he didn't want to resign, I made that move to exchange the Queens
And that game comes to an end...

I am fairly competent with the sicilian although I do have more trouble than with more traditional e4 openings, on this move I normally protect the knight with Be3. In this case I retreated to try and get a hole in the Kingside's darksquares Holzi: Well, if black does actually play in the risky way he picks in the game you get just that, but of course black could just keep on playing "normally".
This is one of the extra options you allow black by playing 6.Nb3, but this move is also rather double-edged for black, because you get the pair of bishops.

I made this move to allow castle kingside since black could easily rush me since I'm commited to either it or the center with my open queenside. I like how taking the bishop will solidify my pawn structure. Holzi: Preparing to castle certainly makes a lot of sense here, Bd3 does that and protects the e4 pawn at the same time. On the other hand the bishop isn't terribly active on d3, for that reason one might at least consider the alternatives.

I made this move in order to hold my center. Without the darksquare bishop and black's queen being fenced in, especially on the kingside dark squares, I thought this would be a way to hold the center. Holzi: While it's certainly not a "real" mistake, I don't think I like this move too much, it seems the bishop on d3 gets a bit blocked in, white ends up having another weakness in his pawn structure (the pawn e4) and does not actually get to use the f-file.
Here I must say that I would probably prefer the black pieces due to the rather akward looking white pawn structure and the somewhat inactive bishop on d3.

I felt this was forced since Be2 leads to trading down and with my pawn structure I decided this was decidedly bad. Holzi: Your decision was entirely correct, not only from a strategic point of view, but also because of the immediate tactical problems involved with 11.Be2 (see following variation).

I wasn't sure if this move was aggressive or an attempt to prepare to castle on the queenside. Probably both I suppose. Holzi: Castling queenside has to be rather suicidal for black (half-open b-file, a white bishop about to turn up on e3, etc.), unless he can prepare sufficient counter chances first (that would probably require opening a few lines on the kingside - e.g. the g-file). I would guess black mostly meant to make castling difficult for white. However you found a good plan (Qf4 followed by Be3) to counter that, so quite possibly black should have done something else (e.g. 0-0 or playing the somewhat more solid move Qc7 or possibly Ne5).

This move looked quite strong. It threatens the bishop since e5 can easily deflect the knight on f6. I knew black would spot this but I felt black had no strong response to this move while I'd be able to play Be3, allowing castling on the kingside without trading off the queens. I still feel black would be better off without them. Holzi: I agree. The black queen on b6 turns out to be rather useless and black would probably very happy to enter an endgame at this point.
As you said, it's quite difficult to find a good square for this bishop, so quite possibly one should have considered alternatives.

The real plan with Qf4. Black's queen is in what looks to me like a bad state while I am taking control of the dark squares. Holzi: Yes, your control over the dark squares is quite strong, which was a risk black had to be willing to take when he played Bxc3. It seems like he didn't play entirely accurately after that and hence didn't get enough compensation for the pair of bishops he surrendered to you.

I saw this move when I originally played Qf4. I wasn't too worried about it then, and I still didn't feel it was a very strong move for black. Looking at black's position it's clear it is. There were manyinteresting exchanges, I didn't see anything other than being able to get pawns on e4 and d4 while exchanging queens. Bxb6 Nxf4 Bd4 Nxd4 cxd4. This may have been better, perhaps my thirst for blood got the best of me, but I still liked my attacking chances. Holzi: The move you played in the game looks very sensible. f2 is a good square for the queen and makes Nh5 look a bit pointless.

I just wanted to plant a thorn in black's queenside. If black wanted to quickly rid himself of this knight he would have to play b6. I was thinking ...b6 Nxe6 fxe6 Bb5. This would eliminate any thoughts of going to the queenside. I also Was thinking about Rb1. I think this move was too agressive in retrospect. Rb1 or 0-0 may very well have been stronger since I could make this move later with at least the same oomph.
Following my plan of dominating the dark squares and pinning the knight. The intermediate move Nxe6 was tempting but I decided I'dwait until it was forced. I felt I was winning here.
This move was a blunder by your opponent, because you can actually remove your queen from f2 with tempo and then the rook on h8 will actually be lost.

I wanted some clout on f4. I didn't want to play Qe2 and allow Nf4 allowing black to move back towards the center. Holzi: Here you could have exploited the rather dubious arrangement of the black pieces + the fact that his king has remained in the centre for too long. If one looks at the position one spots rather immediately that the black setup looks rather suspicious, so it's quite possibly a good idea to look for a tactical solution. In the game black gets away with his play and has a rather pleasant position after casteling on the next move.

Finally black castles and now he actually enjoys a quite good and active position. Black's main advantage however is the white pawn structure and the fact that it's quite difficult to find a good place for white's king.

I think this was my dumbest move of the game. I wanted to expel these knights but missed Qh3. I feel that even if this move was not possible 0-0 was still probably better. Holzi: 0-0 isn't possible for white here (Qxh2#) and castling queenside isn't particularly feasible either. As you say getting rid of the knight on g4 would be extremely useful for white. Since h3 doesn't look like the ideal way of going about that, Be2 looks logical.

I want a piece of the f4 square (this square keeps popping up :( ). I want to play Rf3 expelling the queen to distant land away from the king. My other plan which I elected not to do since I like my king's position was to run over to the queenside in a makeshift castle. Holzi: It's quite difficult to say what white should do at the moment and one of the the most obvious ways of improving the white position is indeed to play 20.Rf1. The whole position is still quite double-edged and both sides definitely still have chances.
Why not continue with the plan? Holzi: Indeed.

Eve n if it looks tempting to threaten things like Qh1+ it would have been better to put the queen on a safe square such as c7. The queen on h2 enables white to play g2-g4 later at the same time forcing the exchange of queens.

I think this was a big mistake. I was somewhat worried about Bxa2 and was thinking of this bishop as a good defensive piece when it's more like a crack head. This move also forces the capture fxd6 which addsprotection to the knight and brings black's rook back to life. Live and learn I suppose... Holzi: I'm not so sure this was wrong, after all finally black also gets a weakness, even if he gets the f-file for it. Also you don't loose any time moving the knight about - if you e.g. retreated it to b3, then black could immediately hop in g3 with his knight, now seriously threatening Qh1+, because he now has f1 under control.

In fairness I was running somewhat low on time here. I was also planning to sac my bishop with Bxh6. I still think this had some punch to it. This also blocked black's queen. I think the king run would have probably been a good preparation move, still not really sure though.
I was torn between this and Kc1. I was also looking at Qh6 (the original plan for making the move e5) but thought Qh1+ Rf1 Rxf1+ Bxf1 Qxf1+ looked fairly bleak for white.

White's king has a nice spot on the B2 square, safe from all the fireworks on the kingside (whoever would have predicted this would be the safe side from the first four moves?). Holzi: The white king might or might not be safe there, but it costs a lot of time to even get him there and to be quite honest I'm not entirely sure white will be entirely happy in the middlegame when his king will probably easier to attack than black's king behind a still nearly intact pawn structure.
It looked to me like my original plan of a strong center was coming true. Even now I still like this move.

Somethingher e: This was actually a shock to me. Seeing a decent looking endgame and no good squares for the queen I decided why not trade. Holzi: Well, you are quite right about no good square for the queen, but the endgame doesn't look especially appealing to me (considering that you are a pawn down).

Wanting to win the doubled pawn while strengthening my central position Holzi: I cannot see how you could (feasibly) win any of the black e-pawns. 28.Be4 also results in some annoying possibilities for black (like sending a knight to c4). A lot of the white problems stem from the brilliant position of the black knight on d5, which makes moves like 28...Nge3 etc. possible in the first place.
While threatening the pawn on h3 this doesn't really address white's chances on the queenside at all. Getting a knight to c4 on the other hand certainly would.
Black's knight on b4 seems rather inactive, so I'm not sure it's an especially good idea to force it onto better squares.

Somethingh ere: Trying to win tempo moves. Here is where I think I first dropped the ball. Rf1 hoping for more trading seems good since my bishops are so strong. I have very little experience with this type of endgame. Holzi: Now the knight on a6 keeps you from playing c4-c5 for the moment. Trading the rooks would help you, especially since your rook is currently totally inactive, his rook is quite strong and his knight have slight problems with finding good outposts - however there are several problems with Rf1, firstly the unprotected pawn on h3 (the pawn by itself might not be decisive, but black would getting two free pawns on the h and g-file, which could be very dangerous) and secondly (something your opponent missed later in the game) the check Nf4-d3+ leaving your rook en prise. But you definitely need to do something with your rook soon, because you cannot afford to have it out of play.

I am trying to trap his knight Holzi: If you have the time to do so, you should check whether there is any real hope of doing so, I don't see that here. As it turns out (though it's not easy to spot) this move gives another pawn away.
Black plays the "obvious" move, but could have won a pawn instead.
A blunder. Rh1 or h4 had to be played - you have to protect the h-pawn, additionally your move allows the annoying Nd3+.

As you pointed out earlier the bishops get extremly strong after trading the rooks and as a result white gets some counter chances on the queenside. In fact it's not entirely clear whether even this second still ensures black's victory... Winning the exchange with the other interesting knight move however would have done so.
The trade

Doesn't give black much counter play, but white's passed pawn together with his bishops seem quite impressive anyway. One of black's main problems is that white can usually quite easily sacrifice a bishop for an advandced passed pawn, but black finds it much more difficult to do the same with one of his knights.
The way you keep black's pawns from advancing looks very good. Simply continuing pushing the a-pawn is another obvious choice.
is a rather silly move, I don't see any reason why black would really want to play it, certainly it throws away a possible drawing chance.

34 seconds left and I felt I need a piece to win in that length of time. I am aware this is a bad move ;-) I talked to black (Ashland) the game and he said he was going to sac his g pawn. I am not sure how this would have turned out but I still like white's chances. I still feel I let victory slip away. When I was in good position I made poor moves since I couldn't find good ones. Holzi: You are right, especially in the endgame you had a winning position for quite a long time. Instead of 43. Ba6 you could have continued to do so with e.g. Be3.

somethinghere resigns Holzi: This was a rather complicated and unbalanced game, the type of position that arises from dynamic openings like the sicillian. You certainly haven't lost this game, because your opponent played much better than you, but rather because he played reasonably well and eventually you made the decisive error blundering the bishop. Black gave up his dark squared bishop up to weaken the white pawn structure, but in compensation white had his two bishops. While those weren't always especially strong, they eventually totally dominated the knights in the endgame (one of the risks black had to accept when playing Bxc3) . It is very difficult to tell, where exactly black got into a losing position - certainly from a practical point of view white already had excellent chances after black took the pawn on h3. When one looks at the opening, both sides committed several small inaccuracies and there was the big chance for you on move 17, but in the end it just added up to a small advantage for black. Nothing really decisive had happened until you gave away the g2 pawn for free. Except for the occasional tactical slip (like 32.Rf1?) and missing the occasional tactical chance for yourself (17.Nxe6!) you played the game quite well, usually you seemed to have a good idea of what you should do strategically, but sometimes you didn't seem to be watching your opponents options closely enough. A lot of strong players think that one of the things resulting in a great improvement in playing strength is analysing tactical positions on your own (writing down the variations etc.) and then comparing the results with the annotations of strong players. That way one hopefully learns to consider all options of both sides and to assess very clearly which plans can be carried out tactically. I hope my review helps.

jaberwock: This opening starts like the French Defense, but gets weird here, and even weirder in the next few moves. This has got to be an inferior opening for black, but as you will see, I have a difficult time exploiting it. jaberwock: Black apparently plans to play an unisual Hedgehog system, setting his pieces and pawns on the second and third rank, virtually daring white to go for black's throat or to build an impressive looking center which black will proceed to attack.

I prefer to reserve this square for a pawn to support d4, as black often strikes at white's center with c5; I would play Bd3; If black should play d5, then white's reply e5 would lead to a French Defense where white's king bishop on d3 fits in better than black's weakening h6.
Where is black going with this? I guess I should just keep developing my pieces. jaberwock: Yes, developing, and reinforcing the white center is the task at hand.

I think the modest e2 square is better for the kingbishop, as this move invites tweaking by pawn to b5 by black; while weakening, this is the type of move that black may need to consider to obtain concessions from white on the center.

What kind of an opening is this? It seems really weak for black, but I'll be darned if I can find any killer moves to take advantage. jaberwock: I completely understand - and share - your frustration with black's liberties with the opening, and there should be swift and brutal retribution, but alas, there is no killer lightning moves. However odd his position is, black's method can be quite sucessful by white if the latter gets impatient or pays too little attention to his center.
Again, I don't like placing my bishops where they may get tweaked, here by an eventual e5 or g5, though the latter would be double-edged forblack.

Maybe e3 was a better place to retreat to, but I'm not too worried about the h pawn marching up to trap my bishop. I can always take the supporting g pawn with my knight. jaberwock: Agreed that e3 is the better location for the bishop; on g3, it may feel discomfort by a pawn rush by black, after Be7 to support the g5 pawn. Also, Be3 could better support a f2-f4 push by white.

I consider this a serious positional error by white. By allowing black to close the center with e5, the position now resembles that of an Old Indian Defense, where white has declared that black gets the play on the kingside, and white gets the play on the queenside. Unfortunately for white, his plan consists of moves such as c4, b4, a4, Rc1, Qc2, c5, and right now his Nc3 and bc4 are actually in the way. this gives black a head start on his kingside plan...
This move shows white's heart is in the right place, but without proper preparation, black will successfully close the queenside, whereupon he can focus undeterred on the other side of the board.
I'm just looking for any opportunity to unclog the toilet, but every offer of a pawn exchange is refused.
This move really has no purpose.

At this point, I am getting behind on the clock, because I just stare at the board looking for something useful to do. I don't want to lose this game on time, just because my opponent wants to keep every piece on the board.

Your annotations are wonderfully honest, and that is truly appreciated. You acknowledge that you have no plan, and feel you need to do "something". - I've been there, frequently, and recently. In my post-mortem review of the game, with no clock pressure on me, let me offer some ideas for white: Since the queenside is locked shut, I would consider having my king take a walk to that sector of the board,a s it is unlikely that the queenside will be ripped open, so the king might be safer than waiting for black to build of his sledgehammer on the kingside. Also, consider wher you want to place your pieces. f5 is an inviting square for your knight(s), after Nc3-e2-g3 and Nf3-d2-f1-e3. Also, the white king bishop is unhappy with so many of the white pawns on white squares. So instead of Qd2, wite could consider trading it off with Bc4-e2-g4, after moving the king knight. Note that these are ideas based not on exact calculations, but on positional considerations which seem to fit closed setups like this.
Unless there was a juicy target such as a pawn onh3, I would leave the black queen on d8.

I don't know what I meant to accomplish with this move, but I just can't breathe with this board. Again, I can't just stare at the board and watch my clock run down. jaberwock: While white has wasted some time, it's not too late to consider the plans mentioned before.

OK, that wasn't a great move. I know that it will weaken my king's protection. I'm just looking for some sort of pawn break. Got any other bright ideas? jaberwock: Having been there and having done this myself before in some of my games, this move shows some desperation by white, who sees none of the plans forementioned.
I'm thinking that I can attack h4 one more time with Qxh6 on the next move, but that doesn't work out, doesit? jaberwock: no; this just loses a piece.
Now, I am under attack, and I do whatever I can to protect g2. Perhaps an immediate g3 is better than what I chose. jaberwock: I don't think either choice matters. It looks lost for white.

Offering a more-or-less forced queen exchange with Qg3 might be a more effective way of defusing this attack. jaberwock: That will prevent a quick mate, but will lose in the endgame, remaining a piece down.
I think that this prevents black from mating me with Qh1. Luckily, black thinks so, too. ;-)

27... Qh1 was mate in 2 for black. I'm lucky he missed it. With the knight gone from f4, my king has an escape route. jaberwock: He misses the mate and coughs up the extra piece. Sometimes luck does have a place in chess, and we have all been on the giving and receiving end of it.
I had my eye on trapping the black queen after moving my king. I missed one key ingredient. My knight would no longer be protected. jaberwock: I would play Nd3, protecting f4 and f2 squares.
Black is winning again.
I can pin the h knight with Rh1 and follow that up with Rg1. I don't remember what I had in mind with this king move.
I'm thinking that I can skewer the rook after the queen moves to its only safe retreat of h2. I see that black could choose to win two rooks in exchange for a queen, if he wants.
Don Octave: I didn't anticipate that, though.
Now, I think I have the upper hand, even though material is even.
why not Rah8 to win h-pawn?
I'm happy just to trade down, now. I've been studying my end game play. jaberwock: Excellent. Endgame study will may tremendous dividends.
OK, I missed that.
Moving that rook just to g2 with the intention of moving it to the h file is probably a better idea. I'm thinking of keeping my g pawn protected in case I have to move my king.
I don't mind making this trade, because I can win a rook by promoting my h pawn.
Well, that was a surprise! I should have a pretty easy win from here.

This probably wasn't the strongest choice, but I still think I won't have trouble winning after the exchange. jaberwock: I applaud this choice; You transpose into a winning pawn endgame, instead of keeping rooks on the board, allowing any cheapo counterplay.
That is just a waiting move. I get a passed pawn with any pawn move by black. And, if the king moves, I can force him into a difficult spot.
Now, I just need to wait for my passed pawn, and be careful to leave black with a pawn move to avoid stalemate.
A tough battle; You were fortunate to dodge some winningcombinations , but forced black to try and find moves that he didn't.
This was my first official game that I played the Benoni but it turned out well.

Now I was unsure about the continuation, but this seemed a good move to me. *death: It is a good idea not only to have some idea of a reasonable single move, but to have a consistent plan of development and action. 10... Nbd7 may be playable (Grandmasters have played it, so who are we to be overly critical - let/^s just say it is as playable as most Benoni lines. ...), but it tends to lead to do-or-die positions in which black must play rather unnaturally to generate kingside attacks. Part of the problem is the bottleneck on the d7-square, which is a useful transit point for both knights, the light bishop, and the queen. Anytime it is occupied by one piece, it tends to cramp the other pieces who want to use that point. A more positionally logical (though not necessarily more practically successful) continuation is .. .Na6-c7, which reduces some of the congestion on d7 and also supports a future ...b5 advance. ...b5 is part of a plan to expand control of the long dark diagonal for the fianchettoed bishop.
12.Qc2 is mostly played here *death: 12.Re1 doesn/^t seem the most incisive. Probably 12.Qc2 or 12.Ra3 both offer white a fairly significant edge.
after analysing I thought this move was good, but now I think it is bad. I could better do 12... g5 and h6 to take somesquares

I knew tha t this was a bad move, but what do you think of this lines? *death: Superficially, white justifies this exchange by thinking of good and bad bishops, but this overlooks the fact that black/^s bishop is part of the cramp/ congestion (especially of the d7 square), and after the exchange, black/^s "bad" bishop on g7 is actually the most important minor piece on the board - it is technically "bad" but active, operating in front of the pawn chain and controlling key central squares.
White must make some concessions on the kingside now.
exchange is better for me
I/^m not sure I agree that this is such a good move. It is a good cheapo, of course, if white captures....
A good shot. Now black wins most efficiently.

What exactly is this?! I am never sure how to respond when White deviates from 2 c4. I am prepared to play a Nimzo and thats it. What responses by Black are best in this position? you've many possibilities. 2...e6 is of course correct; 2...g6, d5, c5, d6, b6 too. It depends on your style of play.

Looking back at this choice of giving away the dark-squared bishop, I would much more happily choose c5, in an attempt to challenge White's central control. Do you thin this is better or worse? Is there other possibilities that are superior? 3...c5 is very good and natural; it seems logical, as White develops quite passively. No doubt about that, as GMI Portisch played it :). I put ?! to your move because of 4.c3: White can obtain the typical structure of a Colle, with a tempo more, due to the poor position of the Bb4.

With this moves it seems I've relegated my self to a defensive role. It doesn't look like I have much counterplay, and my pieces lack good squares. Ther must be a better move than this, or perhaps I'm in trouble already. you're right. 7...c6 is too passive. Two moves seem logical and have been played: 7... b6, with the idea Bb7, Nbd7 and c5; the other one is 7... Nbd7. If you want counterplay, you must be able to push c5 in good conditions.

Here I am definitely thinking "Kingside Attack". My pawns are pointing there, telling me which way to go. I have some kind of pressure down the open e-file. Was this the right idea? I can see that White has many more pieces developed in that general area. The pressure you have on the e-file will not last a long time, after the 10th white move. But what remains is the square e4. If you could install a piece, say a knight, on this square, it would be interesting. And if White repells this piece with f2-f3, then the e3 pawn will be less strong...
Looking back, I wouldn't mind trading my bad bishop for his good one, even if it doubles pawns on the g-file.
He has a good outpost, but I think I felt I could challenge it right away.
Fine! you have occupied the e4-square. Now I think that you've equalized.

Looking back this looks a little foolish, putting the Queen on perhaps an inferior square. Maybe 15...Nf6, ensuring a knight at e4 was better. It is true that Black could quickly trade down on this square, but I would end up with a rook sitting pretty none the less. What was a better move at this juncture? 15... Nf6 is interesting but has an obscure side... White will NOT exchange on e4, neither will give you the opportunity. So your two knights are aiming for only one square, e4... The drastic 15...f5 was worth of interest: it holds firmly e4, prepares eventually the opening of the f-file with f5-f4. About the move played in the game, 15...Qf6, I don't see what aims the queen here. It seems that at this moment you are playing without any plan. Try always to have in mind a more or less general idea what you want to do. For example here: "I want to open the f-file, so I've to prepare f7-f5-f4"; "I want to attack his king with more pieces, so I've to prepare the rook's transfer on g6 or h6"...

We can see in the game that the rook is misplaced on e6 (cf. your 19th move). So better was here 16... Re7. Another path was interesting here: as it's clear that White wants to play Nf3-d2 (the only one explanation for 16.Re2), you can prepare a consolidation of the e4-square by playing 16...Qg6!; 17.Nd2 f5 and Black has good perspectives.

Now I have only a pawn on the e4 square. Surely a knight would be better, forcing him to trade off his bishop and helping mobilize my rooks. If White played f3, would it create a weakness to exploit at all?
The loss of time I spoke about in the comment of your 16th move. Now your rooks looks miserable and useless on the closed e-file.
after 22.Bxd5, the endgame is very good for White. So it's better here to hold on the position and to challenge the d-file with 21...Rd7.

Threaten ing both the a7 pawn and attacking the knight twice to its one defender. Perhaps the simple retreat 23...Nb6 woould have been the answer? My head is still swimming with "Kingside Attack" but I have also hear block before you punch (from one of Silman's books).
22...Nb6 is better for black. But after 23. a4 and 24.a5 White gains more space on the queenside.
I mean who needs pawns when you're going to win in a few moves anyway?

you seem to have a nice position to attack his king, but you've too many weaknesses: your back rank, the f7 pawn and your Nd5 pinned on f7. Because of all these weaknesses, the mobility of your pieces is reduced, and so your attack.

My ignorance of possible threats and of my queenside pawns was too much to compensate for. My biggest question is was this a winning position for Black at any point? If so, what plan should I have attempted to see it through? I thank you for your advise - MIW. I think that the turning point of the game is as the 15 and 16th move. There, you could have taken some initiative. At the end of the game, as you saw it clearly in your analyse, you give too many pawns for an unsufficient attack: unsufficient because of weaknesses in your position. About the opening, remember in closed game to avoid Bb4 if White can reply with c3.

I have to say that I dislike this move. As with all openings it is important to get your pieces on the correct squares and I think if one were honest this move has to be a bad idea. The bishop is more likely to be better at f5, but in any case the decision can be delayed. I think that c5 is good for Black. In these slow white openings I think Black has opportunities if he can challenge early in the centre

The idea was to call Black for and exchange by Bxg4 and then have the h file already open against a possible opponent's castle. Given a second thought, I dislike it a bit, since I would have preferred a kingside castle, which now becomes too dangerous to perform. Probably better is Bxd6. Killerman: I agree with some of your comment but not all. Firstly, I would not take the the exchange on d6 as after 6 Bxd6 cxd6 the e5 square is not available for the knight. Furthermore Black has an extra pawn in the centre and may get the opportunity to play e5 at a convenient time to free his position. So Bg3 is sensible.As for castling I think that your king is OK to be left in the centre as it is unlikely that the middle of the board is going to come open that quickly. Your choice of move is therefore fine.
c5 is still better I think

Aiming to 8. dxc4 Bxc4! Killerman: Funny, I would be looking to capture Nxc4. Does your bishop really have a long term future on c4? I think not really but one or other of your knights has a future at e5.
I think this Black move is almost the only possible to avoid that the c6 square gets really weak in case of 9...b6.

The negative effect of this move as I see, is the fact that now B has the "a" file open against the latest possibility that I had for castling queenside. As a result, I start thinking to leaving the King in the center. Killerman: I agree this move gives black some opportunity at last on the a-file. White is still Ok though and leaving the king in the centre is still all right. Castling kingside is still a possibility as without the queens on the board Black is unlikely to be able to drum an attack up on the k-side

I am not sure about your choice here but I guess a plan is not easy to find either. Both sides need to complete development which will be the key to future success in the game. Therefore moves like Bd3 and Ne5 I still like for White. cxd5 does no acheive anything. The tension in the centre has gone and Black controls the c4 and e4 squares permanently now.

Overwhelming positional play: it appears b7 is almost the only weak square now, and Ra7 protects it. Killerman: I would say that whilst I agree b7 may be a weak point. How is White going to get to it? I think there are better moves such as Re8 or Nbd7 here.

Square e5 is a Black semi-weak square and it stil could be defended with the f-pawn, but would require the N to move away from f6. Killerman: You now recognise the e5 square as important good and well played. The position is still level here I think.
Obviously the opponent cannot live with that!

I don't like this move as the N, once captured, would leave the pawn in e4 in a white strong square. Killerman: I understand your concern but actually Ne4 is not really that good here. Bf5 first is better, when at least any recapture by Black does not have to ruin his good pawns.
But I didn't really see this, and the continuation, that allows Black to gain a full pawn! Killerman: Yes you need to now play Kd2 or Kf2. As you say the rest is easy after g4 for Black.
A big big mistakes, as it loses the B.

And there's no way to carry on defending b4. Killerman: A level game until move 19 so well played for that. I think you need to concentrate on key squares and the development aspects of moves. The square e5 was a key square throughout but you may not have recognised it as such early on. The pawn centre did not need resolving when you played cxd5 as if Black had captured on c4 you would have been OK so why did you decided to do it? You had already recognised that after c4 dxc4 you would have played Bxc4 so why the change of plan? I suspect because it was not easy to see a better one and I agree it isn't an easy position to play. Finally, as with many closed openings like this they lead to a very slow developing type of game which I admit is not to my taste. However, it is just as important to complete your development before your opponent as nearly every game of chess can show that he/she who develops first wins the game. Thank you for allowing me to look at your game and good luck.
not the main line. Usually White plays 3.c4 or 3. Bg5 or 3.g3. The idea of the text move is to prevent Bb4 but White should not be afraid of it.
I don't understand this move.
White's position isn't very good. He is back in development and the only active piece is the Queen.
finally Black played f6 but now it's not the same because he hasn't more the light squared bishop on the longdiagonal
it is not easy to find a good move for White now with the King still in the center
a wrong move that allows White to equalize

I'm not too familiar with Q-indian defenses - which is why I played in this manner. e6- offers to transpose to the french defense. d5- puts the game in the more comfortable Q-pawn openings Bracco: There's nothing wrong with this. It's a pure matter of taste.

Couldn't find this in any opening book. Seems best to gain time forcing a retreat. Then again, looking from white's POV, The c1 bishop is going to be a problem since e3 will likely be called for. Bracco: White was hoping in 3..., Nf6, with transposition to Torre Attack. This opening may become very dangerous if black plays careless moves, but in normal circumstances black equalizes soon.

I don't like this move. Black pushes back the Bishop for a while but seriously weakens his pawn structure with no reason. Furthermore, the natural development square for the knight is temporarily unavailable, and the "e7" square can be used by only one figures among knight and bishop. Better would have been 3...,Be7, putting an immediate question to white's bishop and keeping the structure intact.

The opening is not what I had in mind, but getting as many shots as I can a the bishop (Nxh4, NxN seems superior for black) - seems to be the best course for development: especially since f6 deters Ne5. c5 is an equally good alternative - Let me know your opinion, as well as other alternatives I did not consider Bracco: In my opinion the best option is "c5", challenging White in the center and opening the "d8-a5" diagonal for black Queen. This manoeuvre is typical in those openings where white early develops his QB, like Trompowsky and Torre attacks. However, your idea is logical and perfectly sound in this position.

Again, the Bishop exchange is useful since, for the moment, I'm slightly ahead in development Bracco: I disagree. Should white trade off the bishops, Black remains a meningless tempo up but with a misplaced knight in g6, not to mention the pawn structure. The move "c5" was still preferable.
At a fisrt sight I didn't understand the meaning of this move. After some analysis i saw that the trade in g6 woul have left black with a weak pawn in g6.
Long overdue, in retrospect - Annotator - Still in time

That, i believe , is a mistake by white. I believe black can now create an isolated white pawn at d4. - Annotator - In my opinion this move is perfectly playable and logical too. White has already castled, it is better developed and wants to challenge Black in the center. Furthermore, the "d4" pawn isolation is not forced. See the sample variations.
If I can't win a pawn immediately, I thougt at best to mainten the tension. 0-0 is another. Also, e5 is becoming interesting. Bracco: After the c5 push, your move is logical and strong.

exchanged everything, got my isolated pawn, but I no longer believe I have an advantage. On the contrary - e6 is weak (also pinned, after I played 0-0). Bc8 is stuck. ditto for Ra8. The next few moves will revolve around th e6 pawn - and not d5 as I hoped. Bracco: Your pinned and unprotected e6 pawn (remember 3...,f6?!) is a serious weakness, but the isolani in d4 is a weakness as well! Did you considered to abandon the e6 defence in order to concentrate in an attack to d4? see the variation
no rush, but the pin makes me uncomfortable.

No idea why white did this: b4-is no threat that I can see. I see no real threats for black either on a hypothetical Nb4.- Annotator- An obscure move to me. Probably white wants to free-up the "a2" square for the bishop in case of Na5. The immediate Bxd5 (see variation) seem to win the initiative (or a pawn), but is very laborious to realize the advantage

Lets use the time gained by white's last move to solidify the defense. Suddenly, d4 is an attack option again. Bracco: White has wasted one fundamental tempo, and now his weakness is under strict control

now the purpose of a3 is partially clear. white will continue Bb1, Qc2, Kh2, Rh1. I'm unconvinced that this really was whites plan (this is, in fact, what he did). he seems to good a player to plan such a cumbersome and transparent move.

can't help you here. I don't recall why I made this move (game was played 2 days ago...). Contuation to h5 doesn't seem to be very effective. - Annotator- With coherence, Black could have strenghten his control on d4. See the variation. Qh5 looks useless, in fact.

White seems determine to go to q K-side attack. I wouldn't- his advantage isn't big enough. were I white I'd continue putting pressure on E6- Incl. D5 (taking advantage of the Q's bad position at e8). Bracco: I agree.
fix the problem at d5. Bracco: After 18..., Qf7 Black frees up the path to d8 for the rook, and there are no risks neither in d5 nor on the king side.

The "strange" attack again. It doesn't seem likely that white genuinely thought this would work (white is a veteran on FICS, and is rated ~2000). But I see no other logic. White's planned h7 sacrifice is easily countered. Bracco: White, an experienced player, is probably grouping pieces over the black king. The immediate sac in h7 gives nothing, but... shoul black play carelessly, how about a white queen in h5? :-) Black had to take some countermeasures. The push in "f5" closes the diagonal for a while, but has the drawback of some holes creation in the King's defence (e5 and g5). This is the way veterans play: with some threats, they force the opponent to create weaknesses, hoping to take advantage from that. Furthermore, this is a "standard game" on FICS, but 15 mins is not that much... Something can be overlooked :-)
presumably headed for f4 Bracco: and in the immediate, to protect "d4"
make Bc8 a real piece

No doubt planning Rh1 Bracco: White decides to abandon his weakness and to concentrate on kingside attack. A good practical strategy. Probably this plan is not the "real truth" in this position, but it has good practical chances, expecially in a short time control game.

get rid of (black's) useless bishop, and GAIN a pawn: too good to be true. Once again, black has attack prospects. -Annotator. Yes, in a correspondance game black would have rejected easily the kingside attack and won the endgame, but in a 15 mins game? With the clock that runs, runs, runs... :-)
gain
White continues to pursue his attack.
easiest counter:exchange queens- I now believe I have a winning endgame: the Pawns at f5 an e6 are the main reason, also, nicely active knights (facing a dead bishop at b1)
apparently, white agrees with my assessment.

Error on my part. since the pawn at E6 would be lost. I should say that at this point, I was getting into serious time problems - white has no such concerns at this time. Bracco: the first time truoble consequence: black blunders a pawn.
Despite having no time problems - this move is as bad as the last one made by Black. Bracco: White ignores the material equality and gambles: will black survive to his zeitnot?
The pawn loss has now been averted.
Qh6-forcing the q-exchange is looming.
looks nice, but I don't think it will last.
A better move would have been Nb4!
gone- and the e6 pawn lives.

probably a ood move on his part - but at this point I had lots of unjustified confidence. I was also moving very quickly. this game would go on to 80 moves - but I had roughly 3 minutes left at this time. Bracco: To comment a blitz makes a few sense, in my opinion. White plays on time, black tries to keep the extra pawn and to survive to the zeitnot. Black will win at the end, but there's almost nothing that worths any further didactic comment.
Capturing with the Rook would have been better, I think.
Now, we'll see if I can make the extra pawn work
Get the king in the game. At this point I had a sketchy idea about freeing the pawn at the h column. Again, lacking time, my analysis here was not very good.

apparently white saw the H-pawn options too. This, in my opinion, is an over-reaction. The pawn is not an immediate threat, and ther rook can be used elsewhere: For instance, for preventing my next few moves.
white seems clueless. Though I believe this part of the game is being poorly played by White (I'd appreciate any thoughts on white SHOULD be doing) setting up g3 seems like a good idea.

And now its a race against time (by viewing the game on the server- you can see the clock progression. but not through the pgn file, unfortunately. I have roughly 90 seconds. and must now gamble that I can make something happen soon. therefore: exchange the rooks and see what I can do with the H-file pawn.
G4-would be better: though white loses another pawn-it has no immediate continuation (and has no time for devising one).
At this point: I believe White is lost. He will gain the pawn at D3, but the black king's superior position will win out.
Can't see anything wrong with Rxd3.
White's next move is a critical mistake, in my opinion. Kd4 is Mandatory for white: it equalizes the situation, and considering that black has little time - should win. Bracco: I totally agree

white loses no matter what he does now. do you concur? Comments from this point are irrelevant. The game becomes a race as to whether black can get to mate position in the roughly 40-50 seconds that black has remaining.Bracco: White has no pawn moves and black, depending on white choice, will penetrate in e4 or c4. The game is over.
Better is ...cxb2 or ...Nf6. I think for only a small time before Nxc3, to check for threats. PV 5. Nxc3 Nf6 6. Nf3

Another mistake. I don't see any real threats to me. I look at 6. Qh5 g6 no good (NG), 6. Qd5 Be6 no good (NG), 6. Qf3 Nf6 NG. I keep searching for tactics to punish the mistakes, but find none. Finally decide on straight development, KN first. Don't see many threatening responses. PV 6. Nf3 Nf6 or Bg5 and I'm OK

A third mistake. He should have played Nf6. I see 7. Bxf7+ Kxf7 8. Ng5+ K moves 9. Qxg4 wins a pawn, destroys his castle and I have maintained superior development. I am very nervous about playing sacrifices like this. I check over and over. 7. Bxf7+ Ke7/d7 9. Bc4/b3 and believe I'm up a pawn, he can't castle and I'm better developed. I don't think I really seriously consider other moves.
A real blunder, as we'll see. Both
Black would have been a piece up, had he seen
I carefully consider his dangerous replies before 9. Qxg4. I'm OK after ...Qd7, ...Qe7, ...Nf6, ...Nc6, ...Be7. PV 9. Qxg4 Nf6 move Q and I'm ahead.

Very unsure on 10th move. Spend a lot of time. Don't want to blow my 1 pawn lead. That is, I think I'm ahead by one pawn. During annotation I realize I'm even in pawns with a lead in development. During game I'm not clear about how much of a lead in devel, because I thought I had a 1 pawn advantage and that outweighs everything else. This mistake -- not knowing what the material situation is -- affects all the rest of my thinking for many moves. For this move, I check aggressive things like A) 10 Qe6+ Qe7 11. Finally let's have an overview to this game so that I can give you a piece of advice: First, follow the opening books when you are a novice. The main lines suggested by opening books are precise enough to assure you of an even position. As on the 4th move, dxc6 is the book move and better it is than bxc6. Second, drop some prejudice on position evaluation. I guess it was your fear of weakening the kingside that caused your miss of playing g5 on 12th move and Qc8 13th move, in fact they are playable since it is long before white can mass pieces over the weakened field. Third, check the practicability of a move before making it. This can help avoid implementing strange ideas like 18...a5?? and making blunders like 21...Qe7??. Above all, the more practice the better. Good luck!
