Post game my opponent told me that his pieces had more power on the board. but I don't know what this means. mazeta: "his pieces had more power on the board" pieces that control more squares have a role usually aggressive make a mess in your territory for example you could look at the position after the 21st move In general black started the game with a slow development and left behind (moves 1-7) and you obtained an excellent position. But then you chose to close the center when it would be more logical to try to open it even by sacrifising.Then (moves 8-14) you stopped developing and you regrouped your already developed pieces but almost the same position arise and that gave him the oportunity to continue developing without giving him any problems.Then 15-21 he copleted his development having posted all his pieces in nice squares.In the last 22-29 moves you are forced to react to his threats untill the game ends.If the question is "why i lost?" then i would say that you stoped developing and lost the initiative and didnt try to get advantage of his lack of development.I have given some variations which I think they are not better moves that you didnt see but moves that arise from the need to fight for the initiative.

at the time, this seemed logical, but now, it seems like exchanging the knight may lead to a slight advantage for white.white has a decent position. MAd: Other moves are more common replies. In my database I have about 10000 games where this position is reached and 4. ... a6 figures in only 640 of them. Black does not score particularly well with a6, but it is by no means a losing move. So why is it that players prefer to avoid it? Black is pretty much offering a Ruy-Lopez Exchange where the moves Nc3 and Nf6 have been played. In the Ruy-Lopez Exchange after Bxc6 dxc6 white cannot capture in e5 as Nxe5 Qd4 Nf3 Qxe4 gives black a good game. In our case Qd4 has to be preceeded by Nxe4 Nxe4 when, after Qd4, white has the time to castle therefore retaining a good position.

a normal developement move with several alternatives. However at club level games are rarely won in the opening, and one needs not worrying about them too much. If one just takes this game as an example, both black and white make several judgment and planning errors in the opening, then both make a few tactical miscalculations and white wins pretty much because it is black that makes the last error. At our level it is far more useful to concetrate on tactics than study countless opening books, so I strongly reccomend solving tactical puzzles, the more one solves the more acute his tactical skills will become. With time two-moves combinations will become easier to see, then three-moves and so on. With constant practice one can be able to eliminate bluders from his game. This is far more helpful than knowing that a line is +/= after 17 moves, especially if one has no idea what to do on move 18. So as far as simple tactics goes a common mistake I have seen in this of position and one should be wary of is the attempt to trade the bishop for the knight with b5 followed by d6.

it seems to me white wasn't quite ready to jump in the center at this point, unless he is simply hoping for an exhange. MAd: indeed this looks akward and castling would seem more appropriate, however Spassky has played once, so it can't be too bad. The idea is, of course, to trade for the Be7. It is also worth nothing that after the trade white has again the c3 and d4 plan available, after a few preparatory moves like 0-0 and Re1. The game is now very much a Ruy-Lopez, with white trying to exert pressure on e5 and black parrying the treats with a counterattack against e4.

I decide that parting with my dark bishop is okay, as I will then take the opportunity to control the dark squares with pawns (which otherwise would have blocked in the bishop). MAd: parting with the dark-squares bishop is ok, see both Spassky-Nikolic and Van der Wiel - Nunn below, and you don't really have any choice in that regard since Bc5 is met by Bg5 forcing a sad retreat to e7. This move however seems a waste of time for many reasons: 1) You are not forcing white to play Nxe7 (or Nxf6), he will play it anyway; 2) White wants to play c3 at some point, whether to push d4 too or to avoid trading his Bb3, now it will come with a gain of tempo; 3) The problms you need to solve in the near future is how to develop the light-square bishop and how to support the e5 pawn your move does nothing about eithr problem; 4) you lose the possibility of answering Nxe7 with Nxe7 which truly frees the c-pawn for an eventual c5 hindering any idea white may have about d4. Moreover from e7 the knight can hop to g6 to provide help in any action on the king-side. 5) You offer the possibility of Nxb4, see the note to the next move. I include a game with d6 and one with Bb7 so you can have a look at how things may develop.
I expected him to take the bishop, but this seemed okay to me as well.

the only retreat. Of course, I knew this move was going to have to be made. Unfortunately, (and this I wasn't thinking of) the c3 push is useful to him anyways, so he gains a tempo. MAd: exactly. Note that you also have lost the chance of trading the Nc6 for the Bb3 now.

It is probably time to pause a moment and consider what white and black can do here. Both are still undeveloped: white needs to put the king to safety before taking any action in the center or his majesty can end up in big troubles. His dark-square bishop needs to find a new home, but it is not quite clear where that is. It may go to e3, but that would make a d4-push more difficult since the e4-pawn can no longer be defended by a rook in e1. So should it instead go to d2? but then what would it do there? We can't put a piece on a random square and call it developed. Maybe it is a good idea to wait a little to decide. On the plus side white has a very solid center and and he just needs a couple of moves to be able to break with d4. Black king instead is absolutely safe, but the e5 pawn is a bit shaky. If white can organize d4 exd4 cxd4 black can be in troubles. The light-squares bishop is to be developed as well: a possibility can be then d6 (which incidentally supports e5) and then decide for a square on the c8-h3 diagonal. Another plan may involve Bb7 and Re8 to answer to a d4-push with exd4 uncovering an attack one e4. In the end the whole game revolves around white wanting to play d4 and black wanting to keep the push inoffensive. To this aim Be3 seems premature, while it supports d4, it also makes the Bb7, Re8 plan more effective.

now his bishop has nowhere to run... except an unfortunate retreat to c2 MAd: the retreat to c2 is not unfortunate at all. True the bishop sits behind two of his own pawns, but it is not useless there. First of all it provides a support to the e4-pawn when d4 is finally played, second it is aimed at black king-side. Maybe it is time to stop a moment to discuss this d4-push and why it is so important. White dream goal is to play d4, force black to take exd4 and take back with cxd4, and then manage to roll the two pawns kicking away the black pieces from the 6th rank, and gaining space for an attack on either side. Black of course doesn't want to hear any of that and he will try to stop with any possible means. He can for example control the d4 square with as many pieces as possible, starting with the Nc6, but also bringing the bishop to f6. He can also attack the Nf3 that controls d4, typically with Bg4 (that's why h3 at some point is so commen in the Ruy-Lopez). His other option is to attack e4, white main weakness, hoping to divert enough white forces to that task to make d4 impossible. To attack e4 black can play the light-square bishop to b7 and the rook to e8, and of course a knight to f6. A third option is to allow d4 exd4 cxd4 and then attack white center with c5, d5 or f5. The majority of Ruy-Lopez follow either of the three plans or a mixture of them. Such a volatile situation also means that tactics of all sort are always present and one has to be wary of that. It is also worth to remember that after the d4 push white can try to continue with f4 opening the f-file and the b1-h7 diagonal on te black king. Many a Ruy-Lopez have been decided by the Bc2 coming alive after a d4/f4 push. Supporting your center with d6, or developing a counter-attack against e4 with Bb7 and Re8 would have been a good choice. However your idea is not wrong at all since after Bc2 black can take advantage of the white king and strike in the center with d5. It is clear now that Be3 was an error and castling should have been played instead.
it seems like this exchange is much in blacks favor. MAd d4 at this stage is plain wrong. White has lost control of the position and has let enthusiasm carry him.

I still didn't want to take on d4 here, because he ends with a strong center. This frees the bishop. MAd: he ends with pawns in d4 and e4, but they are not strong. The e4-pawn in particualr is undefended so any attack will force e5 which makes the white center rigid.

developing the bishop, and making the queen move. I might end up moving this bishop again, but even if/when that happens, we'll be even in tempo... in the meantime, I hold a big diagonal (unchallenged, since he lacks a white squared bishop). MAd: You are still in time to play exd4 this time followed by Re8 with pressure on e4. The Be6 forces the queen to move, but in the end she was useless in b3, while from c2 she can support the e4-pawn. In a way you're lucky he plays it to d1. The Be6 also masks the e4-pawn from an attack by a Re8. The position is pretty even, white main weakness is e4 and you should attack it with all your migtht. From e6 the bishop dream of an attack to the king-side which will never be.

supporting a potential d5 push... the d and c pawns, though a bit "backwards" dont' seem to very threatented... MAd: Finally hitting the right tune. White weakness is e4 and pushing d5 is the only practical way to attack it now.
waste of time. Bg5 is not a threat and the queen is better in c2, supporting e4 and leaving the d-file for a rook.

the straightforward response to white move, I think. MAd: White is not threatening anything, Bg5 would be welcome as it is not so good. Pushing h6 if anything gives white a hook for an attack to the king and now all sort os sacrifice ideas can come to his mind.

I d been hoping for a d5 push, and this move was intended to defend the e5 pawn after the push. MAd: If you do not remove the queen from d8 any d5 push will most likely end in a heavy pieces trade along the d-file and and even endgame. Moreover it is a good idea to occupy the file with a rook before opening it so the queen move seems to make sense. However you forgot that white can open it too, especially since he is already occupying it with his queen and rook, and we will see this next move. You hit the right spot: e5 might be weak when things open up, but rather than defending it with Qc7, you might have attacked one of its attackers.

apart from undefending the knight, this move also precludes any h3 push to move a bishop off the g4 square. The knight is asking to be pinned to the rook. MAd: This move is simply bad, moreover I don't see what white is trying to achieve with it, if he wants to move the knight to play f4 then h3 followed by Nh2-g4 would have been better. Nh4 will always be answered by Bxh4 when white pawns are horrible. All g3 does is weaken the knight and the white squares around the king. White misses his chance to take control of the d-file as mentioned before.
I put off my d5 plans for this obvious move. Now, the Qc7 was even unecessary.

I considered something like Qd7 here, to go for action on the c8-h3 diagonal, but decided it would be fruitless. MAd: d5 in itself is not bad, but you kind of missed the point. The knight is pinned to the rook and defended by the king alone, why not try to attack it with a second piece? And what piece can we use? Well the Rf8 is already there, all it needs is removing a couple of obstacles from her sight...
His pinned knight can't accept a black pawn on e4. MAd: This simply drops the exchange.

here I missed the obvious e4, which would have won a piece. His pinned knight was restricting is options, but I failed to capitalize. MAd: This is a pretty bad error for two reasons: first of all you miss your chance of winning the exchange, secondly this move is contrary to the spirit of the position. White king side has lots of weaknesses, all of them on light squares, the Bg4 is the one piece you need to exploit them, why do you give it up?
at this point you can easily end up losing a pawn. On the other hand white king is in the middle of the board so you can try to organize an attack rather than a trade.

greedily hoping to get back the whole pawn.... MAd: taking in d5 hoping to organize an attack on white king was the safer option. With this move you allow a passed pawn in d6 and you need to be very careful.
this is the start of a very passive defense. You may have tried Rfe8 instead with the idea of Re6

the open file matters more than the pawn, now, I decided, since I can't win it anyways. MAd: your problem is that after Rd7 one of your rooks cannot move, and on top of that it blocks the queen. White has a couple of moves "for free" to organize himself. Your choice is probably as good as it gets in this position.
White agrees. MAd: and in this makes an error. This leaves the pawn weak and you now have time to regroup.
I no longer have to block the pawn, so I defend the rook. MAd: White can easily take the e-file now and aim to bring a rook to e7 since you are not putting any pressure on the d6 pawn.

this invites 29. Re7, in hindsight. 28... Re6 was needed. I considered this in spite of missing 29.Re7, and decided against it, since I certainly didn't need to isolate any pawns. MAd: this is bad because it is the prelude to losing another pawn. So far white had to prove that he can push the d-pawn. You have no other weakness he can exploit so it is a complicated task facing him. Now you let him win a second pawn, gaining a lot more options as you have to be wary of that one as well.
This is the real mistake and it loses badly, white enters the endgame two pawns up, and with your king cut off by the white rook.

this is hasty. the pawn from d6 is making life hard for black as the king has no access to e7, so it is difficult to attack the pawn. Moreover the white king can come relieve the rook from any "pawn defence" duty faster when the pawn is in d6. A better idea was to support the pawn with the king and only then push it. White can also create new weaknesses in black position with a4, exposing the b5 pawn.
With the pawn in d7 the king cannot come to his support but white was still on time to attack white queen-side pawns.

white has a straightforward endgame now, that I <think> I played correctly. Unfortunately, white did okay too! MAd: this endgame is dead won for white, it was worth playing a few more moves to make him prove he can win it, maybe not all the way till the end...
This loses even faster since now white can easily create a passed pawn.
and black should really resign here.

Some final comments to the game. It seems to me you missed the min features of the game, in particular that white tries to push d4 and black has to do something about it. In itself this is not horrible, we are all bad players and fail to grasp the basics of a position, however it seems to me you spend the first 10-15 moves wanderig around with your knight without a clear aim, at most with one-move threats like playing Na5 to trade knight for bishop. That Na5 was also meeting the requirements of the position is a typical example of serendipity. Again though you moved the Be6 because it was wit hgain of time, without worrying if e6 was the right square for the bishop. At this point you decided to push d5, probably because you had the bishop in e6 anyway. What I mean is that you did not play Be6 because you wanted to support a d5 push, but you decided on a d5 push because the bishop happened to be there. Here you got worried of Bg5 and a couple of moves later failed to notice white could open the d-file with a complicated position. A few blunders on both sides meant you ended up allowing a passed pawn rather than being an exchange up, and you got scared of it and played passively missing a good chance to achieve a draw and making it easier for white than it should have been. In the end white managed to convert the pawn endgame and won. This is the description of the typical game between club players: the only difference between a 1400 and 1800 is that the 1800 makes a litte less blunders and plans a little more. This is where you should concentrate your efforts: start by making sure you no longer miss winning the exchange like you did. That you tactical skills need a bit of effort is also shown by your notes: you thought you would win a piece while you were only winning an exchange. Solve problems from magazines and books, when you have finished go back to them again and check if you solved them faster than the first time. Then do it again. Your tactical senses will be more awake during games and you'll win the exchange without even thinking about it. When your tactics starts improving have a look at games on the openings you play: pick a good player that plays one of your lines and look at what he does, don;t learn his moves by heart but try to figure out what he is trying to do, what weaknesses in the opponent he tries to exploit, which ones in his position he tries to defend. I strongly suggest you pick classic openings like the Ruy-Lopez or the Queen Gambit Declined, they are best to learn about developemnt, piece coordination etc... Anyone who plays traps and sidelines can gain a few rating points fast but the he stops. But most of all do not get discouraged by losing, you learn a lot more and improve a lot more by losing to a better player than by trashing a weaker one. Feel free to contact me online on FICS if you want to discuss about the game more in details.
9. exf6 was undoubtedly the better choice, but IMO white has lost the opening discussion
White is getting a bit desperate and want to get some pressure on the center a3 was an idea but then black could even castle kingside and blast open the queen side
Ne3 was possible already
forcing black to play a good move

Desperation! My first instincts would be to take the material offered and run with it. But as my opponent was higher rated than me I decided to play the initiative instead That is the source of the zeitnot and nervosity that will plague me for the rest of the game
Here I'm offered a plethora of choices and I decide to try to keep the Knight on h3 out of the game.
Nf2 seems to be the better move but black still has lots of activity and the bishop pair
Whites last chance to exchange Rooks is squandered
A grave error Rxd5 was needed
Rdh8!! and its good night but I have less than 15 seconds left on the clock and choose a simpler move thats still better for me.
I should have played Rh8+ to force the game, but its still close to won
A move I did not see! gasp, think fast Bxc4 seemed dangerous but why??I dont remember anymore, brainghosts most likely
Saved! maybe but he king is cut off

Rc2 seems stronger as it restricts the black king, guards the a pawn and prepares the advance of the g pawn. It also forces black to choose between harassing the g pawn and going for the queen side pawns with the king.

The beginning of a self destruct campaign, activating the white king and repositioning the white rook to the second row where it guards the q side pawns. The big question is if I could have save the draw with Kc6 instead activating the king
Here I resigned as the king is still awhol and white is splendidly activated

Once again I attempt the O'Kelly variation of the Sicilian. White has cleverly chosen the move 3.c3, which leads to a kind of Alapin variation where White has an extra tempo because he already has a knight on f3, while I have wasted a turn playing a6. I know this move to be the best reply from the 50 000 game database of ChessMaster 7000. Compare the following (which are master level or above games) 3.c3 132-100-67 (White scores an average of 0.61 points +/-) 3.c4 52-34-48 (White scores an average of 0.51 points, =) 3.d4 31-39-60 (White scores an average of 0.36 points, -/+) 3.Nc3 14-11-12 (White scores an average of 0.53 points, +/=) He hasn't played d4, so its time to play some good moves. Killerman: I agree White is going to achieve a better position potentially than Black. As we shall see White develops to an Advanced French position where the move a6 is of no real help. You appear to recognise the weakness of this set up so it is important to remember that when faced with such a prospect you must try to get something going in the position to compensate for this. Your development is key and I believe you now make some bad choices.
A premature move I think. You need to reconcile the centre first. Are you really sure the bishop is going to be placed here? Maybe not but the d pawn is likely to go to d5 so play it now.

Normally when I see a player do this I am quite happy. Now I have targets to aim for in typical hypermodern fashion. On the other hand, my king looks quite poorly guarded from White's point of view. I figure that one knight moving to g7 would be enough to guard the king against any onslaught, was this a bad decision? Should I have made further measures to ensure his protection? Killerman: Let us look at the respective positions and see where the problems lie. White has good development as well as a space advantage a kingside attack is bound to come soon. Black has many development problems. Not castled (danger maybe in doing so), bad bishops, lack of space. In this type of position if black just sits back he will get squashed, so it is important to find something dynamic to do. trouble is finding the move.

This allows the "Classic Bishop Sacrifice" which I saw looking from White's point of view the third time I was reviewing the game. Now all the comments I have made regarding king safety seem to make sense it is all up to White as to whether or not my fate is immediate.
I guess he was in a generous mood. Bxf7 was surely better.

The end of a 3-move excursion for my dark-squared bishop. I figured since the center was closed that time was no longer of the essence. Was deciding to move the bishop at the cost of three moves a mistake? Was there a better place that it could end up? Killerman: I agree that routing the bishop in this way was not a bad idea, but i am still concerned by the general lack of development in your position. Although a little risky the following variation is quite interesting.
A mistake that goes unpunished

Here I figure was the most important choice of move in the game. We are told to 'capture towards the center' in the majority of cases, but looking back I think that fxg6 would have been better. If I had recaptured with the f-pawn, perhaps I could have moved my Rook back to f8 or put my Queen on the seventh rank, thus preventing penetration by the White Queen. Which was better, to capture fxg6 or hxg6? Killerman: After the last few moves Black now finds an equal position. Either hxg6 or fxg6 are fine. I would have made your choice as I don't believe that Black is likely to be able to use the f-file.

I do not wish to trade down, as I still want to target both the b2 and d4 pawns with my Queen. I did not want to invite the White queen over to this sector of the board, but perhaps I should have. Would the move Rxc1 have been better? Killerman: I do not like this move and would have traded rooks. The problem is the bishop is now pinned to the rook.I would exchange rooks and play Qc6. The bishops must end up being better than the knights

Now I have some kind of middlegame plan. I wish to mate the White King. I see that if I can get my light squared bishop to b5, I may be able to put pressure on White. The problem is that it will take an extra move to get the rook off the c-file and White has a much greater threat he could have used perhaps even now. Should I have continued pressuring the White queen- side, or should I have done something different? Killerman: Mating the King is a little optimistic here. I agree with pressure on the queenside. Trading rooks previously would have helped draw white away from your own kingside.
The last real mistake which costs the game Re8 is probably OK here.
Now I know I'm in trouble. I had been neglecting the king and now it was time to pay the price.
At this point I frantically serach for a mating combination, but there are none. Some level of panic sets in and I blow the rest of the game, despite the fact that White is also short on time.

At this point I am simply goofing around, the game was over long ago. I feel that if I had made just a few simple changes, it would have been White who was in this shape! Killerman: An interesting game with chances for both sides. I distrust the line for Black as it looks too passive to me after c3 and d4 for White. However you did appear to handle this well albeit should have lost after 0-0. My tip in this game would be to look at the Bc6 move that you played and say why? , because I think that if you wish to pressure the queenside you need to get rid of the rook. You will also have the advantage of the two bishops if you can get the position to open up. Bc6 and the subsequent Qa4 eventually caused the loss although time pressure probably was a factor by then. Thank you for allowing me to analyse this game.
I've never seen this line before. I figured taking it was not a bad idea. Of course.
did not see that the Bishop can take the pawn at c2. I was too concerned with attacking. I'm not used to the continuation and do not know the proper retaliation.

Loses the exchange with black's next move. Black should be careful though that his queen does not fall into a trap where it cannot escape.
Playing 11. ... Bxf1 immediately loses to 12. Ne1 ! and the queen has no where to go. Breder: After this move the position is again lost for Black.
I need to keep the queen off e3.

I'm the exchange up so why not simplify. The game shows, why the black queen is much better on d6 than on d4.
I thought this was avery good defensive move keeping the White Knight and Queen out of b5.

I used great amount of time in finding this move out. Taking the queen to far out is met by. 25. Bd7 + or 25. Bf7 + and a mating threat at e7. 24. ... Qc7 is met by 25. Bd6 followed by 26. Rd1.
Another good defensive move protecting the e7 pawn and this seems to halt White's mating attack.

Angleman forf eits on time. Angleman: I just lost track of time here. Any way I can still fight for a draw with 28. .... Bg7 29. Bf7+ Kf8 30. Qe6 ! ( This what 27. ... Qc6 ) was suppose to guard against.) 30. ... Re8 ( giving back the echange ) Breder:
with advantage for black,e.g.:

Hi. My name is bOdie (LiquidThug on fics). I play the English Opening. I dont know any other opening that is why. I have played this against Arasan and crafty many times. I dont like this move. The knight will get a very nice place on d5. You played Re1 a move later. I would prefer to play 11. Re1 right now and place the rook on the open file. In my opinion there is no reason to kick the black knight.]

Obviously he wanted my bishop. I thought of moving the bishop to g6. Should I have? If he captures at g6, I capture with h-pawn and get a half-open h-file against the castled white king. Would that be better than let him capture at f5? I can always castle on the queenside if needed to. ACA: Your move seems good enough. But Bg6 also seems viable. But instead of capturing with the h pawn, I would opt for capturing with the f pawn. This followed by the move ... e5, after protecting the d5 pawn with c6, gives you enough counter play in the center. Capturing with the h pawn followed by queenside castling doesnt seem good. White can easily start a massive attack on the queenside with his a, b and c pawns before you can assemble an attack on his king.

I hate to make a weakness in the castled king position but I want to fight for the center and I did not see f4 helping with that. ACA: 9... Ne4 seems good. His capturing the Night (Bxe4 or Nxe4) would close the center and you can easily start a kingside attack with Qh4, f4-f5 and possibly your rooks. His other pieces would be trapped because of the closed center. If he playes f3 then

maybe c5 would have be better but he could capture and give me an isolated pawn and that was not appealing to me. I saw that c7 would be a good square for my queen. maybe I should have played b6 to prepare c5? b3, c5, and then Qc7? ACA: The isolated pawn that might arise after c5 is not a problem here. His position is toatally cramped and he has no simple way to use that isolated pawn. On the contrary, after ....Bxc5 you start exerting even more pressure on e3, which is now quite weak due to the move f3. If you ask me an isolated pawn on d5 in this position is by no means weak. It protects e4 considerably, and now your night is free to play to c5 and e5 where it can further your attack. c5 seems a better move than c6.
wondered why he didn't play e4. he could, right? ACA: It seems your opponent was affraid of the following

a mistake? he did have his knight to guard h2. Now I get a good grip in the center with more space than white. ACA: Your opponent just doesnt seem to care about the center! yes it is not a good move. But your previous move b5 doesnt seem to be part of your plans. It seems you didnt want your opponent to play c4. As I stated above the isolated pawn would still be of no bad consequence to you. Infact, here if he plays c4, the c-file might open up for a possible attack with your rook.

I think my queen, bishop, and knights are nicely placed. I do not see any better squares for them. I have a rook on a half-open file and the other rook, well, I did not know where to put it. This ends my plan from the opening which was to get good control of the center and good squares for my pieces. Now I need a new plan for the middle game. I decided to play for king -attack starting by putting my rooks on g and h files and advance the pawns to open the position. Well having a bad plan is better than having no plan at all. I wonder. Should i have doubled my rooks on the e-file and put more pressure on the backward e-pawn? or should i have play to expand in the queenside and try to increase my space advantage? Well, you tell me. ACA: All your pieces are placed for a king side attack, so a qeen side attack with the help of your pawns doesnt seem right. Also attacking the backward e pawn with your rooks doesnt seem viable as he has bishops and a night protecting that area, while you cant attack with any other pieces than your rooks and queen down that file and on the pawn. So your plan sems good enough.
That do es not look like a good move. That put the king on the g8-h2 diagonal with my queen and bishop. I decide to try to exploit that.

Should I have capture with the knight? I did not like the idea of him playing Qh5 which I suspected he was trying to do by his last move Bxe4. ACA: dxe4 is better. The game got not exactly good for you in the next position and if not for his blundering his night, you wouldnt have had such an easy game. By capturing with the dpawn, you have one more pawn in the area where the attacks are going.
uh oh, his knight is heading for g4 and possible exchange of my knight. I did not want that and I especially do not want his queen to get into the melee.
stops knight move to g4. I love to frustrate my opp's plans.
I don't think so. his knight is not going to f5!

Now that my rooks are in place, I did not see any good sac to rip open the position. I did not see any way to force an opening of the g or h files. I played this because I can see that I can get the knight to a nice post on g3.
a blunder? this seems to lose the knight.
another blunder? should he have played Kf2?
I want to attack the pawn on g5 with my f pawn but I want my king to be out of way and in a safer place. Also it is getting to the endgame and a more centralized king is good in the endgame, I know.
I decided not to attack the g5 pawn but to see if i can advance my passed pawn and try to get my rooks deep into the enemy's camp via the e-file.

yes, I know. a terrible blunder. I was pressed for time. Yes, there was no time controls but the game was taking more time than I expected and it was late and I wanted to get the game over with and so I started to move faster than I should have.. I am a poor blitz player by the way. ACA: Re4 would have won it for you.
Another blunder. this time, fatal.

Oh well. I thought I was winning. Got the table turned on me sure quick, sigh. ACA: A famous player (dont remember who it was) once said "the hardest games to win are those which you are ahead in" (or something like that). Never play fast in such positions. Your opponent made blunders. But so can you. The important thing in this game is your plans. Your making what seem to be adequent plans. Work on refining them. White had a very cramped position from the beginning. This was a sign to you to start openning files for your rooks and diagonals for your bishops and weak squares for your knights. Dont worry about isolated pawns, especially isolated center pawns. They can sometimes be very valuble. Your game was quite good in general. Hope I was of any help.
Book until here, isn't it ? AD: This is a common position.

I was waiting for 11. Qf3 trying to double my f pawns, then I would have replied 11.... Be7 the same way. AD: 11.a3 wastes a tempo, because Black was going to move the Bishop anyway. According to the 13th edition of Modern Chess Openings, 11.Qf3 Bd6 12.Bxf6 Qxf6 13.Qxf6 gxf6 14.Rad1 Be6 = is the main line. "White has pressure" after the side line 11.Qf3 Be7 12.Rae1 h6 13.Bc1!, which is a manoeuvre that White is unable to undertake in the game.
It looks like this is not needed. AD: This is another dubious move. More useful is 13.Qf3, because it is not worth a tempo to prevent 13...Bg4 14.Qg3 Bh5.

I didn't like to play this, a bad move! It would be better to play 13....Be6 or 13.... h6. AD: In this opening, it is usual to put the Bishop on e6, which gives the option of ...c5 later. On e6, the Bishop prevents ideas like Rxe7 (after the Black Queen has moved from d8) followed by Bxf6. On d7, the Bishop impedes the other Black pieces somewhat.
soon I noted that this was an ilusion. Black really can't take on b2 because of 16.... Qxb2 17.Reb1! Qxc3? 18. Bh7+! winning. AD: 15...Rb8 is more accurate because of 15...Qb6?! 16.Rxe7.
The weaknesses created by 16.b3 cause problems for White. Better is 16.Rxe7 Rxe7 17.Bxf6 gxf6 18.Qg3+ Kf8 (or Kh8) 19.Qf4 Kg7 20.Qg3+, which draws by repetition.
This improves Black's position. 17.Bg3 is stronger.

It was better to take with the queen threatening doubling the white f pawns 17.... Qxf6 (18.Qe3 loses a pawn by means of 18.... Bxa3!) (18.Be2? Qxf3 19.Bxf3 Bf6 and the knight on c3 hangs) (18.Qg3 Bd6! 19.Qf3? Qxf3 20.gxf3 Be5). AD: 17...Qxf6 is slightly stronger than 17...Bxf6.

now the consequences of the previous bad move, black needs to avoid b4! and the queen have to accept the uncomfortable square on a7. AD: 18...Qxa1 19.Rxa1 Bxa1 looks risky for Black, since 20.c3 Re1+ 21.Kh2 leaves the Bishop on a1 out of play.

with this move, white showed me that I was fighting for a draw. It took much time for me to calculate the possibilies ahead and still I don't know if I have chosen the right continuation. AD: Black should be OK here, since the Bishop is better than the Knight, and the a3-pawn is even looser than Black's pawns. The line 21.Qxf5 Be7 proves that Black is not worse.
21...Re7 is more productive, since Black makes progress even if White plays 22.Rxe7 Bxe7 to prevent the doubling of the Rooks. Even stronger is 21...Be7 22.Ra1 Bd6 followed by ...Qe7.
a desperate move trying to simplify the position by exchanging material, having in sight that my a5 pawn is hanging. AD: 22...Re7 is the right idea.
23...Bxe7 prevents the following Queen incursion.

I made this move with great conviction that taking on a3 would be a bad thing because of losing the d5 pawn's best friend (c6). AD: 24...Qxa3 25.Qxc6 d4 is also playable. Worth considering is 24...Qc7 with the idea ...Be7.

I was already in time trouble and was afraid of white playing 29.Re1 Bf8 30.Re8 and black would have faced more problems. AD: The Bishop is already well posted on the long diagonal, so it is stronger to activate the Rook with 28...Rd8.
29.Nd3? white was in time trouble too. AD: 29.Re1 Kf8 30.Ra1 is a possibility, but 29.Ra1! is more direct.

30.... g6? what a terrible blunder! Especially because two moves later I played g5 giving white the opportunity to put his pawn chain on the white squares. This shows that I lack of some endgame knowledge too. Even if I had time I wouldn't know how to force white to put his pawns on the black squares. In fact, I don't even know if this is possible in this position or if this is really important once soon the white rook will be creating threats on the 8th rank. AD: Generally, Black would prefer White to have pawns on light squares so that White's dark squares are weak and Black's Bishop is not impeded. However, here it is more pertinent to improve the positions of the pieces. After 30...Bf6! (to cover a1) 31.Re1 Rxe1+ 32.Kxe1 Kf8 the position is rather drawish.

It looks like black is in "zugswang" after 35.f3!. AD: Zugzwang is when the side to move would prefer to "pass". The position after 35.f3 isn't Zugzwang because the Rook is en prise. In any case, 35.f3? is met by 35...Rc4.

once I heard that in endgames it is better to protect my own pawns than to take opponent's pawns but I was short in time and wasn't sure that I could protect the d5 pawn. AD: You have it backwards! Defending pawns is passive and reduces mobility. The difference between accepting passivity and forcing the opponent into passivity is often worth a pawn or more. In Rook endings, for example, the side with the active Rook is often able to win from a pawn down or draw from two pawns down.
it looks like it was much better to play 38.Ne5 creating threats on the 7th and 6th rank. AD: 38.Ne5 leads to nothing after 38...Bc5 39.Nd3.
Game drawn by mutual agreement. AD: Black can safely play on. For example, 39.Ke1 Ra2 40.Ne5?? Bb4+! 41.Kf1? Ra1+ 42.Ke2 Re1+ wins for Black. Even 40.Kf1 Kf6 is worth exploring.
This is the Classical Defence to the Ruy Lopez, which has been played since the 15th Century. More usual is 3 ...a6.
4...Nf6, hitting e4, is more natural and better. The text move is timid.

I'm preparing to attack the e5 pawn again with a fianchetto. It seems like c3, d4 is a better approach. DM: I agree that 5.c3, planning d4 is better. 5.b3 is too slow in an open game. Black has ...d6 to defend e5, which means that e5 can only be profitably attacked by a pawn. White could also play the old fork trick here with 5.Nxe5, but 5.c3 is correct. It is not that 5.b3 loses material, but it does mean that White has no chance of securing any advantage from the opening.
DM Black has at least equalized now, which is highly satisfactory after six moves.
This is best. White must attack the black squares in the centre to activate the Bishop on b2. 7. c3 is worth a look, and it isn't bad.

I decided to gambit the pawn for development. After all, I'm still attacking the pawn now that it's on d4. DM: This is the losing move. White gets no compensation for the missing pawn. Losing a central pawn is a serious matter. Also, note how clumsy White's development is compared to what happens after 5.c3. (see above) Instead of going to his natural square, c3, in one move, the knight has landed on d2 and will have to move again to get into the game. The Black pawn on d4 is not only an extra pawn, it is a bone stuck in White's throat. It had to be removed immediately ... there was no alternative. What happens here is not a gambit or pawn sacrifice, it is the loss of pawn. There is all the difference in the world.

Now I think I should've exchanged the knight for the bishop. Bd3 is better, too. DM: I think that your move is as good as anything else in this position. The Bishop is on a diagonal which aims at Black's king. I certainly would not have taken the knight, which gives Black the Bishop pair and brings the other knight from a 'nothing' square to c6, from where it protects d4 and e5. 9. Bd3 is fine too, aiming at h7. I'd even play Be2 rather than take the knight!

Again, Chessmaster plays a very tame move. Yes, it gets the Bishop off the back rank, but why not a more active move, to set White problems? 9 ...b5 gains space with tempo. 9...Bg4 pins the knight, and if 10. h3 Bh5 when 11. g4 is far too loosening for White to consider. 9 ...Ng6, aiming at e5 and f4 improves the position of the knight. 9...Be6, fighting White's best piece, is interesting. If White takes, which he shouldn't, Black has the 'f' file as an avenue for attack and a strong pawn centre. 9 ...Be6 10. a3 (or 10. Ng5 Bxc4; Nxc4).

I want to push my e-pawn and open up the center. DM: I think that this move is fine, but I'm a bit worried about the reason for it. Why would you want to push the 'e' pawn and open up the centre? If Black now plays ...Ng6 he has control of e5 and the pawn push isn't possible. Also, note that if White ever plays either c3 or e5, Black can swap pawns, undoubling his 'd' pawns.
10 ...Ng6 may be more accurate.

I felt that Bd3 would cramp my position too much. Of course, now I can't push the e-pawn. This also pins the c6 knight. DM A tough decision. This is what makes chess so difficult. I don't think the pin on the knight is significant because it is easily broken. My problem with your move is that the bishop is almost sure to be captured and after re-capturing, the white pawn on d5 will be very weak and a target for Black. 11. Bd3 can be answered by 11... Ng6 which rules out the e5 push. 11.Be2 and 11.Bf1 are both quite reasonable. You are right to be concerned about a cramped position, but what is cramping you here is the black pawn on d4.

I feel this was a wasted move now. perhaps c3, renewing my attack on the d-pawn, or a3, opening up the queenside, or allowing my knight the use of the c4 square. DM: I think that one important thing to notice about this move is that White now has an unguarded pawn on a2 as well as an unguarded piece on b2. It may seem that they are in no danger of being attacked, but things can change very quickly. Add to that the fact that Black can invade on b4, and the correct White move suggests itself. 12.a3! (it's not about opening up the queenside) keeps the Black pieces out of b4 and protects the 'a' pawn. One of the things that is most striking about grandmaster games is how seldom they leave anything unguarded ...pawns, pieces, important squares. After 12.a3, a possible line would be 12. ...Nxd5 13. exd5 Ne7 14. Ne4 Nxd5 15. Nxd4 Nf4.

I considered Nxd1, but decided that would make my knight worse than useless. DM: I agree. The Queen capture was correct, but you were right to consider the alternative. We ought to consider all captures and checks (both for us and our opponent) on every move ...sometimes the apparently crazy ones turn out to be strong.
I can't defend all 3 pawns here.

The immediate Nxd4 or Bxd4 seems to have no continuation. DM You played the right move here. You had to lose one of the pawns and the d5 pawn was the one to choose. It was too weak to survive, which is what I was talking about when the bishop went to d5.

I think this move was my undoing. Winning a pawn is nice, but I really want to trade off that bishop. 16.Nxd4 doesn't get me that. 16.Bxd4 just loses a pawn with tempo. Perhaps 16.b4 would have worked. I don't see a good response to that. DM: No, you were undone when you lost the pawn early on. It was necessary to capture on d4, otherwise you are just 2 pawns down. 16. b4 is easily answered by 16 ...Ba7. After 16...Ba7, 17. Nxd4 would be correct.
A useful move, which activates the queen with a threat to d4, puts her in the vicinity of the white king, and enables the black rook to come to e8 if required.
White could try 17.Qe4 but 17 ...Qxe4; 18.Nxe4 Bxd4 19. Bxd4 Re8 is winnning for Black.
luft and tempo look good, but is there a better move? My position is beginning to crumble and I have no counterattack I can see. DM: No, there is nothing better. The game is lost.

Why didn't I play b4 here? That's the second time I missed that move. I would have loved to trade queens or something to reduce his attacking power, but I don't feel there were any opportunities from here on. DM: Don't worry about not playing b4. I've added some analysis to show that it does no good. It's worth noting, though, that 19.c4 creates a 'hole' on d3, that is a square which is not protected by a pawn. Black's later Qd3+ would not be possible with a pawn on c2. Of course, we must advance some pawns, usually we advance one on move 1, for instance, but always remember that pawn advances are two-edged: They gain space, but leave weaknesses behind them.
I try to retreat, but it's blocked DM: 21. Kh2 is slightly better, but it's not enough.
Qe2 just loses the knight

Qd1 seens more versatile now, but I didn't even consider it then. I felt 23.Qxf2 was forced DM: It's not forced. You might have tried 23.Qc3, threatening mate on g7, but Black simply plays 23 ... Qxc3; 24.Bxc3 Bxh4 25.gxh3 Bxh3+ 26.Kg1 bxc4 and the Black win is obvious.
What else? Nf3? DM: 24.Nf3 Ne4. Or 24.Rc3 Qb1+ 25. Kxf2 (25.Bc1 Nd1) Qxb2

White has no more defenders, but Nf3 blocks the bishop. Bc1 isn't even a real threat because Bxe2 comes with check. DM: 27.Nf3 Bxf3; 28.gxf3 Qxf3+ After 27.Bc1 there is a forced mate in 5, which computers never miss!

Conclusions This game was decided in the opening when White lost a pawn for no compensation. White made no great blunders in the rest of the game, but he was never able to recover from the early setback. A human opponent might make a tactical error to allow you back in the game, but computers never do! My advice (I wish I could always follow it myself!) would be: Don't lose material ...one pawn down is usually enough to lose against someone who knows what he's doing. In the opening, concentrate on getting a fair share of control or occupation of the centre. Remember that we (or the opponent) can attack pawns and pieces, but also squares. Squares can be strong or weak, and if they are centre squares that is vitally important. Sometimes an entire game can rest on control of a single square. In the Sicilian, for instance, the game often hinges on control of d5. So, in the opening, concentrate on: King safety Control of centre Piece development Black's attack worked because he had positional superiortiy. Tactics are always available in that situation. If there had been no available attack, Black could have won by swapping off the pieces and his 4-3 pawn majority on the queenside would have done the trick.

This is one of the more unusual lines in the Caro Kann with moves like 3. Nc3 or 3. e5 the most popular. This move is a rather artificial way of supporting the centre pawns and it also takes away the f3 square from the knight. It does however avoid a lot of opening theory and the centre is supported in the hope that White might get a central pawn advantage later on.
I believe that 4.Nc3 supporting the centre and not weakening b2 is better. Black has two good replies to Be3.

I'm not sure if Qb6 is the right continuation, but from my perspective it tickles White's b2 pawn. Killerman: This is fine, developing in a way that forces your opponent to cover something is usually right. The alternative is 4... dxe4
The alternative is Nd2 which may be better, but still leaves White with a poor position.

Where else can the Knight can go? The d7 square is needed by my Bishop to clear the way for the King to castle queenside if it needs to. Killerman: In assessing the best plan there are a number of factors to consider. This is how I would deal with the problem. The first factor is the centre and if you look at the pawn structure it is clear that if Black is to attack White's centre it is by playing c5, it is the most natural pawn break. In addition the pawns on e6 and d5 suggest a queenside attack as they point in that direction. The second consideration is development. Are there any natural moves that I can consider playing? Well, Nf6 has to be a candidate move but neither bishop has a really 'good' square and I would suggest that the queens knight falls into the same category. The third factor is castling. Which side shall I go? Well, if I have decided in the first place that I am attacking on the queenside it is reasonable to suggest that the kingside is where I will castle. In conclusion then I am castling kingside and playing Nf6 and c5. Either of the two moves is fine and I give a couple of sample lines. By using similar logic to that which I give above will help you when you are undecided as to the best course of action.

Another attempt to annoy White at the cost of moving the Bishop twice, is this worth it? I was thinking if White plays a3 immediately I will reply with Bxc3 to double White's pawns on the c-file. Killerman: I prefer Be7 but your choice is fine and your reasoning is OK. I would add that you can also withdraw the bishop after a3 to e7 as happens in the game.

I'm not sure about this move. You are obviously following your plan of castling queenside, but as I outlined earlier I'm not sure of that as a plan. In addition White is threatning to take over space with the move e5 so putting the bishop on d7 takes away a square from the knight. I would therefore have delayed moving the bishop at the moment. The move 9.. dxe4 is best here attempting to loosen White's hold of the centre and giving Black a share of space on the board.

Do I have a choice? Black just doesn't have enough room for all of his army. What if White replies with Nh5? Kf8 would have been my answer, but is this adequate for Black? Killerman: No, you don't have a choice any other moves just lose material. If White had now replied Nh5 then either g6, or Bf8 would have been the moves to play. Although Kf8 is OK you keep the option open to castle queenside later.

I don't see what else to do, but I know I don't want to castle yet. Killerman: Black will now find it difficult to play the c5 break so a kingside attack is more likely. Castling queenside followed by Rdg8 gives you some attacking chances. If you leave your king in the centre for too long I don't see how you will be able to usefully use your queensrook
Although you now have an open file to work with it is not so easy to break through. Therefore I prefer exf5

is doesn't make a lot of sense as there are better moves to play. The knight does not yet have any future on b5 as it is bound to get chased by a later a4 and be forced to retreat thus losing a tempo. 0-0-0 is therefore better.
A wasted tempo I guess Comet was looking to double rooks and does not see the loss of tempo after a6 which Black is bound to play next.

White's attempt to pressure my Queenside ended up with Black's passed pawn. Comet B60 must have made a mistake somewhere. Killerman: Your position was solid and Comet has been a little optimistic in it's attack. The loss of tempo on move 27 has not helped either. Although the passed pawn will create threats it will be difficult to promote.
Another optimistic move and waste of tempo. Kf2 is still better as White will need to centralise the king and may need the piece to stop the passed pawn.

I have a pawn threatening to promote, but I just don't have the technique to remove the blockader and make it happen. Killerman: The pawn is now well supported on a3 so the plan has to be to bring up other forces to help. The king is a useful attacking piece now and the knight has good squares in b5, and a6 intending b4. White has little by the way of a counter attack and must defend.

The difference in my suggested line above and your choice is clear. White has had time to attack the pawn and both your knight and bishop are now having to defend. If your king had been involved in helping the passed pawn one of these two pieces is free to attack somewhere else. Don't be afraid in the ending to use your king.

I don't know if a direct Nc3 is better than this little distraction first, because the Knight exchange at c3 is going to happen anyway. Killerman: Nc3 seems to lead to a quick draw and Bg5 seems pointless as you do not gain anything. I would have tried Ra8 and try to bring my king up as before, but I think that now White can stop you from gaining an advantage in that line too.
The king is going the wrong way and gives you another opportunity to bring up your king to attack

My alternative is Be7 or Rh8, of which I think Rh8 is best because I don't want to lose a3 pawn. If White replies with gxh4 then Rxh4 Bc1? trying to exchange the pawn then Rxh2 Bxa3?? Rh3+ winning the Bishop. Killerman: I think the move played is best

I didn't see this move will force me to exchange the a3 pawn. I'm thinking that White now has a passed pawn at h2 so I need to bring my King to the Kingside. Killerman: I know why you played this but you can still win by playing your king to the queenside

For the rest of the game, my best hope is to play for draw because now it is White who has the chance to win unless he makes a terrible mistake. Killerman: After the loss of the a-pawn the position is drawn. The reason is the fact that the white pawns are on dark squares, so White's bishop is worse than yours. In addition even though white has a passed pawn White can't make progress with it as there is not enough space to advance and support it.
Here I offer a draw but Comet B60 refused.

A very interesting game. Remember that in endings it is important to visualise the best squares for each piece. Your advantage was the a-pawn which was going to tie down all of White's pieces so bring the king up was the correct way to win. Not that you could do much to stop the blockade of the pawn but you could use it as a threat. Another good point is that in an ending you usually need to create two weaknesses to win the game. By bringing the king up and then attacking the kingside with the 'extra' piece creates that weakness and the win. Even so you played a good solid game and deserved more. Thanks for allowing me to review the game.

A strange way to continue the French. After 3. e5 the knight is not able to retreat to d7 as in other variants of the French, where d5 was played, so if the knight doesn't want to retreat to g8, it has to go to the centre where white is able to develop and attack the knight at the same time. Basic opening rule: develop your pieces, never move a piece several times in the opening = loss of time.

to protect against ...Nxf2 5. Kxf2 and I lose ability to castle as well as disturbing my kside pawns... JK: I don't like 4. Be3. The bishop is somewhat closed in by the pawns f2 and d4, and the diagonal c1-h6 was under its control before as well. As I said before I think it's a good idea simply to develop, e.g. by 4. Nf3, and later start attacking the knight in its exposed position. Black shouldn't play 4... Nxf2 since 5. Kxf2 loses a whole piece for a pawn, and white is miles more developped. A piece is far more worth than being able to castle, and you are still able to achieve the "artificial castle", e.g. by Bd3(Be2)-Rf8(Re8)-Kg8. The Nf3 is very important now because it omits 4... Nxf2 5. Kxf2 Qh4+, which would mean trouble for your king. By the way, trying to capture the knight with 4. f3 doesn't work. The knight has not a single square to go; however, 4. f3 Qh4+ means trouble since neither 5. Ke2 Ng3+ (6. hxg3 Qxh1) nor 5. g3 Nxg3 (6. hxg3 Qxa1) look promising.

attempting to develop a piece and push back the black knight from e4. JK: 5. f3 still doesn't work because of Qh4+. But 5. Nc3 is not bad since black is forced either to exchange the knight that already consumed several tempi for yours that only used one tempo, or retreat it with 5... f5 6. exf6 Nxf6, giving up another tempo.

at least the knight is gone but now I have doubled pawns. None of my kside pieces have developed. On the other hand black has only developed 1 piece and it is off the board. JK: I don't think the double pawn is really a problem, for it is not isolated and you'll likely get several chances to get rid of it during the match. And you have the semi-open b-file, maybe for your rooks. If you don't want the double pawn, you could have played Nd2 instead of Nc3. As you said, you have a huge advantage in development, I'd in any case prefer white in this position.

I don't think he will take my pawn [dxe5] now because I will end up owning the file [7. Nf3 dxe5 8. dxe5 Qxd1 9. Rxd1 and I have the file]. JK: I don't agree with your variant. Having the rook in the open file is of course an advantage, but black is faster in castling and will bring his rook to d8 pretty soon. And now your ouble pawn is isolated. Nevertheless, Nf3 is not a bad move, developing and covering the essential squares d4 and e5.

Now his N is also attacking e5 possibly he may also ... f6 further attacking my pawn. I like keeping his pawn on e6 closing his QB in. I could move Bf4 offering another defender to e5 or Bb5 pinning his knight that is attacking e5. This would also clear my kside rank for castling... JK: Now you see why I didn't like 4. Be3. It doesn't do anything there and you have to move it a second time (to f4) to make it work. By the way, there is no need to act since e5 is attacked twice (Nc6/Pd6) and covered twice (Nf3/d4), so it is stable. But of course Bb5 is not a bad move since it develops, pins Nc6 and prepares white's castling.

The e5 pawn is still covered but if he uses his N to attack e5 there is a discovered attack on my B on b5. If so I would have to play Bxd7+ and not lose a tempo. On capturing my bishop I capture his knight at e5. His back rank is now cleared so the file will become contested now since he can deploy his rook to d4. Castle,

Bad mistake. What would you do after 9... Nxe5? 10. Bxd7+ Nxd7 and you lost a pawn, though having some advantage in development. Or 10. dxe5 Bxb5, also losing a pawn. Obviously something like 9. Rb1 had to happen, covering the bishop. If you have an uncovered piece on the board, always watch out if it cannot be attacked suddenly.

another attacker on e5 [still f6 available as well] Looking now I might consider [10. Bf4 ... 11.Rf1] JK: Luckily black missed the opportunity to win a pawn. But the threat is still alive. Around e5 everything is becoming a little tough now, so maybe it would be best to relieve the tension, maybe by 10. exd6. After 9... Bg7 Black doesn't have the possibility of Bxd6, which would have meant taking and developping at the same time, winning a tempo.

Now I don't like this move f6 is unpleasant... Not sure what I was thinking ... maybe 11. Qf3 ... 12. Qf7 [or if he castled 12. Qh1 ... 13. Qh7] anyway Ng5 was the move I made JK: Now black can take on e5 without any problems, right? The combination after 10... dxe5 11. Qf3 O-O 12. Qh3 h6 leads to nowhere. Ng5 looks like following no plan.
Well, black does't like your pawn. Second chance away.

Not sure why he moved Re8 ... is he afraid I might attack e6? because of my N on g5? Perhaps d5 would have possibilities?If 12. .. . Nxe5 13. Qxb7 [protecting my B on b5] Rb8 14. Qa6. Not clear enough... JK: 11... Re8 is crap. The e file is totally closed and doesN't look like it's going to open soon. Rooks belong into open files. And the pawn f7 is free for you now.

Attacking his Q. 12. Qxf7 may have been stronger. Could lead to Q trade. I dont want to see the N get pinned. JK: I would have preferred 12. Qxf7+ Kh8 as well. I looked at this quite some time and saw no way to get more out of it but the pawn f7, but a chess is - with exceptions - usually the more forcing move. Maybe you could have tried 12. Qxf7+ Kh8 13. Qf3, threatening the fork Nf7+.

N attacked twice only 1 protector. I lose N&Q for Q Not a good trade. Suspect 13 ... Rf8 coming up either pinning my N or attacking my Q. Now I think I should have moved 13. Ng5 Rf8 14. Qh3 looking at ... 15. Qh7++. ... if 14. ... Qxg5 15. Bxg5 winning a Q for a N. ... if 14. ... h6 my N is attacked with out a good escape square. JK: Nothing to add to this analysis, except from that after 13. Ng5 Rf8 14. Qh3 14... h6 omits the mate quite reliable.
If 13. ... Bxh6 14. Bxh6 will prevent Rf8. JK: All right.
As previously discussed ...

Now Black is concerned about the e5 pawn... must be wanting to bring his Q to f6 to contest the file. I was looking for Rf8... If JK: In my eyes this is simply winning back a pawn. As I mentioned before, black's attackers outnumber your defenders, so black can take the pawn. By the way, your second analysis that follows looks forcing (15... dxe5 16. d5 and so on, giving you the exchange; thus, black cannot take 15... dxe5, but 15... Ne5 16. dxe5 Bxb5 still works.

just tryin g to keep the knight centered and in play also attacking f3 to help prevent black from putting the Q there. My B on b5 is in trouble I should have traded off Bishops first. JK: Yes, you simply overlooked your uncovered bishop - which is enough to loose the match. Since the attack on h7 has no chances due to 17... h6, you should probably move 17. Qe2, Taking the queen out of attack and covering Bb5, or 17. Qh3 h6 18. Bxd7 Qxd7 19. Ne4.
attack on my f1 rook.
take the d file ... for now

Absolute blunder ... may be due to clock? JK: Of course this totally loses the match, but you were down a piece before, so your chances to get something out of it were rather small, even if you didn't do the blunder.
Next blunder ... pretty much all over ...
23. gxf3 Qxf3+ 24. Kg1 Qg2#
Pin the B JK: 25. gxf3 Qxf3+ 26. Kg1 Qg2#. But 25. Rf1 doesn't work either due to 25... Bxg2+.
Oh well
The N was trapped Moving the B to f2 let him get out. JK: No, the knight always had the retreat to f5.
JestMe resigns JK: You didn't do that bad, simply did some moves that were not exact enough.

You d have many other alternatives like 3... d6 (passive but playable and known as the Steinitz Variation), 3... a6 4 Ba4 - d6 (known as the improved Steinitz) 3... f5 !? (a very dangerous variation). Your move is ok but I would personally play the improved Steinitz.
The common sense says "Don't move too fast". I took my time and produced the following masterpiece
I didn't consider d6 because in a naive way I didn't want to close a side to my dark bishop Akaineco: I am sure it is a playable move, but I would prefer d6 with the idea of g6 , Bg7 and 0-0
Actually this is your first real mistake, The pawn does not fall at once if you take dxc6 :)
6th move and I am one pawn under... I thought "that's life... show must go on, the match is long"
My idea was to occupy the long diagonal and, maybe, get the pawn back. Probably Ba6 was better, in order to prevent white from castling. Now my target was to disrupt a bit white pawns' centre
That's what I wanted... Now let's look for counterplay on the king side.
White allowed this tactic and it was good for you to forsee it :)
Thanks to this I can gain a piece
2 pawns for one piece, with still the two bishops. I feel ok now Akaineco: You should feel ok about the tactic, but your opening needs some fixing .

Still feeling ok, I countered white attack and still got a better position Akaineco: The alternative I give you is more "sure". With the text you still have the better chances but you complicate the position a bit more
Maybe slightly better was Qf8 with the previous idea
You are allowing a tactic no one saw

Better was Nxf5, with the text white has equallity accoding to fritz. I Think here You did not Judge the possition well enough. 2 of your pieces are not active, but whites pieces are all in play. This means you have to find a way to put them All in play. ONLY THEN will your piece up count.
Aiming to press the king and strengthen the attack. Unluckily this way I let the knight come back in play and I lose the attack... From now on only defense for me

Maybe my definitive mistake, I was still thinking to be attacking and wanted to play a "solid" move, attacking the castle and strenghtening my king's position... I didn't see the obvious reply that follows Akaineco: Your final mistake
My king starts wandering here and there, my rook never comes in an active position
My last hope 33...Ba4 34 Qxa4 Rxc8 and at least the rook is back in the game

All in All it was a tactical game with many tactical errors for both sides. I personally like these games (maybe it sounds funny but I do) because they are human. I believe that Kxg8 was the beggining of many evil things for you because you let white complicate. You will have to remember That a piece up is only worth when it plays an active role in the game. White used his experience and puzzled black into some traps. I suggest 2 things. Firstly learn an opening bettter than the one we saw here and secondly when you are material up do not try to complicate but to "uncomplicate" Exchange heavy pieces and put all your pieces to action. I Hope I helped you even 1 bit :)
The Hungarian Defence which is a very solid choice for Black.

I didn't find this move in any of my openings books. Killerman: I don't think you will. I have it on a large database but it has not done well. I think the problem with the move is that whilst the Knight appears active, it does not look so after the bishop retreats. Black has also moved the same piece twice in the opening and for what? The normal move d6 continues with the development plan.
What about this bishop placement? Killerman: This is fine and I prefer it to Be2. You decided on your third move that you wanted to aim at f7 so be consistent.

This is the point at which I think White has to make a big decision. Both sides are nearing completion of their development, but I feel that White still has two small advantages. His pieces are better placed and he has a better grip in the centre. Whilst you idea of playing f3 is not bad I believe that f4 is very difficult for Black to meet effectively as it gives more control in the middle and Black has to waste further time in rerouting the knight. Your choice Bf4 is a little suspect as although you continue to develop I don't think your bishop has a long term future on f4. What would you do if Black played Ng6? Probably move it? If so have you gained anything? I don't think so and Black would have a knight on a better square. f4 seems to show why Ne5 is not a great move by Black.

I think h3 could make the castle weak. Better may be the plan I speak about before: f3,Qd2,Rad1,Rfe1 and if Black attack my bishop Be3. Killerman: h3 in itself is not a bad move at all it keeps control of the vital g4 square. I think it is your next move which was actually wrong as Kh2 does not need to be played. Your alternative plan would be correct starting with f3.
Optimistic

I wanted avoid Bxh3 but now, examining the game, I think that' s not dangerous. Is now the plan I thought about before starting with f3 good although the g3 square is weak? Killerman: Yes, I think f3 is OK as long as you are careful in the 11 Nh5 line.
The second time the knight has moved in the opening. Killerman: Well I agree and it didn't have to move but I don't think the loss of time here is too significant although I think Ng6 is better.

Hurry to occupy d5. Allows Black to simplify and get equality. How could I prepare it? Or what other plan does the reviewer suggest? Killerman: I think that if you look at your position you should see that both sides have one problem. Where are the rooks going? White already has more space and a grip in the centre, but like a lot of players the rooks just don't get going until later or when an obvious open file appears to put them on. What about the following line, starting Nxc6.
here it aim the wall

I declined my opponents draw offer and I tried to win, but because of my inexperience (I have a very small tourney experience) I risked the loss. Now I hope the reviewer give me a lot of suggestion about how to play endgames. Killerman: This endgame should be drawn just because of the symmetrical nature of the position. However, both sides need to be careful. The key to playing endgames is activity. As the board opens out each piece needs to be on it's optimum square. Pawn structure needs to be good and when bishops are around you have to be selective about the colour squares that the pawns are on. Lastly, the king. It is essential that his majesty is used and as it is unlikely, with few pieces on the board, that your king can get mated there he needs to be moving towards the middle of the board.

in order to get control of d7 square. Killerman: This is a tempting move but will only work if Black captures the bishop I prefer Kg3 bringing the king into the game. The problem with your move is that Black now finds a good square for his bishop on d5 where it becomes a better piece than your bishop.

How are both sides doing here. Well your king is better placed than your opponent, but still you have not found any weaknesses in his position. You do however need to proceed with caution and I think it is now necessary for you to play h4 to stop Black's g5 move. I think if you do this then Black will play Ke7 intending Rd8 and offering the exchange of rooks.
After this Black starts to get some initiative.

When the bishop can move between f1-g2 to hold the draw. To summarise the game. White held a good position but did not use the rooks to best advantage be aware of this as it is a failing in many players who start attacking before developing all their pieces. Once into the ending your king is an attacking piece so it must centralise. Activity is the key part of the endgame so if you get tempted to play defensive moves look again. In this case the ending was I believe drawn all the way through until your blunder on move 46. An enjoyable game to look through and I hope that I have given you some ideas. I would recommend that you perhaps get an endings book my favorite is by Paul Keres called Practical Chess Endings which is full of theory. There is also a very good book called Endgame Magic published by Batsford which is quite excellent.
Philidor's defence. A very common opening. I sometimes play that myself although I prefer four knights defence. It's a matter of taste! Four Knights and Philidor are two perfectly playable openings

This move was strange. I suppose he tried to increase centre pressure on d5. This move is thematic in the Philidor. To be honest, I heve never seen any game whit c6 played at this early stage, but I can't see any refutation so far. The proud c6 pawn basically prevents any White piece intrusion on the d5 square (a Knight or the Queen, very dangerous if combined with a Bishop in c4 with pressure on f7). If White advance his d pawn to d5, Black has two options: to trade the pawns with cxd5 or to further push his c pawn in c5 without allowing dxc6 e.p., that leaves black with a weak pawn in d6
IMHO a normal aggressive move to keep the pressure on the centre and develop an knight. Your Humble Opinion meets the approval of hundreds of Grandmasters all over the world !!! :-)

This move was really bad and I should've taken more advantage of that. The queen blocks the dark bishop and the queen might eventually get pinned in front of the king. Qe7 is a poor move, but there's no immediate way to exploit that. Hadn't Black played c6, an aggressive plan could have been 5.Bg5,Nf6 6.Nd5! and Black is forced to weaken his kingside pawns. Note that the pawn in c6 prevents Nd5, the most straight action versus themisplaced black Queen

I didn't want to take and allow him to develop his queen to e5 so early. I would have prefer the kingside castle, for three reasons: 1) Development 2) You moved twice a pawn in the opening with several pieces still at home 3) With d5 you blocked the center. Let me try to explane these three points. 1) the easiest one: Unless you have a valid reason to postpone that, please develop your pieces! 2) In the opening, move your pieces/pawns only for the strictly necessary number of times. In this case black was threatening nothing (exd4 could have met by Qxd4! - the e5 square is under White control). 3) In closed positions one or two tempo doesn't make a relevant difference; in open position they do! Black moves like Qe7 and h6 could have been punished effectively with a fluid center. Did you consider 6....., c5 as an answer to your push in d5? Black has closed the center and can take some breath (b6, Ba6 and Na6/d7 or g6, Bg7 and Nf6)
He just increases pressure on my e4 pawn in a normal developing move. correct
There was no need to alter the central structure. The center is VERY VERY important. One should alter the central structure only when it represents an advantage. Once more castling was preferable

I expected him to take back with his knight, but I suppose he wanted to avoid wholes in his pawn structure on the c file. Nxc6 would have removed the control of d5 square and weakened further the d6 pawn. With a pawn in c6 Black sooner or later can hope to get rid of the d6 weakness pushing in d5
I thought that I could lure out the knight to the edge as it would be less useful there. Correct

Trying to get rid of pawns so that I can check and catch his queen. Excuse me, but I can't figure out how you can get rid of your (blocked) pawn in e4 putting a Rook behind it :-). Black gets isolated double pawns which should be a weakness, but I was too tired to see any immediate attacking strategies. Black weaknesses are the most relevant theme in this position. A simple plan is to put the pawns under pressure keeping the initiative. If Black resists without any material loss, White can try to trade off as much figures as he can and play an endgame. With this pawn structure, if we imagine for a moment to take off all figures from the board, the pawn endgame is definitely winning for white!

I want to be able to move it along the third rank to begin a king side attack. This is a very important information to discuss. Rd3 looks like a doubling manoeuvre, but you played it with a different purpose, a King side attack. That's why FICS annotators want to know which was the idea behind every relevant move. In this position, as I told before, the most important theme is the bad pawn structure of Black. His castling is pretty well defended and has no weaknesses. The real problems for Black are the c5 pawn and the "d" file. The Knight in d7 looks somewhat silly defending the pawn, and doesn't allow the Black rooks cooperation.
Black wants to split up the middle to develop the rook, but a rook and a pawn is not enough.

I prepare a square for my knight regardless of the small weakness I just created. useless to say that this move is a waste of time. Since you were following a wrong plan, all the moves pertaining to it are at least useless. Better would have been Red1, winning the c5 or c6 pawn.
